reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to write a review about this game looking at it more as a F2P FPS than a Ghost in the Shell game. Yes its in the title. Yes the character models and things are there and people are getting annoyed because its missing some key aspects of the series.

But im going to cut that out and focus on the gameplay, mechanics and the pros and cons of it being currently in its Early Access state. Ive played going on 5 hours straight of matches while taking in the things I saw to help clear up any uncertainties people may have. (Be gentle its my first review and it's long)

Lets begin with the PROS that I found were good.

+Movement. It responds well. Decent running and movement animation. Even the action animations are solid. No bugs personally seen yet there

+Firefights are tricky in a good way since you cannot shoot through your own teammates and friendly grenades can kill you

+The look and feel of the game is pleasant and easy on the eyes. Yes people complain about the engine its on but its really quite decent.

+There is a market where you can spend in game currency (not NXcoins) to buy attachments, guns and other things. But so far, the things I can unlock through play are equal if not better than the things I can buy. Not to mention a laser accessory that I could unlock is 9900 GP to buy compared to a 44000 market one.

+As for weapons, each one has its prime situation. Yes the sniper is OP in damage. Yes the AR is better at medium range. Yes the SMG is lighter and allows you to be more agile. Every weapon has a field it excels in and overall its balanced decently well. Oh man this is so stupid. To get a better weapon I need to spend 200k GP. What a piece of BS". Again
date: no you dont. You -can- buy it if you want to but the first weapon you unlock is a MP5 or whatever and its pretty decent boosting pretty much all stats less some damage(barely) and effective range from the starter. Pfff
recommended: who needs range on a high ROF close range SMG.\n\n+Community. So far every room I have had the pleasure of joining has been nice
hoursPlayed: friendly and all around enjoyable. Well except for the one guy who apparently was getting away with his bad internet and one guy always seemed to be on the receiving end aha.\n\n+Leveling and Currency. Now I'm not sure if it will stay like this but currently
voteText: as you level you get 50k GP to spend on things. "Wow! Thats a lot!” Why yes little Timmy it is. Seeing as you can get 500GP per loss up to 1000 on a win. Not that slow I'll say that much. You can level pretty fast as well. Of course getting more wins than losses speeds it up but I like to think with my current play time and level
helpfulPercent:
I managed to average a little over a level in about an hour

PRO/CON

+-I personally like the skill system. But I’ll put this as a PRO/CON since it comes up a lot in other discussions. At the beginning of a match you automatically start with your tier 1 skill (200points). As you get kills/assists/do game mode objectives
votesHelpful: you get points that refill that gauge to a max of 400 points for the tier 2 level of the skill\n\nThere are added benefits to saving up to tier 2 and not using your skill every time you can. FYI your skill has a cooldown meter to limit fast consecutive uses if you are on a bloody
votesTotal: messy
votesFunny: mass murdering killing spree. But during that time you may obtain points towards your next skill use. So its not all that bad. Even more reason to save up those precious points\n\nI can see how people dislike it if your team is getting completely steam rolled and its hard to fill. But you automatically regen skill points until your skill bar reaches tier 1. Albeit slow
commentsCount: but its something.\n\n+-Hitboxes. Ah yes
column16: the double edged sword. I like to think that its both
column18: helpful and frustrating. I also believe its not just the hitbox but the weapon firing as well that is also a contributing factor. More so the former though. Many times have I tried to gun down someone running up some stairs at me to have him take 25%-50% damage to only knife me in the animated melee kill. But also to run down a hallway away from 3 enemies firing auto weapons at me to get away and lead them unsuspectingly into a pod of my own team for the assists. As I said
column19:
it works both ways. Hoping it will get tweaked soon

+-Mobile Agility AKA "Parkour". A little rough around the edges. You cant jump very high so you cant climb on top to many things to either get a vantage spot or cut corners. Granted at this stage its both good and bad. It currently in a way levels the field so everyone is even. There are prompts to press W+Space to "vault" over/up small ledges but some things I hoped were climbable were unfortunately not

+- Healing. Now some people are unhappy that you can't regenerate or heal completely. Cough Cough CoD Players Cough Cough. Well they are right up to a certain point. Now this game is listed as a Tactical Shooter if im not mistaken. So if you were able to just wait for your wounds to heal (looks at certain types of players) then get right back at it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For all intents and purposes my 'Yes' recommendation is lukewarm, will re-assess as the beta continues.
Is it worth 5$? Sure.
Will I still be playing it six months from now? Maybe.
As with any game on the market, do your own research before dropping any serious money on it.

Pros:
-Ability System - I like the character abilities and the focus on team-play that results from having a good spread of abilities on the team.
-Original English VAs - Might seem like something minor in most games, but it shows dedication to be true to the source material to get the voice actors from the series to work on lines for the game.
-Teamplay Oriented - Not much to say here. If you pick your characters to have a balanced spread of abilities and play to their advantage, then you'll be much more successful.
-Interesting Approach to Advancement - Unlocking more mod slots as you play and having post-game drops that degrade over time but allow you to enhance your characters.

Cons:
-Therm-optic stealth isn't a blanket ability that everyone can use. - It would be much more interesting if the Major could hack -and- control enemy Think Tanks instead of being the only character able to cloak.
- Can't Cook Grenades - You can pull the pin and hold it forever, it still won't effect how long it takes to explode after tossing it.
-Character Stacking - Anyone who has ever played TF2 can attest, having a team full of snipers is never a good sign. Having a team of eight people all playing the same character with the same ability isn't any better.
-Map Size - Not all of the maps suffer from this, but TDM levels are especially cramped.
-Useable Space - Some of the maps are of a decent size, however the usable area is very -very- flat. Sure there are sniper rifles in the game but good luck finding a decent vantage point to make good use of them.
-Spawn Protection - TDM is the main culplrit here, if you have enough people with cybersentries on your team you can lockdown a spawnroom and turn it into free kills until the game is over.
-Freedom of Movement - The contextual movement system is alright, but when you can't go up a ladder because you were jumping and have to land then look up before climbing the ladder it just slows everything down.
-Togusa doesn't have a Mateba.

Early Access Review

As a fan of the Ghost in the Shell series, I HAVE to recommend this game.
But I just can't, not at this stage of development.
If you're not a fan I recommend you wait it out until this game comes out of Early Access
and becomes Free to Play as promised. I'm going to tell you exactly why you should do so.

First Assault Online is mediocre at best, as an FPS.
SOME CONS:-Small maps
-Spawnpoints that will drive you absolutely insane with frustration
-Weapons are all boring and feel the same as in any other FPS shooter
-Starting pistol is basically useless

-Teamwork unfortunately doesn't come into play as much as it should
-In a desperate need for autobalance
-Visually doesn't look that great either
-Menu is as big of a mess as it was in Counter-Strike: Nexon" but you get used to it so I'm pretty much nitpicking
- You start with 3 primary weapons

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You ever want to play Call of Duty but you wished it was an anime?

Well boy have I got a game for you...


I put this in the comments but I thought I should throw some serious opinions about this game in the review since this review appears on the front page and I really think people have gave it a bad rep:

I'd say this does a pretty okay job at representing the universe and has really good gameplay to go with it. There's tons of other cyberpunk games with more in depth single player gameplay, try Deus Ex or System Shock if you want something like that. I'm just happy Ghost in the Shell finally got a good game, and it's pretty addicting to go with it. They really went all out with the weapon customization, and it is the best I've seen in a game since MGS4. Everything you pay for with in game currency or real money has a trade off, a straight stat nerf and buff that you can instantly feel and see. Nothing is a straight upgrade, this is such a fair system and I'm ♥♥♥♥♥♥ people are calling it pay to win when its not. $3 is a fair price for an early access game and I really hope people dive in and give this a chance. My main complaint so far is the matchamking, and apparently the newest patch has reworked it to be faster with less players, I'll try to play more to keep you guys updated eventually.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't usually do reviews, however this game is exceptional!

I've had around 10 hours of in-server play, and I've used all the weapon types, and I can easily say that this is my favorite shooter at the moment.

Pros:
- Fast TTK, but not to fast like CoD
- Good objective gametypes
- Quality community (for the most part)
- Seems rather balanced (some weapons can use work)
- Based on a good anime, seems to have original English dub voice actors
- Team centered 'class' skills
- Is cheap

Cons:
- Lack of Auto-Balance
- Only a few maps
- Will be F2P, so might become P2W?
- Spectating can be buggy
- Early Access still  (Not really a con?)
- Can't use shooting range with un-purchased guns/mods
- randomized spray pattern might need work

All in all, I would recommend this game (and have been) to anyone who likes shooters, or likes the anime series.  I've not been a fan of most modern shooters with their abundance of guns, and toxic communities, as well as long respawns (in the games I've played at least).  This has been a nice breath of fresh air, for me at least.

If you have $5, pick this up and have some fun, or wait until it's F2P and join us then, it's well worth your time and 45 minutes worth of work*  (assuming you make minimum wage in the US?).


EDIT:  There is a CS style AWP type weapon - It's the .50 cal with the damage enhancing barrel.  It only has 4 mags though, and with such a low TTK, it's easy to get killed with, a skilled sniper can still make use of it though.  I think It should be made bolt-action for fairness, however it should not be nerfed damage wise.  It wouldn't make sense for a .50 cal round to only wound someone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Although this game is in early access, and still has a long way to go, I would still recommend this game to anyone who is a lover of the first person genre and the GITS franchise.

The great aspects
- There is a very diverse set of classes for the variety of different gamers. Varying from stealth to object placed sentries. Class for any type of player

-  Original english voice actors from the anime
- Tutorial is very easy to understand for new players
- No issues with lag from my experience so far
- Maps are very well designed with player intuitive in mind
- 3 game modes, varying for TDM, Hold the objective, and demolition like modes
- Share your class specific abilities with team mates
- Team play highly influenced
- Quick chat commands
- Every weapon available to any class.

The bad aspects
- Microtransactions allow quicker access to items through the use of GP, can still be collected from playing (However not pay to win)

- Player buffs have durability, meaning they will expire after extensive use
- Game will start with  dramatically uneven teams.
- Enemy health is hard to make out
- Toggle ADS enforced when using Snipers

Basic Summary, A nice little gem!
I can see this game hopefully going down the right path, since it only costs £3.99 to play in it's current state I would say give it a try, before you decide paying for skins and camos ect

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GiTS First Assault is shaping up to be a decent online shooter. It's already way better than 90% of the early access games on steam, and given a bit more time to flesh out the maps and characters I think it will turn out great. The mix of arena and tactical game modes is also nice to see.

Pros :
- Strong fps mechanics
- Interesting character abilities and skill sharing system
- Good mix of game modes, CS style demolition and Terminal Capture are great fun
- Great gunplay
- Good map design, not too many chokepoints
- Orignal voice actors

Cons :
- The maps don't really carry a GiTS feel to them, if that makes sense
- Characters don't leave much of an impression. skills excepted
- Feedback for sniper rifles in particular is slightly off
- Certain special skills are very hard to counter, seeker drones in particular. Perhaps add louder audio cues as they approach so its easier to notice them.
- No auto-team balance

Early Access:
- The game is slightly buggy at the moment, Mainly in the form of people spawning under the map, though it only happens once in every few games for me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game at the moment isn't the best, but it also isn't the worst, like some other games I've seen on Steam.

The current state of the game right now is pretty lackluster, seeing as how there are only 3-4 game modes available. There doesn't seem to be a story as far as I'm aware, but the recent patch notes are saying that they will implement them, so that's something to look forward to!

As far as the gameplay goes, it's pretty fun! It's a bunch of mindless shooting in some areas, but it seems that as you start playing the objective-based game modes, there would be a lot of strategy involved. Some characters seem to work better in capturing objectives, some better at defending, and some doing their best in Deathmatch.

One thing I'm not enjoying however, is the character skill and weapons. The weapons are incredibly bland, and it takes a godly amount of effort in order to unlock newer equipment, not to mention that you get roughly ~700 GP per game, and unlocking a character costs a whopping 50,000 GP. But that's not my main issue; my main issue here is that some characters are almost broken compared to others. For example, look at Maven. She's pretty useless right now, sure you could say she's great at defense, but there's no denying that she's pretty garbage compared to other characters. That cyber sentry is disgusting, it almost instantaneously kills enemies, and takes 20 years to take down.

But that's not to say the gameplay elements are bad! This game includes something called Skill Syncing, if you get your character's skill to level 2 in the middle of the game, activating it will allow you to share it with your teammates! Granting them the skills that their character otherwise wouldn't be able to use. From sharing sprinting, to invisibility, this is a very unique aspect of the game, that can win fights, or lose them depending on how you use it!

Graphic wise, it's pretty great! There's a bunch of detail added in the game that makes it look amazing, and it runs very smoothly on my average PC. Although sometimes the environments may look pretty similar, making it hard to navigate around early on.

Moving on to the game modes,

DEATHMATCH:
This is your generic kill everybody as fast as you can" game mode
date:
with the goal of having 100 kills before the enemy. Not much to say here other than it gets boring quickly if you'd rather play the objective based missions.

DEMOLITION:
Your basic plant the C4 at the bomb site
hoursPlayed: defuse it

but I still have fun regardless.

TERMINAL CONQUEST:
Now this is where the real fun starts. This game mode is basically King of the Hill

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OverviewGameplay: 6/10
Sounds: 8/10
Multiplayer: 5/10
Graphics: 7/10

Pros & Cons+ Good voice acting
+ Smooth animations
+ Great techy atmosphere
- Below average hit detection
- Average map design
- Average weapon mechanics
- Not many active players
- Awful UI
- Poor netcode

Closest ComparisonFeels like: An average FPS game
Looks like: Blacklight Retribution & Neotokyo

ConclusionThe first thing you will notice about this game are the strange gun mechanics. The gun play just feels...off to say the least. That combined with bad hit detection really hurts a solid shooter game. Classes have unique abilities, though the long cool downs make it more of a gimmick rather than have them affect gameplay that much. Overall since the base shooting is so average/below average, Ghost in the Shell feels painfully generic, on the low end side.

6/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overview:A very interesting and addictive shooter. This ain't CS:GO, this ain't CoD, this is Ghost in the Shell. Probably you can feel the game better if you have watched the related anime. I haven't, but that does not affect me to enjoy the game. One thing I would like to point out is that the recoil pattern (if ever existed) is not as regular as CS:GO or CoD so spray and pray is not the right way to fire unless the enemy is 3 meters away from you. Snipers are weird mainly because the sensitivity for zooming in and zooming out are different, which may take some time to familiarize.
Payment System:So far as Early Access, NOT P2W AT ALL. All weapons, attachments and characters can be and can ONLY be obtained by spending non-cash in game points which you can earn by simply playing games. What can be purchased using cash? I don't know, because it is totally unnecessary.
Matchmaking System:Despite that there are not a huge amount of players playing this game, you can still find a lobby in 4 seconds, whenever and wherever. Sometimes teams are not balanced, but as game goes on, more players will fill in.
Game Modes:Lacks a lot. So far there are only 3 game modes. TDM, which we all know how it works; Demolition, which refers to Search & Destroy in CoD and CrossFire which is also the most classic mode in CS; Terminal Conquest, which is a variant of Domination from CoD. Differently, there are 5 terminals linearly on the map. The game begins with the third which is the middle terminal and whichever team has 3 more points than the other team or has 5 points wins.
Weapons:Not so many. I'd say there are about 15-20 weapons in total. HOWEVER, you have to use the certain weapon if you want to unlock attachments for that weapon. And to be honest, there are a LOT OF attachments for weapons. Some of them can be purchased directly from in game shop, others you have to unlock them first by using the weapon and then purchase the unlocked attachment from your inventory. The order of attachment unlocking is fixed, meaning that you have to unlock the first attachment before unlocking the next. This is also the main reason why I'm still using my default MP5 after playing this game for 10 hours. THERE ARE STILL LOCKED ATTACHMENTS FOR MY MP5!
Characters:Like I said before, you need to unlock them using licenses purchased from in game shop using non-cash points. But if you are lucky enough, you can earn that license from daily login reward. There are several different characters, every single one of which has unique abilities, so pick the one you feel the most comfortable with. By using one character over time, you can progress the slot unlocking for that character and thus equip more chips onto that character.
Rewards:This would be a F2P game eventually so they did use some rewards to hook people up. Daily login reward is the most common one, whch does appear in this game. You can get different things in daily login reward, from GP (in game non-cash points), to EXP boosts, to GP boosts, and some other stuff. Don't look down upon those rewards. Yes I admit that most of time you will only get small bonuses from those rewards like 500GP or 10% EXP boost or 10% GP boost. But believe it or not, I used to get a 500% EXP boost for once and that thing helped me level up 3 times in 1 hour. All boost rewards from daily login reward last for 1 hour once you use it, so if you just want to play for 5 minutes and take a nap, don't use it until you have enough time to play the game.
After each match you will be asked to pick one reward out of three. Totally random. It could be GP boost or EXP boost which applies to the current match, but the thing probably you really want the most is chips. So far chips can only be obtained from after match rewards. Another thing worth noting is that those chips are not usable permanent". Of course if you earn one and don't use it then it will be permanent

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, this is coming from a relatively high skilled CS player (GE rank atm):

+Brainless shooty fun, the game commits no sins.
+The guns feel VERY good and all the sound assets are bang on.
+Boobs
+No pay2win BS, all guns are sidegrades, the default weapons are perfectly viable.
+No FPS lock, so if you have a 144hz monitor you can take advantage of that.
+Looks nice visually.
+All the classes are good.
+Well thought out maps.
+Actually rewards good aim and doesnt reward spraying too much (headshots are usually an instakill).
+Hitreg is god-tier. (Edit: New patch made it a bit worse, might have added lag compensation?)

-Right now (Mar. 2016) you cannot use additional mouse buttons (M4, M5, etc.).
-Sometimes the game does crash when you change stuff in the options menu.
-At early/late times it can be hard to find a game. (Edit: Dive on Random seems to usually get you a game.)
-I do experience stutter on death or before death sometimes, if that makes any sense, but not always.


All in all the game is perfectly worth it if you want to have some fun.

Edit:
Have been playing more of it recently, I wildly prefer Demolition and Terminal Conquest to Team Death Match as it has pretty weird spawns and the spawn protection can be really annoying. It still seems that all guns are viable, some ARE a bit better than others but you can really make-do with anything.
The game doesn't lack depth at all, so it's the type of game you can keep playing and trying out other things while never getting bored.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For soon to be F2P its a good game, for a 5 buck pick up as well. It's a fun little shooter with a couple different user abilities and a team buffing system.

It has unlockable guns and attachments as well as skins and ability improvements and some boosts to your character. Basically got it to play in a GITS theme as a Mokoto.


Pros:
1.It's easy to play
2.Fast paced with shorter match times
3.TDM, Uplink KOTH type mode, S&D,
4.GITS
5.Motoko
6.Motoko again
7.Decent amount of guns and attatchments

Cons:
1.Hit detection goes from fine to god awful
2.Guns are incredibly inaccurate as in there is no spray to control and you get owned by RNG sometimes as in putting a full mag into someone while ADS and they slightly strafe and you keep on them and you maybe hit them a couple times. Though that doesn't happen that often and I think its just server lag or laggy opponents
3.The RNG on the sprays cause random headshots which can be annoying being picked off cross map by someone running and spraying while you are sniping
4. Only a couple maps, and certain points have broken spawning where you spawn in the open infront of enemies behind cover
5. The weapons are not GITS, they are modern weapons and exclude the real life variants of GITS weaponry.


Overall its a cheap/free quick casual shooter with a GITS theme if you are looking for some really indepth shooter thats an experience look elsewhere. All I want is for them to fix the hit detection and add in the GITS weaponry.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game plays like a mix between Call of Duty and Counterstrike. Sprinting, iron sights, class powers, with no health regen and no respawns (at least in some modes).
Gameplay wise it is very fun, its fast paced but still requires you to think about your actions. You cant just run around shooting like in CoD, you have to aim properly and use your powers effectively. Teamwork is also useful, although I dont believe there is mic support yet. A little odd since its a multiplayer FPS.
Graphics aren't amazing, and yet it seem to have framerate issues. I'm playing on a GTX980 and I suffer from some frame drops now and then, even on medium. When you melee kill someone the frames plummet. Although this could be issues with their servers.
The market system seems pretty decent, you can unlock guns by playing or you can unlock guns by buying them with points. The point system actually works pretty well as getting points isnt all that difficult, so it doesn't feel like pay to win (at least not yet). You get 50k points a level, and about 1000 or so points per game,  and guns usually cost about 200k.
So far the only things you  have to pay money to unlock are skins, and if they keep it like that then this should prove to be a great game.

Pros:
+Fun gameplay
+Great price
+Doesnt seem Pay to Win
+Large number of classes to play as
+Finding a game is quick, servers seem populated.
+Gunplay is fun
Cons:
-Servers seem a little laggy at times
-Frame rate drops, especially with melee kills.
-The menu UI isnt great, can be a little confusing
-Cant set FOV
-You cant test guns before you buy them. This is annoying since getting a new gun takes about an hour or 2 and buying one then finding out you dont like it really sucks.
-I don't really like the pistols, not sure what it is but they just seem clunky compared to the other weapons.

Other notes:
So far there isn't a lot of variety in terms of weapons, theres about 10 I think. Obviously I expect this to change over time.
Only 3 maps, maybe more that I havent seen yet, but as with the guns I expect this to change over time
I don't know anything about ghost in the shell and after playing this I still don't know anything, very little ghost in the shell related content (At least as far as I can tell).

Overall I'd say its definitely a fun game, especially for the $3 I paid for it. Once it becomes F2P I'd definitely recommend downloading it. For $5 its still really good. I'd give it a try if you like FPS games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL:DR - This game still has lots of areas to improve upon and game performance can use more fine-tuning, but it has a solid and fun base and isn't pay-to-win. It's pretty cheap ($5), so give it a try if you're curious.

First of all, if you're looking at this and expecting something like Deus Ex, steer clear. This is a lobby-based multiplayer FPS with a Ghost in the Shell theme.

Gunplay is pretty simplistic and while I feel that the overall game balance is still on the fence, it's still easy enough if you've had any experience with modern online shooters at all. You can play as different members of Section 9, but playstyles don't differ too drastically amongst them, as the only differentiating factor are their skills, from cloaking to arm rocket launchers and everything in between.

On to the business model. This game will be free-to-play once it's out of Early Access. In-game GP is used to buy weapons and attachments for permanent durations, and are only obtainable with in-game currency. Real-life currency only gets you cosmetic skins and operative licenses, which are used to obtain additional operatives; the licenses can also be purchased with in-game currency, and you can get up to three free licenses in the early levels. The starting equipment you get are very competitive and are on par with GP-purchaseable weapons.

At this point in time, game performance isn't the best for everyone. Personally, the game runs fine for me; for reference, I'm running an i7-4790k, 16GB RAM, and a GTX 770 2GB with the game installed on an SSD, and I'm getting 90-150+ frames per second at 1080p. Netcode can also use some improvements as well. In general, performance has been a mixed bag for some people, so your mileage may vary.

Updates are fairly frequent and I personally feel that development's been going at a decent pace. The CMs/GMs do engage the community often, and do weekly livestreams and events as well. As for the community, it's overall not too shabby. Time will tell how things go once the game is received by a wider audience, though.

Give it a shot and see if you like it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is alright, but barely related to the GitS other than the skins and few operative skills.

Posivite aspects for me would be the fast paced nature of the game and how aggressive abilities prevent the matches of becoming your next generic camping fest. Skills also seem to be quite balanced for an early access, excepting Borma's nanogel, which, in fact, has been proven to greatly boost the k/d ratio of most players, compared other Operatives/Skills.

Negative aspects are, in a themed game like this, things like little outdated graphics/dx9, dull maps and map objects, which grant the feeling we are fighting in a simulated environment (aka lack of immersion), plus:
- Guns and mods are very generic and barely related to the series. Poor gun customization via mods: For each gun there is basically only one way you should be taking
- Explosion sound effects could be -way- better (nades+arm launcher)
- Game mods (TD, Capture Terminal, Demolition) don't add any originality to the gameplay itself. Taking into account how many attractive game mods you could have figured out by watching GitS SaC series, you are missing an great opportunity to give this game its own -very strong- identity
- Operative modifications break so fast, I don't even bother with them anymore
- Netcode rewards higher pings a lot
- Server triggered stutters might occur when a player gets killed, leaves or joins mid game
- Proprotionally big amount of whiteknights and pubbie's testosterone spread within the (very small) community might lead to frustration when trying to constructively criticize, which further shows us how prevalent the generic FPS part of the game is against the the very little portion of GitS we get. See the first sentence of this review
- Last but not least: Nexon has a working shop in the early access stage, which in my book is and will always be a shameless move


Things I would consider if I was in charge:

- Giving the game environment the cyberpunk touch it deserves
- Adding and reworking map objects in order to deliver the feeling we are actually in a damn postwar,  yet still overpopulated scenario (ideas like some random, but somehow still related events within the battle come to my mind, which may or may not influence the encounters; destroyable objects which might cause harm to players or even serve them as improvised cover; random civs spawns; more+better background sounds and so on)
- Bigger maps with different ways to sucessfully accomplshing the goals by having one or several strategy options in order for the game to become a little more tactical, without throwing the fast pace style through the window (GitS combat is extremely tactical)
- Option to play matches which include friendly fire for tactical reasons. See above
- GitS Serie Guns
- Enemy visuals in some cases could get a touch. There are many neat looking elite units in the series, which would be great to look at while shooting them down; a cyborg wearing shorts on the other hand, leaves something to be desired
- A suited mod for this game, which should have been in here since day 1, would be CTF in form of capure the intelligence/plutonium/uranium/prosthetic parts/etc. Either 2 teams 1 objective (neutral flag) or 2 teams and two objectives (red + blue flag)
- In-door/out-door (dynamic) fights
- Future low-priority PvE patch for die-hard GitS fans willing to see a bit more than some random black/red cyborgs

edit: corrected some stuff
edit2: corrected more stuff and added one more point
edit3: one more point

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It feelsl really empty right now. There are very few guns, few customization options, and few maps. But hey, it's an early access game; it's probably going to get a lot better. In any case, it's totally worth $4.99, or $6.99, or $8.99. I went for the $8.99 option because why not? (Crashes every once in a while, but that isn't really a big deal. A lot of games crash every once in a while.)

By the way, most players still don't know how to aim. If you can aim in this game, you're going to do very well. (Edit: They're learning, but it's slow. A lot of players don't even have a 1.00 KDR.)

Tips: If your opponent is far away, click fire. Don't hold down left mouse. If you find that a Seeker Drone is chasing you, run until an ally kills it. If you run out of ammo during an intense 1 on 1 firefight, switch to pistol. Don't use the M249 unless you're a masochist. Don't unlock anything until you find out which guns you prefer. (I made the mistake of unlocking everything for M249, and now I'm very broke.)

If you enjoy FPS games or Ghost in the Shell, you should get this. If you don't enjoy FPS games or Ghost in the Shell, don't get it. It's really that simple. (There's no story. If you play games for the story, don't bother with First Assault.)

Update: I'm honestly kind of burned out after playing 80ish hours. The firing patterns used to be amusing, now they're just annoying. Guns and good attachments are absurdly expensive. Takes literally eternity to level up, and the 100k might as well be 1k. This game has serious balancing issues, as well as arbitrary team shuffling.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Welcome to the “I’m exhausted why am I doing this” -reviews. With your host Fyrop. (This is the longest review I've written so far so here we GoOoOooo~ God have mercy).

Let me start by saying the game itself runs really well even on my (to put it kindly) toaster of a computer. I’ve actually had very few issues with things like the framerate, stuttering, or lag. (I put this here because I forgot to mention it earlier and figured this would be a fine spot… Listen I put a decent amount of effort into this review just let it go).

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex is a decent FPS, there isn't much for me to say here since it's so early in its development... I'm recommending it in this review because I have mutual feelings over it at the moment, and as usual somewhat skeptical of the game's future. Though I wouldn’t mark my feelings towards it as negative either simply because of the nature of early access games. (That being they can go either way and this games still right there in the middle). I have enjoyed what’s here quite a bit. This game at it’s core has a lot of potential, what’s here is fun; but there isn’t much of anything new and it definitely needs a lot of work before I say whether it’s worth your hard earned money or not. For this Early-Access Review" Instead of just stating the pros and cons I'll state what it does differently from other FPS’s and what it’s lacking in.

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex has a somewhat unique system in which each character has their own special ability that has two tiers for different types of use (These varying from Invisibility; Player Detection

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minature maps, spawn kills and clunky/unfluid movement and gameplay. I know it's a early access game, but it just feels too raw to enjoy at the moment.

**Edit Heres a bit more depth**

The game feels like it was just slapped together to make a few bucks, all the words about 'Putting their heart into it makes them look like they havn't got much of a heart. If your a diehard GitS fan, who loves ultra fast paced shooters you might love this.
If you're like me and wanted something a bit more tactical from a GitS game, you won't find it. All in all, its only 5 bucks go ahead if you're a fan.

Pros
* It's Ghost in the Shell!
* The menus are decent and finding a game was fast and easy
* The skill sharing system is unique and kinda nice

Cons
* Nexon
* The graphics are really lacking in a certain visual flair.
* The guns are super generic. eg. 1 submachine gun, 1 rifle, 1 sniper, 1 lmg
* The maps are horribly done. The modules are to small and cramped and make it so you can see the enemy spawn from walking around one  corner.
* The spawns are also very bad, not the positioning as such, but the fact you can stand in the enemy spawn without penalty.
* The sniper zoom made me feel very motionsick, i'm not sure what it was but i've never felt motionsick in a game before.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex - First Assault Online

What you need to know:

Right now the game is in beta so things are pretty wonky with the net-code and there is a lack of weaponry and map diversity.  But so far everything that is out, is awesome.

While there is still a ways to go with this game you can clearly see the foundation the devs have laid out and you get glimpses of features and content to come.

The music is really good, the voice acting is right from the show, it looks and feels like the world of Ghost in the Shell.

I must reiterate it is in beta so things don’t quite work as they should and the main hub in-between games could be a little more user friendly.

Other than that I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys Ghost in the Shell.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

I looked into the shell and I didn't see any ghosts..

Ghost in a Shell: Stand a Alone complex - First Assault Online is your run of the mill shooter and yes while it is in Early Access, its in near finished state. The only thing left that seems to need work is balancing. But even that is really sort of nit picky and only matters for a very small few.

Listen, I'm going to blunt because I don't see any way around it. This is a very standard Call of Duty styled and paced competitive shooter. Its exactly what you expect. It feels good. The guns kill people, different guns feel different, the maps have nice choke points that form organically through play. It works; You level up in overall level as well as for usage of specific weapons.

All the modes you've come to enjoy are present from your shoot all the things type deals to the objective based defend and attack modes. A sort of 1 death per round affair.

The community that has bought into early access is small but VERY active. After full release the company plans to make the game free-to-play.

You choose a class which has a specific skill attached to them. An odd but helpful thing is you are the only one to see your own avatar in game. The enemy team are all painted with the same skin however the players retain their specific loadout and ability.

THE GIST
If you want a free, well done relatively traditional competitive shooter. This is it. Its very comparable to a Blacklight Retribution but in all honestly this seems a bit more polished and the developers seem dedicated to this project. Obviously, upon full release or even a borked update that could all change but for the time being, this is a very inexpensive buy in for a decent shooter. However, I must advise, waiting for a full release when it is actually free-to-play is also a very viable option.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing, I am enjoying this as much as I enjoy Counter-Strike and Killing Floor these days.

The graphics, of a game that is based on an animated series, I expected some cell-shaded, half-bad texture work, but it is not cell-shaded and the textures, effects, details... all are smooth as f*ck and I catch myself in customization menus more than I should.

The gameplay is awesome. If I should compare it to anything, it would be a mix of Counter-Strike and RainbowSix.
Non-regenerating health, special abilities and teamwork.

The online system works great! You can freely switch between region if you have friends who play on US or EU servers, though your connection won't be tip-top, it will still let you play with your friends! You can even sort your friends into different categories like here on steam.

The weapon modifications are awesome and makes the game more advanced than you'd first think. The modifications are not only stat-wise but also changes your weapon visually, like in PAYDAY 2 if you're familiar with that.

PAY 2 WIN, the section some of you have been waiting for!
It's non-existent. Sure! You can get some cool pre-order bonuses! SKINS... VISUAL CUSTOMIZATION... Nothing that makes you better, changes any stats or activates your aimbot whatsoever.

The money bonuses? There is no IRL currency equivalent in-game, only in-game cash, and the most expensive package (Elite Pack) gives half a million credits, which can be earned in 5-7 games if you're half as good as I am.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I never would know about this game, before my friend gifted me a reedem key for this game.

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex - the first FPS game I mostly enjoy playing right now, compare to other FPS. There are 9 operatives, each with a special skill, that even one single skill can turn the game into Victory. The operative skills are two type - self buffing and team buffing or called SkillSync, which you can share your skill with allies.

There ir Borma - Nanogel (regenerative armor user, who can save other lives by using SkillSync at tier 2 to heal allies preparing for another enemy attack. Other SkillSync users like Paz, who can give boost to your sprint to approach Terminal more quickly or to suprise enemies unprepared, Motoko, with Therm-optic Camo or so called invisibility you can suprise enemies by flanking them or you can just sit there from long distance like a camper and snipe, and Saito can give information about enemies location and be prepared, when they make a move.

Self buffers - Togusa, Batou, Ishikawa and Maven - they buff their abilities for more efectiveness. Togusa at tier II can launch two seeker drones instead of one, Batou launches two rockets, Ishikawa upgrades turret's health and more vision, Maven can cover allies by covering with barrier, which enemies can't see through, but allies can.

Maps are not many, but I enjoy these maps! I know, It's early access, but this game is something for me.

9.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun game. Definitely worth the $5 for early access.
It definitely needs some work, though.

Pros
Gunplay is solid - Guns have weight behind them, and the sound packs a punch.
Guns are fairly balanced - Nothing jumps out as overpowered.
Interesting skill system has some nice teamwork options - You can share your unique skill with your teammates, and combinations can turn the tide of a match.
Gameplay has a solid foundation - It's good. With more modes and variety, it can be great)
Graphics are decent - Nothing to write home about. They do their job.
Optimization seems alright. No frame drops for me so far.
Aussie servers!

Cons
Weapon and map variety is low. (for now. Early access and all) - A few maps, and a few weapons. I like how there aren't 50 weapons of each type that fill the exact same role, though.
Some inconsistency with damage - Sometimes I seem to die in 2 hits, while others I am hit with 10 rounds and am still standing.
Game modes are unoriginal - TDM, DOM, DEM. Nothing unique at all. I hope some different modes are added in the future.
Early access - Personally, I dislike early access, and there are very few times I will purchase one. Exceptions are GiTS and Toxikk, because they are both games I think can be genuinely great, and will actually get content. Unlike most devs who put their game on early access, get a bunch of cash, then stop development.

Neutral
Hardcore GiTS fans might not enjoy how it plays.
Assault Rifles have seemingly 1HKO headshots from any range. Leading to very frustrating situations where an AR can outplay a sniper rifle across the map (with some luck)
No music - Sound plays an important part in the game, so this might not be a con for some people. But, when there's a gap in action, with no ambient music playing, it becomes really dull.

All in all, GiTS is an enjoyable game.
I haven't been interested in many shooters for a while now, and Ghost in the Shell can fill that gap.

It has a solid gameplay and mechanic foundation (with its clever skill system), and if the game is continuously supported with new game modes, weapons and maps, it can become an excellent shooter.

If you're a hardcore Ghost in the Shell fan. Don't go into this expecting GiTS in video game form, just play it to have fun with a solid FPS.

Spend $5 on this, or go and spend $60 on a Call of Duty game, and $15 on each ♥♥♥♥♥♥ map pack.
Pretty easy choice, in my opinion.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before I start i'd like to point out that i've never heard of Ghost in the Shell, and as such will be basing this on the game itself, not the theme.

I'm probably going to get some flak for saying this, but the short version of this review is: Get Call of Duty Black Ops 3, you basically get a better version of this. Now allow me to explain why.

Its already painfully obvious that the game will be taking a pay 2 win route. To start with, its a free to play shooter by Nexon, secondly, the starting weapons are already horrible, with accuracy so poor most firefights feel like a game of chance over actual skill, given the weaponry provided rarely hits where you're aiming, even when aiming down the sights...

The game also requires painfully long experience and money grinds to get your next weapons, you'll earn around 2000 credits per usual deathmatch, and even the next level of equipment requires somewhere around 60000 to purchase, ignoring the fact you also need to by attachments, some you're unable to buy until you've grinded enough matches to unlock 1 of the many weapons you're not allowed to use yet... if you've just started, and have bought the most basic of the starter packs, you'll be looking at the back of your first assault rifle for a -long- time.

Next up, gameplay! The game is supposed to be a team-based shooter, gives you 1 of about 8 characters, each with their own unique power, such as being barely able to see enemies through walls, being able to run faster and jump higher so you can stab 1 guy while the rest of his team guns you down mid animation, a sentry that serves more as a bullet sponge than actual damage, and the list goes on. The shooting itself is fairly poor, with little to no recoil and the previously mentioned poor accuracy, where even aiming down the sights can't get your bullets to hit their target reliably...all you can do is point it at them and hope chance favours you.

So to sum up:
Its a painfully grindy game that starts you off with weak weaponry, has a giant wall of xp/money to reach the next weapons, is by Nexon, a company notorious for its pay 2 win games, and with bog standard combat...yeah its not horrible, but it does nothing to stand out.

If you're interested in this game, save up and get CoD Black Ops 3, there is nothing this game does, that it hasn't already done better.

It's just not good enough to be considered a game yet, and that makes me sad considering I played it during the CBT and I really did like it, I tried to enjoy everything that this game had to offer and for a closed beta I was pretty alright with it, there were complaints on the forums and promises to have them addressed but...it has just gotten worse, my FPS dropped, the game's movement is still sluggish when moving and feeling like ice when I'm walking, the weapon shooting is just dreadful because you either hit nothing with an entire mag and get pz'd or you get a random headshot. I tried so much to enjoy this game in CBT and to see nothing has changed makes me a little bit sad.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First thing out of the way, this game is very quick paced and competitive.

The maps are tight with plenty of shortcuts and cubby holes, with open spaces connecting them. This balance of open and closed spaces gives a dynamic sense of immersion into the world of Ghost in the Shell, and by the sounds of it, they actually managed to get the voice actors for the stand alone english dub, or at least very good impersonators.

Like many other team based deathboxes, this game features a variety of weapons (albeit, only primary weapons can be purchased as of alpha) and also features unlockable mods.

Unlike other games of this style, once you buy the weapons or mods, they are yours to keep and weapon mods are not set in stone.

For those looking to buy the early access booster packs, they do give you extra credits, but for those who don't: do not let this economic imbalance deter you. Upgrades and weapons have to be unlocked through grinding. Yes, even if you have the money, you have to earn the weapons. Adding to that, every level increase gives you a healthy sum of bonus credits (alpha: 50,000), so you can be sure to be able to afford weapons and mods as they become available (I haven't even used my booster credits and I have all but one weapon available to me, and a bunch of upgrades).

Whether you win or lose a match, you get credits and xp, although more if you win; and at the end of each match, you get a luck draw for a booster item. Xp, credits or even character buffs.

On that note, character buffs. These are expendable and have a number of uses before they are depleted and can include things like faster strafing, faster reload, quicker sighting.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Sporting a rather oddball, yet intriguing combination of multiple shooters.

Primarily incporporating the nature from Counter-Strike, it does not forgive missed shots, it does not forgive getting shot at, and it most definetly does not forgive not handling your weapon build correct. TTK is generally slow, and headshots are very, very dangerous here too, but there is no HP regen.

Yet, ADS mechanics are brought in from the likes of Battlefield and Call Of Duty; Raycasting with spread and recoil values, but are much more violent by default, you cannot do more than 2-shot bursts outside ten-ish ingame meters or so, and tapfiring is absolutely necessiated if you wish to find yourself a succesful session.

Infinite stamina, barely any flinch, base movement speed affected by the equipped weapon build and pulling out a knife or a grenade, yet feels somewhat sluggish at times. I'd say this translates to catiousness. Game wants you to think ahead and being prepared at all times.

And this itself brings me to my last take on the core gameplay; Where as in classic arena shooters the difficulty comes in the form of predicting your enemies and calculating trajectories, and map knowledge - this game draws it's challenge in weapon handling. I cannot stress this enough, the weapons are violent and aggressive if left uncontrolled, the spread and recoil build up enormously with anything more than 2-3 shot bursts.

Noteworthy, despite not directly gameplay, there are no scavenging ammo itself in this game whatsoever, none, nada. Only way to get a fresh load is to pick up left behind weapons and hope it has enough pewpew for another +9 streak. The game is technically in good state, and runs stable on all 3 builds of mine. Workarounds exist and manually tailoring your system does sport that extra boost.

This concludes my opinion of the game and its state so far. It is a shooter for a very specific taste and liking, but by no means a bad one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First is Assault isn't without it's flaws, there are framerate drops and latency issues here and there, the spawns can be unfair, and I would have liked to see an upgrade tree in one form or another, but as an overall gaming experience, First Assault is nice to look at, has nice music and sound effects, and most importantly, it's fun.

The Graphics are nothing special, but where this game shines most is in it's mechanics.

First Assault plays much like most other First Person Shooters you'll see on the market, but with an emphasis on Tactics and Teamwork. Every character has an ability unique to them that charges over time or as you rack up points that you optain by defeating enemies, assisting a teammate, etc. These abilities have two tiers each, you can use it immediately at tier 1 when the cooldown ends, or you can wait a bit longer and rank it up to tier 2. Motoko has her Therm-Optic Camo which makes you more difficult to spot by enemies. Rank it up to tier 2, and it can be used by 3 other teammates in an interesting mechanic called SkillSync. Batou has his arm launcher which can fire a rocket and fires two rockets at tier 2, but cannot be used in SkillSync at either tier.

If you manage to layer the right skills, you can put your team at quite the advantage and pull of some awesome plays. I've noticed that Therm-optic Camo and Super Sprint, which increases your movement speed, is especially deadly.

Unlike most FPS out there, one player is less likely to carry the game, as the outcome of the match depends heavily on how well the team works together. If you're into that kind of thing, this game is for you. However, First Assault has only three gamemodes currently and some features are unfinished, and will be Free to Play at a later date, so it may be wise to wait until release.

I'm having fun with First Assault, but I can understand the gripes others are having with it. In it's current state, this game recieves a 7/10 for me. This score will most likely rise upon release as we see bug fixes, new gamemodes, new maps, and new features (hopefully.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game might as well be called Cyberpunk of Duty, so that is what I shall be calling it throughout this review.

Cyberpunk of Duty feels, in many ways, like the futuristic COD that should have been. There's no crazy OP killstreaks, there's no BS aerobatics, just you, a gun with attachments, and an ability that recharges over time and with kills. Other than the scifi and anime trappings, you'd be forgiven for thinking this is a calmed-down COD more in line with what COD4 was.

While not the more technically impressive, the game's visuals very much have an anime sort of flair to them, despite not being cell-shaded. Enemies and friendlies are easy to pick out against the background, and all of the HUD elements are cleanly presented and easy to read, while maintaining the cyberpunk feel of the source material.

Gunplay is solid, with netcode that performs better than most. Recoil is very much in play here, and managing it is key to all engagements, even those at fairly close ranges. All of the sounds in the game are similarly fantastic, from the gunfire, music, and seemingly-authentic voice acting.

My issues with the game are very few, and one of the few actually comes down to the playerbase, and not the game itself. For whatever reason, 80% of players seem to have all picked the main character. This means you will almost never see any abilities other than cloaking, and you'll also rarely get the opportunity to SkillSync anything other than cloaking. This is disappointing because I would much rather SkillSync the arguably more useful wall hack-like ability, or the other sharable abilities. Perhaps this will change later in the game's lifespan, but for now, you'll be playing with a flood of clones.

Ther are also a few menus that are conspicuously devoid of anything on them, but these are sure to be populated throughout the game's development.

Overall, this is a great shooter, and it's damn near impossible to find this kind of quality for the asking price of $5. This is a game that I can really see myself putting a lot of time into.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A well-built, early access, fast-paced, team-based FPS.  All the mechanics feel in place, aside from strange occasional bugginess in the forms of disputed hit-boxes (or fire patterns, uncertain), a melee strike that doesn't seem to go off when it should (right-clicking when the symbol pops up for an insta-kill is supposed to work, right?), and other oddities that don't always happen but when they do it's right when you needed them not to.  The game does lack content, and according to the way it was advertised it should have pure co-op scenarios and more but doesn't.  However, it is early access, and UI elements appear to be in place to facilitate the missing content.

The gameplay certainly is unique and seems to fit together well.  Each character has a different ability that, when used well, can really benefit your playstyle as well as the team through sharing the ability's effects.  Nothing feels really overpowered, and it doesn't feel like rock-paper-scissors unless you aren't aware of your surroundings (which would be your own fault).  Also, it's Ghost in the Shell, with great voice acting.

Spend a little (no more than $10) on an intro pack and see where it goes (kinda wary of Nexon, which has a money-grabbing history).  If the game shapes up to something nice come launch, spend a little more to give the developers support.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex - First Assault Online is a decent early access FPS that delivers in some aspects and could improve in others. I really liked the customization options you can have for weapon attachments, as well as chipsets that act as temporary perks for your characters. The Skillsync system is interesting, with some skills being more beneficial than others, but I like how the abilities can affect ones playstyle or the flow of battle during a match. The gunplay can be best described as clunky and random at times. There seems to be some aspect of random spread or recoil present when firing a weapon and sometimes hits dont register. Overall, since the developers are continously trying to improve the game and listen to community feedback, I think that some of these issues can be remedied in time for official launch but as it stands now, it is a fun and fully functional early access game that I can recommend.

I've also written a more in depth review and overview at the website below:
http://freetoplayreview.com/ghost-in-the-shell-stand-alone-complex-first-assault-online-early-access-review

reviewText:
Early Access Review

alright here's my review
----Pros
- Game is very, very cheap and well worth the cost.
- Only thing that costs money are the outfits.
- This game is NOT P2W
- Most of the community online is very nice and competitive.
- The early leveling and rewards are very, very generous with tons of early GP for weapon/accessory unlocks.
- Heavily skill based, no overpowered nonsense.
- Learn what weapons work for you and your playstyle, instead of using the same 2-3 overpowered weapons (eg CoD games)
- Quite a few weapon accessories are double edged. (eg, accuracy improvement, character speed reduction) Preventing people that pay tons from having a lead over their peers.
- Plenty of different maps and style of games, different character's skills work much better in certain maps and certain game types, so make a party and set up plans and strategies.
- 8 characters, each with their own unique skills.
- Skills are not overpowered, nor underpowered.
- The game is in Beta stage and I'm lovin' it. (Mcdonald's Pun not intended). ;3
---------Cons
- The opening is unskippable, loud, and takes more seconds to finish than it should.
- No microphone support yet.
- Missing weapons from the anime, but honestly, they'll be added eventually, duh.
- A drop in FPS and a small delay here and there, but not often enough to rage over.
- Lag Spike will occur maybe once or twice within 1-2 hours I've noticed.
- Hitbox issues every now and then, but that's to be expected from Early Access.
- Shotguns do not spread their fire either when aiming down the sights or when hip fired. No idea why this is...  Also, because of this, when aiming down the sights, you can effectively melt through enemies at mid range with incredible accuracy. But when shooting someone in closer proximity, since the shot isn't sprayed like a normal shotgun, if the shot misses the exact mark on an enemy, the entire spray misses and not a single pellet hits. It seems very strange, but maybe I'm just not used to it.
- You cannot see the costumes or other characters on the enemy team. All enemies look the same. (hopefully that will change)
- Invisible enemy's" names will still pop up over their heads when you aim even remotely at them. That NEEDS to change.
-I've seen 2 people assassinate each other at the exact same time

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game is breakingly unfinished.

It has the potential to be fun. The idea is good. But the backend is bad. very bad.

I'm currently running a rig with 750gb ssd storage, 16gb memory, i7 3770k CPU and nVidia GeForce GTX 670 GPU.  I'm running on 60mbps down / 4.5mbps up connection with tested 0 packet loss and approx 2-5ms jitter. The game registers me anywhere from 20-30ms average on the servers I play (US ones). Safe to conclude no hardware issues, yeah?

Then, lets also get out of the way crouching/tap-firing. I do both. Stationary crouched tap-fire shots for maximum accuracy. Then the following things happen:

If you aim at someone, say, someone stationary 5 feet from you and you put the targeting reticle directly centered in their chest and fire... you may or may not hit them. Some matches you'll hit. Other matches the game will completely ignore the fact you're aiming down sights and not one bullet will touch your target. Then he turns around and kills you because you've expended your ammo clip. Thus aiming is pointless.

Then there's the times where it bugs and irregularly registers hit damage... this happens randomly, but I'd estimate approximately 40-50% of time. When this happens, body shots that normally would do 10-30% of your health instantly kill you.

Then there's the deal with shotguns. Occasionally they do the same thing when distanced so you can 1-hit kill a target completely across the map with a SHOTGUN. Because you can snipe with shotguns. Logic.

Aaand there's the glorious moments where you're taking fire and get behind cover... and the cover does not save you. You die anyway. Out of their line of sight & out of their line of fire.

Anyway, hopefully the devs can fix this in the future, but as of right now, if you play this game and enter a match there's a 50-50 chance it will be broken and unplayable.

Update: Logged in again for the last time tonight. I logged in and played for about an hour or so and the game was 100% unplayable. Nothing would hit where the targetting reticle was placed, was being shot through walls, just entirely bogus.

Game's just not worth the bother, it's clearly broken and with limited time right now to enjoy myself in games, it's not worth the strain of gambling on a 50-50 chance the game will be playable and not just downright frustrating.

For now, this is uninstalled & removed from my games list. Really bugs me though that it's been a waste of money for now, but I will come back to this maybe 6 months to a year from now and see if it's progressed any by then.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell based PC game; we all dreamed it and now it is here. All the glorious bits and bobs from the series in a neat shooter package, all while being a free to play game [at some point in the future].

Pros:
-GitS:SAC universe in a game!
-All the original (English) voice actors from the series voicing their character.
-Practically F2P already with the minor buy-in price.
-Skillsync system is fun and original.
-Unique method to identifying enemies.

Cons:
-Steam packages aren't very worthwhile
-Almost no skins whatsoever in the entire game
-Each character has 1 skill, and that is the only reason for their existence.
-Only one original gun in the entire game: the Seburo pistol you may see in some preview images
-Incredibly boring weapon selection overall.
-Maps are not dynamic enough, far too simplistic layouts.
-Maps are fairly small; you often respawn right next to enemies
-Updates are infrequent.
-Too few game modes and maps.

Review:
I came in not really expecting much, but it does have a lot of charm and a great original concept so far. The Skillsync feature is fun and original. The concept of adding little enhancers to your character gives you little additional bonuses to your gameplay (i.e. faster reload, weapon swap, sprint speed, deployables health/time, etc). The abilities themselves per character are useful all around, albeit rarely teamplay oriented in a game that is always team vs team.

The first thing that really got to me, however, is the weapon selection. The images you see on the store page show a really cool, futuristic looking bullpup; not in the game. The images show Togusa's Mateba; not in the game. Besides the one Seburo pistol, literally nothing from the GitS universe carries over into this game. Almost as if they failed to hire someone to do any concept work at all. The images in the store to appear to be, at the very least, staged images involving assets that exist, rather than some sort of paintover by another artist, yet we are lacking some essential weapons here.

Now that's not to say the weapons are bad, they are just the most boring list of CoD/Battlefield weapons you could possibly imagine. Only one of which even has hardware on it that makes it look different; the M4A1 which has a different handguard and stock. Absolutely everything else is the exact assortment you would see from a modern shooter 5 years ago. The modding system seems nice too, however they artifically restricted optics so that guns only had 2-3 options maximum even if they are all essentially the same size, use the same magnification, and are for the same obvious rail system that all modern firearms use. All other attachments are essentially identical for all weapons (front angledgrip, bipod, laser, barrel, and magazines), and for most of those categories, there is only one unlockable option, and one purchase option in total.

Sure, maybe some of these weapons do show up at some point in the series or movies, as it takes place in a variety of locations against a myriad of worldwide organizations, but that does not excuse the lack of originality, especially when they've already added a non-canon character. It just tells me they have no interest in making this any more than a generic shooter in every regard.

Map design and sizes could definitely use some expansion. That's not to say it is easy to camp or use cheap tactics, but there are too few options overall to reach objectives or the enemy team. So while I don't advocate any sort of MLG involvement here, it took me a matter of hours to master the layout of every single available map in every single game mode because they are just that simplistic. Maps that are small are one thing, but the number of obvious chokepoints and general lack of enough alternate routes make it far too easy to not get flanked or countered.

Character design is actually quite good, and identifying enemies is fun and easy because enemies have a completely different model. The caveat? This means your custom skin is rarely seen if only your own team can see it. Customization also boils down to alt textures, and currently there are only 2 in existence. Each character is specifically tied to one ability, which sounds fine, as someone can identify your ability by what character you are playing, but that is also sort of pointless if the other team can't tell the difference. Because we are not lacking in screen real estate, the ability could have been tied to some other identifying icon and let everyone use whatever player model they wanted. More importantly, the ability has literally nothing to do with most of the characters that have them. For example, Matoko has thermoptic camoflage, which is fine to be known for, but everyone at some point uses it in the GitS universe. Generally all the abilities are made to be different enough, regardless of how they interact, but there  is no direct link between their usage and the character using it.

Skillsync, while fun, is generally worthless because either the maps are not dynamic enough for it to matter. You could get an entire team to skillsync each o f the abilities and steamroll a team, but it would only last for a short period of time before another long recharge/cooldown to use any ability again.

The real issue, however is that there have been barely any updates. You may say Well it only released in December

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Early access: Please note my opinion may change with time and with updates and changes.

I'm a long time fan of the GITS franchise, I'm old enough to remember buying the original film on VHS in the 90's and it's one of those animes that will always stick with me.

And firstly, and for me most importantly, I struggle to see what this game has to do with the espionage, intrigue, sabotage and subterfuge of that brilliant fiction. There is not much more than faithful aesthetics and sounds and even then that is only a thin veneer on a game that very clearly seems to lack any style of its own. There is a deficit of substance and depth that will deter some fans of the series as I know it is doing so to me because this is something integral to the GITS franchise, story.

To address the game itself I find myself struggling for words but the ones I pick are picked carefully.
I still think the franchise would be best suited to a FPS but as a shoddy, clunky FPS that doesn't flow smoothly it made my skin crawl, seriously, the controls and handling are in dire need of speeding up and streamlining (Ctrl for crouch but Caps Lock for Sneak??? Pick one, make it do both and stick with it.)
the combat in the GITS films and series is cool and slick, featuring acrobatics and feats of strength, this is important to be reflected in the gameplay, you should feel" like you're a cyborg agent who can moonsault a gun out of an opponent's hands.
It may come to stick that this title plays like Deus Ex meets COD and roughly looks like the offspring of such a union but that is only indicative of the niche this game is trying to fill and how poorly it will succeed at filling either better than they have themselves already.
Nothing offered isn’t already on offer anywhere else save for the IP but you’ve already heard my thoughts on that.
Compared to other gameplay types from popular shooters this feels like a poor job
date: none of the nuances that make other titles fun or exciting to play but just a dull
recommended: repetitive drudge.\n\nSeriously consider the development of this game as yet another FPS online multiplayer game in a veritable ocean of similar titles
hoursPlayed: nothing is new or brilliant.\n\nI will continue to play this game in the coming days and will update
voteText: amend and edit this review according as I see fit."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

MISSES THE MARK - BADLY

If you're a fan of Ghost in the Shell like I am, you would have been excited at the prospect of getting a PC Ghost in the Shell game.  I know I was.  Ignoring all the bugs complaints (true or otherwise), or the poor animation/physics quality, or everything else related to gameplay, this game fails on it's most important selling point.  The theme.  Instead it concentrates on everything that doesn't matter to the franchise like out of place character and weapon schemes.

Apart from the characters, nothing fits.  The enemies are ripped straight out of Killzone instead of your run of the mill, poorly equipped guerilla insurgents and ghost-hacked civilians.  Even the weapons are all wrong, with the arsenal containing mostly 21st century weapons instead of the hallmark Seburo-type weapons we've seen in the GitS and even Appleseed series.  And don't even get me started on the Halo-esq gauntlet knife.  Bottom line it's all wrong.

Lastly, the game is pure deathmatch.  It's like calling Rainbow Six: Siege a Rainbow Six game.  It really isnt if you know anything about the series.  This game is sorely lacking singleplayer/coop operations.  They have three seasons, plus the Arise series, and three movies to go off of.  No excuses.

Bottom line, if this game even hopes to be worthy of the title Ghost in the Shell, it has a lot of work to do before it's projected 2016 release.  So get on it.  I'd really love to turn this review from a Stay away" to a "Pick it up now"."

As a fan of the Ghost in the Shell series, i'm quite enjoying the game. It does GitS well for a First Person Shooter, and for a f2p game it should be excellent. Looking past that, it is a fairly simple game. Nothing genre defining, but very enjoyable nevertheless. In it's current state as of 12/14/15 (steam release day), there are only a few maps and a dozen or so guns, but the game is still in closed beta so more content can be expected.

All in all, play if you're a fan of the series. If not, it's still worth a try at the very least when it goes f2p.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Game content as the time of writing this is incredibly limited, though the base game is astonishly well polished considering this is a very early access title. It's clear the developers focused on the stability of the game at launch rather than content, and while I'd prefer both, that's unresonable and I'm glad they went the way they did instead of launching an unfunctional unbalanced mess. Business model is currently fair, it will be a F2P game and you need to pay now, but it is a mere $5 and you are given early access goodies to make up for this. The chances of a game launching with fair business models and turning to the dark side is very common though, so I hope this doesn't happen, but I'm not going to rule out that possibility. The developers seem friendly and outspoken with the community and I hope this continues. Nexon and western markets is usually a battlefield, so I hope we don't see naive development decisions based on what works in asian markets that kill these sorts of games, in the west, we don't stand for unapologetic P2W tripe. But as I said the business model is fine right now, but this could change and the developers should be careful.

The game reminds me a lot of blacklight actually, it doesn't feel as satisfying as Blacklight and the customisation is less, but the gameplay is generally smarter, more polished and more importantly balanced compared to blacklight. Also as I said the maps are incredibly well designed, they may not be perfect but as someone who really looks at map designs, I can tell that the devs are educated on what makes a good map. Simple, uncluttered and balanced is the way to do maps and they have succeeded there. The guns last I played were balanced with the exception of the semi auto sniper rifle which was broken as ♥♥♥♥. But I'll update weapon balance later.

You may be lucky to get 20 hours out of this game right now, but if you are a fan of fast pace FPS games you will enjoy that time. It's solid, the maps are well designed and the balance is passable for a release title, as I said the reason this is very early access is the clear lack of content.


P.S Oh completely forgot, I played 14ish hours of this game when it launched and have no opinion on the state of hackers. By now the game could very much be ruined by hackers and I can almost guarentee this will happen. I haven't played this game in a while but I wrote the review recently. Before buying check to see if the game has been ruined by cheaters or not. I'll update the review next time I play and theres some more content.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has potential, but it still needs a lot of work. The gunplay feels a bit clunky and honestly if you're going to make a fast paced shooter like this you have to make sure that the movement feels fluid and smooth which it doesn't, however it is still playable once you get use to it.

There isn't a lot of content yet, but I'm assuming that will come in later updates. I'm also kind of dissapointed that they haven't added any lore based weapons from the anime into the game. Idk if these weapons are just placeholders, but all the weapons are just slightly futuristic versions of the modern weapons that we have today.

All in all, I can see this becoming a solid game and I will continue to support it. The only reason my review for this is positive is because as a huge fan of the GITS series I like it because it's GITS and I'm only recommending this game to fans of the series. If you're just a normal FPS player who knows nothing about the series and want to try this game, I wouldn't recommend it as you'd probably find nothing special about it, but to fans like me it is.

Final Verdict: Wait for future updates, there's not a lot of content in the game with a limited amount of weapons, customization, maps, and gamemodes.

Also biggest plus: NO MICROTRANSACTIONS!!!!(yet at least) YAAAAAAAAAAAAY!!!
