reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell is a generic title. Don't expect anything ground-breakingly new, but don't take that as a bad thing. Whilst it offers nothing really new or out of the ordinary it's a very fun, fairly balanced multiplayer shooter inwhich you can gain a lot of entertainment from.

From a quick analysis, the game is based upon an anime that shares the same name/brand. (Personally I have not seen the anime nor do I know much about it) So immediatley the game gives off an anime vibe (not full on weeb trash), but also a heavy emphasis on cyberpunk and terrorism/counter-terrorism themes too. Essentially at this stage of 'Early Access' the game features a small number of maps, and a couple of games that include: Team Deathmatch, Demolition and Conquest.

-Team Deathmatch is your typical go to gamemode, it's the most played in the game and you sadly won't find a lot of games for the other modes.
-Demolition plays just like Counter Strike Global Offensive's very own gamemode of the same name. One team plants the bomb on a site and defends it whilst the other team defuses and eliminates the other team.
-Conquest is about capturing node areas to control a giant robot reminiscent of a spider that aids the team as they push to further nodes across the map.

The weapons in the game handle very well with a plethora of weapon types from assault rifles, smgs, sniper rifles, shotguns, etc. I've used a fair amount of weapons in the game, most of the assault rifles handle the same, some might have more recoil or deal more damage etc. The shotguns are OP at close range, the pistols are weak but help in a pinch to finish off enemies, the sniper rifles are only a 1-hit kill if a headshot is attained. The gameplay is balanced very well and I must give credit to the devs to have this game balanced nicely. No gun is op or underbalanced from the feel of gameplay, and the movement isn't too fast neither to slow with the maps being a good size - not too short not too small.

Ingame, there's a gradual unlock system where the more you play, the more score and kills you earn - you'll eventually unlock weapons, attachements and more. You earn ingame credits that are used to buy other weapons, attachements and all sorts of other items too. While it might seem like a grind to earn these, playing regularly will guarantee you these items in good time.

I recommend this game to fans of FPS games, it's a multiplayer only game too so not for the SP lovers. A very promising early access title.

7/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll be honest at first I was like oh no Nexon... this should be great but then I said nah ♥♥♥♥ it lets have some faith in the developers instead and was I glad that I did. THIS GAME IS NOT REVOLUTIONARY not in the slightest and I think that's why I love it. I came into it wanting an old experience a basic, nice and simple first person shooter like the good old days of Call of Duty 4: Modern Warfare and that's exactly what I got. Just so it's clear I have not watched the anime so my review is based fully on the game itself!

First off there is a average amount of options enough to get a good pass for early access just don't go into it thinking ♥♥♥♥ yeah triple a quality options. To me I personally think the gameplay is great but I think that just boils down to personal preference to be completely honest. The sounds design apart from the generic gun sounds and grenades sound so damn good and the hud in game looks nice and is easy to use. So much games lately have been out going crazy with this hero system in first person shooters... but I can safely say they do a good enough job about it. Weapon customization is also great its just like any other shooter it's got the basics skins, a good amount of attachments etc like I said before you know the game isn't revolutionary. The leveling I think is quite balanced it's not slow but neither is it fast, it's a good place for it to be same with weapon unlocks etc. There's also 3 game modes Team Deathmatch, Demolition and Terminal Conquest. Team Deathmatch is well you know a deathmatch between teams, Demolition is place the bomb or defuse it like in Counter-Strike and Terminal Conquest is capture point by point a tug of war kinda like rush from Battlefield but back and forth it's good fun. The game of course has a marketplace and boom red lights just went up but right now it's actually very very very good everything is obtainable just by playing the game which is always a good thing. I was pleasantly surprised by the servers and community for any Australian players out there you're pretty much covered in this game there's an average amount of lobbies going plus everyone seems very friendly. My favorite option has to be custom matches with friends you also get xp it's just so socially friendly it's nice.

Now as much as I like the game it does need improvements obviously first off straight away is keybinds it works at the moment just fine but it does need tweaks and improvements why is interact and pick up two different keys? Things like that. The main menu works as it is but also does need tweaking its not obvious what is what from the get go I mean I actually had to look up a guide to claim my items. Also ONE HUGE THING the game needs is an fov slider for real everything feels zoomed in, fullscreen mode needs to be renamed to fullscreen windowed because that's what it is, I'm not complaining about it being an option cause I love borderless just calling it fullscreen is misleading to most people. As much as I said I do love the gameplay it still does need tweaks especially melee, the tutorial was rather long and useless BUT COOL AS ♥♥♥♥ then again that does fall under personal preference. The game does have performance issues too like when I first launch the game for at least the next 10-20 mins it stutters in game then smooths out, also why does the Nexon launcher have to stay open it has no value since its there for like under 10 seconds honestly just make it auto close after the games up. Lobby wait times are pretty ridiculous 90 second countdowns it seriously needs to go down to like 30 seconds. Last thing is Nexon and their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ god damn anti-cheat there is like so many ways to go about it but nope you have to keep making a new Nexon anti-cheat that does jack ♥♥♥♥ for the rest of the games life span... honestly just use something else for once!

I love the game and I don't mind dumping $5 USD on it though as it stands I wouldn't recommend it to everyone as it will be free to play at some point but for those dying like I did for some simple basic first person shooter fun just dive right in!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If your thinking about it. Now is the time to get it. The game is really enjoyable at the moment. Everything runs off the in game cash right now. It has its glitches here and there, but it's to be expected. We all know nexon may turn this into another P2W, so jump on the ball before it starts rolling downhill.

Edit: Came back to it and so far its still enjoyable and here's my overall review.
Pros:
- For being early access it plays very well. it's well polished.

-They are updating it and listening to the community thats always a +.

- Every gun and upgrade is atainable via in-game currency and you get 50k GP every lvl up. They also just increased gp gain every match last update by community request. Only thing that requires actual money is cosmetics.

- If you've played CS or Cod, than you'll drop a lot of kills. I average 20-40 kills a game. Very easy to get into and familiar with.

-Very enjoyable if you can get a party going with your friends.

Cons:
-You better get some friends if you wanna play during the week. Servers are very dead sometimes. I've had people go from east to west servers just to return to our game cause it's the only one going on both servers. On weekends you probably can find a server on your designated coast.

-Hit Reg is meh. It's usually accurate, but could use some finer tuning.

-No mic support. I know mics usually bring toxicity with it, but in this game I feel it would encourage more players to stick around in the lobby and do callouts during the matches.

-Some maps need some work. Especially port" it's such a small map and only based on spawn trapping the other team. It would work with a smaller amount of players maybee 5v5 not with 10 on each team.


Overall: I would recommend it if your looking for another shooter to play around with from time to time. I would wait a bit more for more updates or a boost in players

Early Access Review

Before you read the whole review I would just like to say.. for an Early Access game, this is definitely worth the 4.99.

Some people are probably expecting an anime cell shaded story game where they get to play through the events of Stand Alone Complex. This is not that!! I mean obviously if you bothered to watched the gameplay trailer?

If you are a fan of FPS, love the typical game modes that CS:GO and COD offer this game is for you. The best way I can explain it is its like CS:GO with a Ghost in the Shell theme. A CoD progression kind of system when it comes to unlocking weapons and mods and the gameplay is pretty much the same as all multiplayer shooters.. with a little twist :)

Each character has certain skills, like the skills they had in the show! From going stealth mode to gaining a barrier of extra armor, setting up turrets and more. Although the game is still in Early Access, I can't see much changing other than little tweaks here and there. With whats out now we have more than a basic idea of what to expect when the final version releases.

Maybe in the future there will be some kind of story mode but for now it's pretty much your usual team death match/demolition shooter. Thats not a bad thing though. If I had to choose between this and other multiplayer FPS I would choose Ghost in the Shell. The unique skills and characters make it interesting.

I like everything about it, the only problem I have are the frame drops. When in combat for a split second things can get a bit choppy.. this is a huge deal when it comes to competitive gameplay. If they fix that they are golden!
So the optomization is pretty good but could be better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll keep this simple. It's great, really it is, I'm not often a fan of shooters but this one is neet.  (Ignore my low playtime, I've got a boatload of coursework to do atm and can't play this too much, but I can tell I'm going to sink quite a few hours into it over the holidays.)

Pros
-gameplay feels solid and authentic
-it's snappy and fast paced without every weapon being a one shot kill, meaning that there's an element of picking a gun to meet your play style.
-character unique skills are a fairly original thing in the shooter genre, especially the skill sharing which adds a surprising amount of strategy to the game.
-The game feels very GitS. Nice and gritty with an air of shiny and futuristic.
-The above feature is in no small part helped by the voice actors, who have mostly returned from the anime.
-Microtransactions don't unbalance gameplay or make it remotely pay to win. I haven't done any microtransactions and I didn't feel at a disadvantage.

Cons
-You can only jump like 1 foot off the ground. You think I'm exaggerating? I'm not. I could seriously jump twice as high in real life. I hope this gets tweaked, because it's really the only thing about the game that doesn't feel very GitS. I mean you're a damn cyborg/augmented human. Let's see characters that can jump a story high like they can in the anime, then I'll be happy. But this is legitimately my only complaint, I won't touch anything about the optimisation, this an alpha, and a really good one at that.

Features I'd like to see
-Character specific agility stats/health. I've always wanted a shooter that does this. Even if only slightly. We already pick characters based on their skills, but I think certain characters should be slightly more resilient than others, and certain characters should be faster/be able to jump higher than others. If done properly I think this could be an amazing mechanic.
-graphically, I'd like to see slight improvements to the lighting/contrast of the game areas to really flush it out and cement that GitS atmosphere.
-I know that this is a planned feature, but I'm really itching to play the PvE in this game, I feel like the story mode is what is going to really kill it. I just didn't think I could review this without mentioning it. Obviously GitS has a phenominal story line, and I can't wait to see how they implement that in this game. They've got the voice actors for it so I feel like the devs will really be missing a trick if they don't do something with the talent.

This is well worth a 'buy.' seriously, it's like £4 (what is that, $5.50?) You can't really go wrong for that price. I genuinely think that once this gets into a full release it'll give counterstrike a run for its money.

Early Access Review

Somewhat feels like a CoD.

The theme is very close to BO3, however, enhanced due to the fact that the anime is way before CoD.

Enough CoD reference, let's jump into this game.

First of all, the game feels snapping, most guns does not have recoil at all (pretty good for its fast paced gameplay), but bullet velocity is extremely low, and it bothers me a lot since I'm too used to the weapon mechanism of CS:GO. Sniping in this game is not that great, you would have to stand still until the bullet impacted something, that mean you can't move right after you pull the trigger, or else your shot would be off.

Weapon customization is pretty cool, lots of options, most guns are based of modern stuff, but some of them are outfitted with futuristic furnitures, pretty creative.

To conclude this review, yes, I would recommend this game if you're into modern military fps, and are ok with some of the futuristic elements.

(And no, the map is not too small"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's an alright fps.

The maps are a little small and clustered, especially with the awful spawns, but that's only in deathmatch. The maps are relatively big in comparison in the objective game modes. Honestly there's a few hotspots where most of the firefights take place and you won't really see much gunfights outside of those places.

The unlocking of things is absurdly slow. Just so damn slow. You'll need a decent amount of gametime to get attachments for the gun you want to use.

It's not as laggy as I first thought it was, since they apparently messed up the east and west servers, meaning I was playing with the wrong side of the Country. Now it's pretty smooth minus actual people with bad connections.

There's not that many weapons out right now, which is fine since this is going to be F2P and it's only in early access right now. Also, the slow unlocking of attachments actually pairs well with the low amount of weapons to stop people from unlocking everything to quickly.

There's a couple of other issues I have with the game like headshots being instakills, no health regen (even after over a minute of being out of fighting), not being able to pick up someone's primary to replace your pistol, an over the top interface that takes a good while to get used to and just comepletely awful team balancing; however, since it's F2P and the dev's seem to be listening to the community to better the game and there's no pay-to-win aspects in the game, it's already better than most games out there.

Give it a shot, disappointed or not it's free to play so you don't really lose anything except maybe an hour of your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pictures and final verdict on MMOs.com: http://mmos.com/review/first-assault

tl;dr:

First Assault is nothing new. There are a few new twists injected into a standard formula that has been in play for quite some time, but it will ultimately feel very familiar. Despite that, the high production values, inclusion of the original voice cast, and Ghost In the Shell setting may convince you to play it over other games. At this point in time, it is not pay-to-win in the slightest. Keep in mind, however, that that could change in the future. This is the first time that we have seen a major free-to-play publisher make use of Early Access, and First Assault’s tenure may very well set a precedent.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell Alpha (EARLY ACCESS) Impressions
Ghost in the Shell is based on an anime/manga series that has been critically acclaimed to be one of the better sci-fi of it's genre. Having a game that is a First Person Shooter is definitely something that is appreciated for fans of the series. From my understanding the Early Access purchases help support the games development into an eventual Free to Play - this could either harm the game in the distant future or it could lead to a potential gem.

I've chosen to purchase the alpha (early access) to support Nexon with their video game as I personally do enjoy Ghost in the Shell, along with their games. However, this is based on my own judgement of what I believe supports the games future. I'd personally would love to have more players get into this game, and can recommend this title to fans of both Ghost in the Shell and Nexon as a developer. However, there are indeed changes that can be made to make this game better, and with the game being in it's alpha state I'm not too worried.

As of right now...
As I continue to play this game I notice things that are off right off the bat:
Hip fire has more accuracy then aiming down sights.
You can assissinate through walks/doors.
Hit detection is pretty bad. Sometimes headshots aren't registered to kill right away.
Key binding shouldn't be stressful, it should be You want C as crouch? No problem! We'll just replace the key you have as C for something else" instead of "You can't rebind until you rebind the other key to have the key you want to be the action you desire".
When you do play the game
recommended: "how do you get good at this game?" Don't aim down your sights yet... It'll more than likely get you killed. Also
hoursPlayed: always use your skills when you're able to use them
voteText:
and make sure you sync with other teammates when you play too.

This review will change overtime as the game updates!
Just to reiterate
helpfulPercent: yes I know
votesHelpful: "this is in it's alpha state"
votesTotal: and hopefully the devs read every review or bugs found by players to make this game amazing! However
votesFunny: if you notice I am fully 'recommending' this game despite it's flaws that can be patched out eventually.\nTo those who think this game is just another shooter? Yes
commentsCount: yes it is. Are there better shooters out there? Yes
column16: yes there is. Should I wait until it goes down in price or Free to Play? Ultimately

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Very interesting and promising FPS here. Been playing slice Closed beta and had a blast honestly. Sure, it is a pretty generic FPS overall with Gits theme rather than a hardcore gits game. BUT....it does it RIGHT. many things i really enjoy about this FPS i actually despire in many game i played.

PRO:

-Run smoth and flawless as far as i experienced. I got a fairly old pc and it run like a charm, well optimized. Graphic are satisfying.

-Weapon feel GREAT: they actually have RECOIL (i alway hated blacklight or COD lazer gun) and SPREAD (and not pre set one like CS:go)...so YEA, more will complain weapon are unreliable and innacurate, but that not the case...get soem tim eto get used to them and find the proper way to pace tap fire/burst. But once you get used you jsut drop dead poeple from across the map with the started m4 extremely fast.

-Headshto feel like...headshot. Every AR, even SMG, in theyr eeffective range WILL OHK headshot. and i love it.

-No regeneration. Exept from some specific skill, when you liek half hp...you wont magically hide around a corner and be good to go again in 3 second. no you will try your best to still do damage and get killed from a pistol round casu you had 20 hp left. Love it.

-Skill sharing is fun! lot of skill can be shared with teammate once you get level 2...and that open up for some great teamplay potential.


CONS:

-Not a lot of content yet. This is only early acces, have to be expected but...like 4-5 map, 3 game mode, few weapon. Enought to have LOT of fun IMO but dont expect a full agem yet.

-No monetarization system yet. As it stand every weapon/mod you unlcuk with the only gainiable trought playing currency are permanent and stuff...what nice. How it will be once more proper monetarization system take place in open beta...cannot be sure. I trust they will go for the only cosmetic and faster unlock path however. Dirty bomb did it right IMO i dotn see why they would screw up this game.

-Still a few bug around (again expected in early acces)


seriously...try it out. Worth it...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

AUSTRALIA REGION AVAILABLE

Great fun FPS game, a cross between NeoTokyo and COD.

There are three main game modes: Deathmatch, Demolition (plant a bomb at one of the two sites) and Terminal Conquest where you spawn a friendly Tachikoma (that speaks same as in the anime) that fights for you after you start capturing a Terminal :P

Game shooting mechanics are similar to CS, but you can also use iron sites and customize your load outs and guns like in COD.

Cool feature is that every character has got a special ability that powers up as you kill enemies, for example Motoko can use an invisibility cloak (like in NeoTokyo, but it automatically decloaks and recloaks after a delay when you shoot) and Batou shoots a rocket launcher from his arm. Also when you activate your ability at Tier 2 your teammates can copy that ability by being near you and pressing E.

There are 7 Section 9 characters you can play as plus what looks like locked Laughing Man character. At level 1 you choose one of the characters from Section 9, and then as you level up you can unlock two more at level 3 and 5 respectively. Then you gotta buy any others for ingame currency that you earn by playing.

There are lots of gun attachments and guns that you unlock as you level up and then can buy using the ingame currency.

The characters (operatives) look great and voice acting is great also - the same as in the anime.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex is basically your another online FPS game on Steam but this time, Ghost of the Shell being slapped on the cover. Personally, I love Ghost of the Shell which is the only reason I bought this but it wasn't what I expected it to be.

You begin the game with a famous soundtrack 'Making of Cyborg' introducing the whole shebang (opening.) A cut scene plays and the first thing you will do is the tutorial. After completing the tutorial, then you will actually make it to the menu. And what a surprise, you can customise your avatar, your weapons and set up your room. And in the options, not much accessibility is offered, except for the 'Left-hand enabled' option which is nice. But no subtitles. As a player who wears hearing impairs, I would appreciate some subtitles if the devs plans to add story into it.

I tried Team Deathmatch, it was fun. You are given not just weapons but skills such as invisibly, 'sees-enemies-through-walls' ability etc., But again, nothing new. It does have similarities to COD Black ops with all its cool advances technology' going on. But I would recommend it because it's much cheaper than CODs series and it's easier to play without all these kids screaming at you. Plus
date: the price is pretty reasonable considering what contents and quality this game has to offer.\n\nOverall: This is like Project Snowblind and CSGO mixed together. Would recommend to buy
recommended: if you have patient on its development and a few glitches.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can neither recommend this game nor tell you to stay away from this title.
All that can be said is that it will be at your own risk.

I recommend this game:
-I recommend it to any Ghost in the shell lovers out there.
-I recommend the game for its characters' skill variety.
-I recommend this game for its game modes. Not a lot but it helps to diversify gameplay and that is a +
-I recommend this game because the community is very decent
-I recommend this game if you have a clear low latency to their servers.

I do not recommend this game:
-I do not recommend it for FPS fairness stats weaponry
-I do not recommend this game for map design that seem rather primal, easy, or quickly made or flat to level designers.
-I do not recommend this game for the headshots. it is just a stupid function or still too poorly implemented at this alpha stage and it needs serious rewrites that makes the whole game feel like happy goes lucky or Aim assisted ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ters.
-I do not recommend this game if your ping is average or worse.



There are weapon that you MUST have and others you MUST avoid like the black plague. While weapon stats is instanciated as it should be, the difference is so vast that players want to focus on HS or head shot in order to help if not carry the team, who say head shots say particular few types of weapons, the rest is complete garbage that ends with lower random headshot stats.

I would sit this game better than Ghost Recon Online down the road from now when they implement solutions and refine the game but the game still has a very long way to become nearly as fun as BF franchises small maps

Early Access Review

An able, responsive shooter that reminds me of the older days of the original Counter-Strike. It feels like it blasted out of the mid-2000's with all that made people love those kinds of shooters but took with it none of the baggage. It has an active community, active moderators and active developers. For how long? Who can know.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wait for the free release unless you want to beta test this game.

Is the core gameplay fun?  Yes.

Modern coutner-strike style gunplay meets fun class based team oriented strategy.  Using skill sync to give your entire team invisibility or sight through walls and then rush the bomb site feels incredibly rewarding and allows for great comebacks and unexpected plays.  However, the gunplay is significantly hampered by the stat based gun upgrade system that makes shooting slightly random (and spray very random) unless you upgrade the relevant stats.  I kind of like this though because the game relies much more on team work and using your abilities effectively, rather than simply sniping the other guy first.  If you sit in one spot and try to snipe you are gauranteed to get picked off by the myriad of abilities available.

Is a lot of the launcher infrastructure broken?  Very obviously yes.
You are supposed to get a free character unlock at level 3 and level 5.  I did not get an unlock at level 5.  There are various obvious spelling errors (Impact Dempener, Anti-Machin Launcher).  The cyborg upgrades that you (sometimes) get after matches are either woefully useless (reload while sprinting, wait I can already do that right?) or totally over powered (20% increased strafe speed + 10% movement speed gives you a HUGE peek advantage).  And they don't give you these random upgrades often enough, so you will run out if you try to actually use them.

Beyond that the game just has general balance issues as you would expect.  The rocket launcher ability at level 2 can instantly kill the tank that spawns in the tank mode.  If someone on your team saves their rocket for this you never even have to deal with the tank...

However, I'm going to recommend.  Because it is in fact a lot of fun when you get past the early access issues.  And if they can fix some of the launcher bugs and balance the game a bit more I can see it being a really fun game by release.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very good alternative for Call of Duty.

Gameplay is similar, fast paced and action packed, you choose a character out of a dozen different characters from the show to play as, each with different abilities like super sprint, shield which also regens health, thermal sight allowing you to see enemies through walls, invisibilty etc. and a loadout which consists of main weapon, a secondary weapon (pistol) and a grenade.
You can skillsync your skills with, I think 3 others nearby if available to your character so nearby allies may use your skill at the same time as you are which also allows for some nice skill stacking and tactical play.

Gamemodes are demolition which is what it sound like, attackers try to plant the bomb, defenders defuse it,
Terminal conquest which has two teams fighting over a series of control points which have to be captured in order, so when the first one is captured then the point moves, if the other team captures it back then it's the first on again,
Last but not least there is the classic Team deathmatch.

There is a nice but a bit small selection of weapons at the moment of the review in the game with nice customization options like sights, barrels, muzzles etc. all which affect the weapons performance. You buy weapons with in game currency (GP), but there is a cash shop too. You won't get that much GP out of single matches, but every level up grants you 50,000 GP which is enough to buy a single addon to a weapon. Buying a weapon costs around 240,000 GP so about 5 levels and you are able to buy a weapon. On top of that, there are unlockable weapons which unlock as you gain experience and are cheaper to buy after unlocking them than other weapons bought from the market.

TL;DR

I highly recommend this for people who want fast and action packed games like Call of Duty.

The game is not a direct CoD clone but in my opinion the gameplay is made with CoD in mind, though Ghost in the Shell provides some unique takes on things, like the skillsync system.

It also cost me just 3,5€ which is well worth the money.

Early Access Review

Let's be honest: It's not going to win any awards. Even so, it's a solid foundation for a decent game. It's got tight controls and solid shooting mechanics, even when you first start out you never feel as if the game has you at any serious disadvantage for not having more unlocks.  All the weapons seem to play a role and have their use.

As of wiritng (Early access, Jan 2016.) what is there is good, especially for fans of the series. Skill linking and the abilities of the characters add a fun twist to the game and do not feel too unabalanced or overpowered either. Pick it up if you have a couple bucks to spare, or wait till it hits FTP. It's a great game for when you just wanna kill an hour shooting stuff and don't want to have to get too serious.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ok... first things first... its Ghost in the Shell as a First Person Shooter... that of itself should be enough of a hook for many of us gamers who also know the anime and manga to jump right in... anyone remember the 3rd person game of Ghost in the Shell? it was great and alot of fun on PS2... i only mention it as its one of my fave games back in the day... well...

this game delivers even in early access... i was on the closed beta before the game arrived on Steam... i thoroughly enjoyed my time on the beta and had great hopes for this ones when it hit retail... and so far it has delivered... there are some issues... they have been mentioned by reviewers already... all i can say is overall as a team based FPS... this game is great and huge amounts of fun... i am trying to get 3-4 of my friends involved so we can play on the same team but getting everyone together had proven difficult due to timezones and peoples work... but anyways back to the game itself...

the overal aesthetic and feel is truly Ghost in the Shell... characters are instantly recognizable from the series Stand Alone Complex... and the character detail and animations are really lovely... the attention to detail is very good...

i love the real world weapons... also component customizations are good... kinda reminds me of Blacklight... the game back in 2012 that started all that kind of thing... you can buy scopes... barrels... stocks... mags... etc... and these are all speciific to your chosen weapon... right now theres decent choice but i can see more weapons being added with later updates... i also hope to see the assault rifles and pistols from Stand Alone Complex but the inclusion of real world weapons was a good idea... grenades are useful in the game... but they dont break the game... one thing i really liked was the special abilities of each character... they are realized well and they work nicely in the game... each character has strengths and weaknesses... so when you can unlock new characters while playing through the game its nice to look at the special abilities that appeal to you... i have 4 Section 9 team mates unlocked so far and i have 2 spare character unlocks available... i tend to play as Motoko as she was always my fave character from the anime...

as to finding a game very late at night... i have had no issues... there always seems to be people playing this at any time of day... i tend to log into the European Union West server and i can get a game anytime of day or night with minimal wait times... server lag has been mentioned before but i havent experienced it hardly at all... in fact only once...

my internet connection is fibre 80MB and my ping is usually 30ms or less so i never have connection issues...

all i can say is this game is great fun and it doesnt cost much right now to get started... (£3.99 on early access) eventually once the game leaves early access it will be totally free to play but i am glad i got in early and got the Elite early access bundle...

seriously people just try the game... if you enjoy the FPS genre there is alot to love and the whole Ghost in the Shell theme is inplemented rather well...

ill give it a solid 8.5/10 and i know the Devs are adding updates and new content frequently... just get some and dive in...


see you ingame...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey, listen up. Yes, you, the one reading this: I'm here to give you a serious review and not waste your time. Crazy right?

Anyway, I'm here to answer the question on your mind: is this a good game and should I get it?

So far I'd say the answer is YES. Here's why:

- For an early BETA it feels like a 1.01. There are very few glitches besides the occasional body clipping through a wall but that happens in almost every FPS.
-Gunplay is solid, so far. You have your flavor of standard guns: developers have promised to add more later. For now you get an SMG, an assault rifle, a sniper, a pistol, an arm blade thing that acts like a knife, and a grenade to start. Unlockables include a more powerful assault rifle, another SMG, and a LMG, among other variants.
-The three gamemodes- good old Team Deathmatch, Demolition and Point Control- provide enough variety to keep the game fresh for a while.
-The community is mostly non-toxic. There is the occasional Stand-Alone (see what I did there?) who will disrupt the flow of things but they are ignorable.
-Motoko has been fan-serviced.

Things to keep in mind:
-THIS GAME IS IN BETA. EVERYTHING IS CAPABLE OF CHANGE. What you see now may be worse than Battlefield 3 Beta later.
-Please, for the love of Pete, buy the least expensive pack first, if you can't wait for the game to become a F2P later on.
-Sadly, Togusa does not have his famous revolver.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First things first rest in peace uncle Phil...

Now...

I've seen the anime, and wasn't super into it. It was nice and all, but not my bag. On to the game:

As far as shooters go, there's a tried and true formula and the one that everyone seems to enjoy the most is the CoD...I don't personally understand it, but that's fine.

This game has great qualities and is trying to mix it up. Unique abilities per operator that can give a strategic advantage in the game definitely adds a great element to the game play. It's not OP because both sides can have it and stronger abilities have a longer wait time to execute. Also if an entire team is using one operator...it's pretty easy to pick them apart by using a better strategy.

The guns have a pretty decent balance and the devs have done a good job with them. SMG's don't work for crap at range unless you fire slowly and the dmg is so minimal that anyone with an AR is going to pick you off pretty quickly if they can aim decently. The AR's fire slow and in CQB, the SMG will tear them apart. Of course there's your one shot sniper, but we are all used to that so it's hardly an issue. Small ammo capacity and slow reload time plus the slower ADS due to the scope is all factored in.

The match bonuses add a great little element too. I know when I was just short of hitting the next rank I was praying for an EXP +10% and pumped my fists in the air like an idiot when I rolled it.

Operator customization is weak at the moment, but I'm sure there will be tons of options once it actually rolls out. We are still playing Early Access so there's a lot to come out in the near future. The little cyber implants also give a little edge too and is nice to use to help with things like quicker reloading or faster strafing. I personally use the SMG and am zipping all over the place spraying my load in everyone's face so I fancy the quick reload and strafing.

Currently I feel the level progression is a little slow for my taste, but then again if I reached the top too quickly I'd probably get bored in a way. Even though, once I've hit the maximum unlocks, I know I'll still have fun playing just to wreck other people...

All in all I'd definitely recommend this game to everyone who likes FPS. More features will roll out and Nexon has a great habit of doing lots of events to keep the community interested. Good job Nexon USA!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I enjoy this game even though I'm not used to games like this with weird movement pacing (I.e. being too used to fast moving games like UnrealT2k4, Duke Nukem, Doom, Etc.)

I see a lot of people complaining that this should have been a game like Deus Ex but people forget that the game is based on Stand Alone Complex which had way more action than the movies.

Speaking of Gunplay it can be tricky to get used to considering this isn't like Combat Arms or Call of Duty where Spraying will get you kills but ADSing wont help as much either (at least for the time being because I feel the snap to ADS is slow and is too harsh on sensitvity reduction). You have to burst your shots as recoil and spread will get you killed even at mid-close range. Hitboxes are also a little jank to be honest and it seems too easy to get headshots even with non long range weapons.

The use of power ups are nice and the need for teamwork is a plus especially with using the SkillSync system can turn games to your favor

Currently I give this game a 7.5/10 because it does need improvement but overall the game works relatively fine you just have to learn how to work with the games systems.

An able, responsive shooter that reminds me of the older days of the original Counter-Strike. It feels like it blasted out of the mid-2000's with all that made people love those kinds of shooters but took with it none of the baggage. It has an active community, active moderators and active developers. For how long? Who can know.

But the fact of the matter is that you can plug in, play as your favorite Section 9 operator and blast people away with spectacular cyborg giblets littering your screen, great in short bursts or for extended play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An Early Access, Nexon-published shooter based on a twenty-year-old anime license. This is going to be awful, right?

Wrong.

First Assault is one of the most potentially-awesome Early Access games I've played. It's incredibly polished for a free-to-play title, it feels great to shoot stuff. Sound design is great, with a little wind-up for emphasis on kill effects. Accomplishing stuff feels really satisfying every time. Most of the special skills are really fun to use, as well. Maps look and play well, with lots of ways to flank and clear even in some of the narrow corridors.

The key to success is effective timing of the rechargeable skills, and good communication among team members. Matches are very fast, with most lasting ten minutes tops, and some very decided ones lasting under two minutes. You'll get to use Tier 1 skills maybe eight or so times a match on average, and Tier 2 skills usually won't happen more than three. Five if you're pretty much MVP. Many of them can be shared with your teammates, and planning to have an army of armored or invisible players can be a game-changer.

The game is definitely not finished at the time of writing; teams don't auto-balance and there is no way to switch teams in-game. With the smallish player pool, newbies can be placed against the best of the best, and matches are more often than not pretty one-sided due to one or two team members who are way out of everyone else's league. There's a limited selection of equipment, with only two side-arms, three throwables, and one melee weapon. Glitches do happen, though they're rarely game-breaking.

If you're not great at these kinds of games, you're going to have a bad time your first few matches, before you start to be able to coordinate. If you're good at ADS shooters already, there isn't going to be a big issue coming to this; the only things to learn are really the maps and skills, and you'll be able to pick that up pretty quickly.

There are currently no paid-for items in the market; all can be bought with time. This is definitely going to change once the game goes free-to-play, and the review will be updated when that happens.

If the problems with matchmaking and team balance aren't fixed by the time this game is released, it's going to get a negative. For now, though, this is a FPS I keep coming back to, and it deserves more testers and feedback in the forums to grow.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Extremely polished for early access.  Very tight shooter mechanics although bullet spread, hip fire, spray and burst fire feel mildy different to other shooters and take a little getting used to.  Weapons have an effective range and using COD, Counter Strike or Battlefield style shooting felt like it was random at first who would win, me or the enemy.  But getting used to this games spray and burst fire mechanics has much improved my kills based on skill rather than RNG bullet spray.
Fantastic balance and choices for the sake of gameplay.  Grenades are much more tactical use because of good design decisions, not just throw over a wall and hope you get a kill.  The different character skills and sharing of skills add a lot of fun to the games, no abilities feel outright overpowered although 1 or 2 characters feel slightly underwhelming.

This game oozes with Ghost in the Shell atmosphere, they have everything spot on to capture the feel of the series.  Character models are reasonable respresentations of the series characters although Paz and Borma are a little different to what I would expect.  In game though the characters tend to have some form of head gear on so this becomes irrelevant.  They seem to have got the original (English) voice actors for the characters or VERY good copy cats, I can't tell you how much this adds to the atmosphere, hearing Aramaki over the radio or the team characters voice commands and info during battles is awesome for fans.

Progression feels good without feeling gimped in the early game, my main concern being income later on in the game once leveling doesn't happen as fast.

There are 3 game modes, standard TDM, a counter strike Bomb/Difuse which plays well and a mode, called Terminal Conquest, involving capturing points and pushing to the victory capture.  The new mode involves Tachikoma spawning on the side that captures the points and this adds a lot of fun to the mode.  The voice of the Tachikoma as it runs in to help the team had me grinning from ear to ear.

The game needs new maps in it's future and I was dissapointed most weapons seem to be modern world weapons rather than GITS universe weapons.  That said the weapons are gorgeous and come with lots of customization options that midly affect how the weapon feels.  All the staples are in there, snipers, SMGs, ARs, and shotguns.
Snipers don't dominate any map but I've seen them used well and most maps have certain points where snipers are ideal.  Most combat is close quarters or medium range.
Normal progression from playing will get you a standard armoury of weapons that aren't inferior.  There are also weapons that are more expensive but can all be completely bought with in game currency that is earnt from playing.  From testing so far they are balanced with the cheaper progression weapons.

Free to Play summary.  It isn't a pay 2 win format.  It's a pay to collect or for cosmetics.  Leveling up initially gets you a decent amount of currency and by level 5 you can have 3 of the characters for free.  Actually playing games gives a low amount of currency but there are bonuses from logging in which I'm not sure right now how much it will help.  This is similar to games like hearthstone where grinding by playing constantly isn't really viable but unlike HS you can quickly get a viable loadout that isn't underpowered.  Hopefully there wont be power creep with introduced weapons and characters.
If you want to experience all characters and weapons expect to have to sink some money in to the game as I can't see you being able to earn enough to experience everything without undying endurance and no job.  However this is a more than fair format for the company earning from their game.  Getting the most appealling characters and loadout you may want is VERY achieveable within a reasonable amount of time.

I expect to be playing this game for quite some time and am extremely excited for future content unlike other recent shooters I have tried.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IF YOU'VE COME THIS FAR TO CHECK REVIEWS

BUY THE GAME, IT'S WORTH IT.

I am a Graphic Designer who grew up being inspired by Ghost in The Shell, Akira, BladeRunner and a bunch of other Cyberpunk projects. If I'm not creating, then I'm PC gaming to kill off time and enjoy Quick-fun, Team-based shooters or RPG's. I'm currently waiting for Deus Ex: Mankind Divided and needed a fun Cyber-punk Stylized Online-First Person Shooter to keep me entertained and up my mouse/keyboard skills. This is it, and although it's not a bad thing, the game keeps me coming back for more hours and keeps me excited to receive the content that's on the way! Despite some of the art and lore not resembling the anime, it's more than enough to keep fans of the franchise intrigued and entertained. Even for gamers who aren't fans of the franchise, the presentation and sound, along with the particular art-style surrounding the maps and character models give off a sense of originality.

Gameplay is fast paced and gets the adrenaline going, especially when you and your team of 7 players sync up individual Augmentations (Abilities, perks) to either push in a specific direction, or split up for flanking tactics. There is a class for every type of playstyle and they all compliment each other really well and create some very exciting scenarios that help you feel like a bad ♥♥♥ almost effortlessly.

It's still a work in progress with developers allowing feedback and responses by next month, and requires a few tweaks to the gameplay and team balancing, but for what it is at it's current state, I'd say give it a try. My fanboy furturism fanatic side would tell you to BUY IT NOW! It's well worth the $4.99 and definitely well worth the $8.99. Plenty of grinding and quick unlockables depending on your experience with the game and skill. Currently not Pay to Win and hopefully won't dive into that category too strongly.

Add xMachina if you end up purchasing the early access! My keyboard and mouse skills have gotten so much better playing this xD. Currently dominating with an SMG/Speed-Augmentation class that allows me to flank quickly whenever my team is held off or cornered. Happy gaming.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wait for the free release unless you want to beta test this game.

Is the core gameplay fun?  Yes.

Modern coutner-strike style gunplay meets fun class based team oriented strategy.  Using skill sync to give your entire team invisibility or sight through walls and then rush the bomb site feels incredibly rewarding and allows for great comebacks and unexpected plays.  However, the gunplay is significantly hampered by the stat based gun upgrade system that makes shooting slightly random (and spray very random) unless you upgrade the relevant stats.  I kind of like this though because the game relies much more on team work and using your abilities effectively, rather than simply sniping the other guy first.  If you sit in one spot and try to snipe you are gauranteed to get picked off by the myriad of abilities available.

Is a lot of the launcher infrastructure broken?  Very obviously yes.
You are supposed to get a free character unlock at level 3 and level 5.  I did not get an unlock at level 5.  There are various obvious spelling errors (Impact Dempener, Anti-Machin Launcher).  The cyborg upgrades that you (sometimes) get after matches are either woefully useless (reload while sprinting, wait I can already do that right?) or totally over powered (20% increased strafe speed + 10% movement speed gives you a HUGE peek advantage).  And they don't give you these random upgrades often enough, so you will run out if you try to actually use them.

Beyond that the game just has general balance issues as you would expect.  The rocket launcher ability at level 2 can instantly kill the tank that spawns in the tank mode.  If someone on your team saves their rocket for this you never even have to deal with the tank...

However, I'm going to recommend.  Because it is in fact a lot of fun when you get past the early access issues.  And if they can fix some of the launcher bugs and balance the game a bit more I can see it being a really fun game by release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex - First Assault Online is a First-Person Shooter set in the Ghost in the Shell universe from Nexon, a company well known for Pay 2 Win schemes and titlkes that will leave many infuriated with the levels of crap that would otherwise be thrust upon them. However, so far it seems that the game is taking a more CS:GO like approach in that your money is more apt to be spent on cosemtic features, such as skins. Thus, the equipment is earned via in-game currency given out after matches and when you level up, which appears, so far, to even things out. In a way, this system is resemblent of a Call of Duty progression system.

A team based shooter, it offers several team-play modes and a more basic Team Deathmatch mode. Players can choose to play as characters from the GitS:SAC series, each of which has a special ability that offers some variety in gameplay. Even in a TDM setting, some of these skills encourage players to stick together and work together to beat the enemy team. This is enforced by some abilites allowing multiple allies to sync up" and share an ability (Such as Motoko's disguise ability)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As someone who has yet to watch Ghost in the Shell but has always been drawn into the overall aesthetic the series seems to provide, I figured I'd try this game. $5, an online FPS. Why not? To say I'm absolutely shocked with how fun this is would be an understatement.

The game itself feels like a mix of your standard MMS style shooter (CoD, Battlefield) but with a slight class based system very similar to what is seen in Dirty Bomb. In fact I'd go as far as to call this a Sci-Fi Dirty Bomb with what I'd say is a bit more weighty movement. It feels really REALLY nice. There also seems to be a big focus on going for headshots as well so it's a nice test of skill at times. Body shots kill but headshots absolutely destroy. Like we're talking 2 bullets vs 15 bullets. Getting kills feels super rewarding. It's not exactly counter-strike but it's a pretty nice change of pace compared to most shooters in this style.

As it stands right now there are only 3 modes. You have your standard TDM, a capture point mode (one point) & another mode called Demolition which I haven't played yet but it seems to be your standard team elimination/bomb defusal deal (someone correct me if I'm wrong on that). I have mainly stuck to TDM as that is what feels like the game is designed around. Everything flows quite well with it, it's a rarity that I find TDM to be the best mode in a shooter but GITS just feels good with that mode.

The games skillsets for each operative is decently varied going from camo, super armor, faster running speeds & the likes. What is really cool with it how some of these abilities have a tier system. If you build up your points enough you can use a tier 2 ability which will allow you to share your ability with other team mates which means you can potentially be invisible with super armor. It opens up quite a few possibilities with a coordinated team. I really dig that.

Monetization wise there isn't much to speak of right now, the store has practically nothing in it and from what I can tell it's all in game credits. Obviously this will change once the game becomes open to everyone.

Map Variety isn't great (just not enough of them, you'll see all of them within an hour) and they are plagued with some bad spawns at times. It's not game breaking but you will have a ton of Wait...really I spawned here?" sort of moments after a few hours of play. It's not Battlefront Beta or Spawning on Nuketown with a Chopper Gunner above you bad but it can be a bit off putting at times.

One of the most welcomed features in this game is the ability to hotkey your aim sensitivity which is something I never knew I wanted until now. You can actually just changed your sensitivity as you're running around in game. Press a button and change it up. This is super useful for those who always change classes or need to make fine adjustments every game depending on how they are playing. I now wish every game has this built in
date: it's an awesome feature. The one big glaring omission is a field of view slider. Thankfully the default seems to be pretty good (around 80 or 90 if I had to guess) and as someone who typically gets motion sickness in most first person games from low FoV this one has yet to bother me. It's still inexcusable that this is missing.\n\nOh
recommended: and performance is great. Maxed out on a GTX970/4790k I'm pushing just over 150FPS without an issue. There is seemingly no lag in game either. This game just performs fantastic. I can see this scaling on lower end machines quite well.\n\nOverall
hoursPlayed: even for those not familiar with the series this is just a nice fun shooter. For those who are in the market for something casual that takes just a bit more skill than your average shooter or the person that wants a less objective focused Dirty Bomb this if for you. If you're looking for something revolutionary that approaches modern FPS in a very different manner look away."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well time for my review, having 41.9 hrs in game, I can see ive seen almost every nook and cranny.And I want to help you folks make a good decision. So lets Start with the good.

PRO's:

- Good options of custimization of what guns/attachments you want, while also delivering on the character front as well.
- As stated its a Fast actioned FPS (given the severs are balanced/enough players) and can be very fun to play
- Theres No true overpowerful gear, all players are on a fairly equal battleground
- Quick time getting into games
- In game layout is very Nice to look at, not very cluttered at all
- It could go far in terms of F2P Shooters

So now the

CON's: (first off tho, these are mild cons, and tbh its like nit-picking)

- Hit registration and Spread

Hmm I've seen a lot of people bring this up, so here's my 2 pence (yes I'm British ;)) . First off, when ADS the bullets need to go where the iron sight/red dot is going, it can just fling off in a random direction. yes if the weapon has recoils the bullet indication should go where the red dot goes. so lets say the M4A1 has kicks to the upper right, the red dot sight in screen goes to the upper right, rather than staying still and having your gun spraying in ADS.

- Nano Gel - Broma (A Operator you can chose)

Okay, now before I start, I've used it, and man its....unbalancing to say the least. Yes you can aim for head shots, but like pointed out above, unless you are within a certain rage, that's incredibly hard. and the regen on teir 2, is a little insane. You can also try to outnumber him, that works too, but when this buff is shared with the enemy team, its kinda, just a way to make the game incredibly frustrating. Unlike other skills Like the Hyper-sprint, or Cloak, its not good, it doesn't make you so Over powerful, it just give you a little bonus.

- Terminal Conquest. (like Domination, except one point atcive at a time, and you fight for that node)

First off I love this mode...when its balanced, and there's no broma's (look above for Borma/Steam rolling). So whats wrong with this mode, well for every game ive been in, its hard to gain back a point/lead, once the first terminal is taken. So what causes this? For me its the points given for securing a node/bits of teir XP gained from either ally kills/capping Not sure what it is, but I get little bits of teir for doing F**k all) and this really encourages steam rolling. The think tank however is fine, nice mechanic, but I don't like the here's the hacker mechainc" just make the hacker immobile while hacking.

- GP/XP (money and in game experince)

Now while XP should be harder to get when you level

reviewText:
Early Access Review

GHOST IN THE SHELL VIDYA GAME [vibrating intensifies]
Fanboying aside, this is a pretty solid online rooty-tooty-point-and-shooty. Equipment and cosmetic options are still very limited, but hopefully this will improve at/before release.
The skills and skillsync mechanic are both really interesting additions to what would otherwise be a pretty standard shootbang game, and they give players a vital edge against unprepared opponents.
My only real gripe is that you cannot cook grenades, and they have a really dodgy timer window. This makes them more or less useless unless you catch an enemy in a corner with one.
Also, Togusa's revolver when?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Surprisingly fun! I love GITS - and I really expected the game to be subpar. I hesitated to buy into it until today. Im glad I did - as some have said, its basically your standard fare for team based shooters - but utilizes its GITS flare very well. The voice acting, the thematic elements, sfx, Tachikoma(!!), it just all fits together well. The controls feel a little stiff at first - but you get used to it. The TTK can be fast but isnt near instant like CoD tends to be - ie: its a little more forgiving to less skilled players - and thats a good thing - because a game should be about fun right?

I also like how there are traditional 'level up' unlocks, along with ingame earned currency purchases of gear. So you have two avenues to aquire new toys instead of *only* unlocking as you level. The concept of implants you earn that slowly burn out is interesting as well - make em count!

Overall, I didnt think it was going to be as enjoyable as it has turned out to be. If you like GITS and you like shooters - you cant really go wrong here ;)

Edits for spelling.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before I start I should say that Team PvP games are typically not my kind of game.  I do play them from time to time, but I grow tired of them quickly.

Pros:
- It's Ghost in the Shell themed.
- There are a decent amount of weapons to choose from but I'd expect more to be added as the game goes on.
- The Quick Match option was great.  It either put me in a game in progress or added me to a Waiting Room with others to select a Match.
- The shareable skills were very awesome.
- I could select from a list of weapons to work on unlocking next.

Cons:
- I could not select which Mods to unlock next on my weapons.
- Some weapons (like the 870 shotgun you can unlock) have no Mods to unlock or purchase while others have very few.  I hope that these will be added as the game goes live.

If you like Team PvP and Ghost in the Shell, then I think that this game is worth your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok so I now have a little over 20 hrs of ingame time and feel like I can post a quick review.
So how do I feel about this game so far?.... well its a lot of fun but also so very frustrating at the same time.

So here are some quick pros and cons:

Pros+
+Game starts off at $5
+Match times are really quick even in demolition mode
+Have the ability to customize weapons even though at this point its limited
+Weapons are NOT behind a paywall for now, so all players can grind the GP points to unlock rather then pay $$$
+global events really help with the xp grind and gp income at early levels
+Get to play as some of you favorite Ghost in the Shell Characters
+Servers are generally good (I use American Empire East)
+The weapon and voice sounds are generally good

Cons+
-From the game trailer and sreen shots thought the game was going to include a story mode
-Weapon accuracy for the most part is garbage unless you are using a sniper rifle
-Player balancing mechanic is a joke, one team usually gets the high lvl players while the other most of the lowere lvls
-ammount of xp you get from team deathmatch is very underwhelming compared to demolition and terminal game types
-some of the operatives abilities feel overpowered compared to others which makes them the predominant choce/oppenent instead of a more balanced approach
-operatives are locked behind paywall, would much rather do the gp grind to unlock all operatives (yes I know you get two additional for free at lvls 3 and 5)


As the game continues to get patched I will add/change the pros and cons and mabbey my feel for the game (hopefully less frustration and more fun), but as of right now I would reccomend it to others just beacuse overall its a fun game especially if you like the anime and just want to play as the Section 9 team.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell was quite a unique IP for its time, melding elements of sci-fi with philosophical concepts and well-developed characters. In particular, it developed a gritty, almost film noir style of narrative punctuated by some very nice tactical and action sequences. This game is a callback to that world, with many of the recognizable characters, weapons, and abilities wrapped up in a counterstrike reminescent package.

GitS: First Assault draws a lot of positive inspiration from counterstrike; well-balanced maps and weapons, some of the fun gamemodes, and even some of the UI. The game is a joy to play and relatively stable as far as FPS netcode goes. Like counterstrike, twitch reflexes are second to good situational awareness (I have a decided lack of both). Despite this, I really enjoyed gameplay and found that both objective control and run & gun strategies were viable.

The abilities bring a unique twist to the counterstrike formula and I was really surprised that they weren't overpowered. Somehow they're all useful in any gamemode, and there's no huge reason to choose one over the other. Matoko's tactical camouflage is true to its appearance in the anime and while noticeable, it's just transparent enough that distracted enemies don't spot you as you run to cover or past them.

There isn't solely praise to be said; the launcher began crashing when I entered my login details a few times without having registered. I had to verify/repair the game's data to fix the problem. When your client falls out of sync with the game state, hit boxes don't align properly and enemy players teleport (not by enough to be noticed while aiming). These issues are sporadic and you can learn to see when it begins happening, but it can be jarring the first time another player eats 2 full clips of ammo and doesn't take damage.

There is a very nice in-universe excuse for the tutorial, and although the tutorial is effective, I did find one glitch; the portion that had me throwing grenades was not letting me pass. It turns out the grenades were not doing any damage to the NPCs that spawned; I had to kill them with the pistol before they began to take grenade damage properly.

Think tanks are a little bit too resilient, but Batou has a skill that makes short work of them. I think they rightfully have a lot of health, but I feel that hacking them to weaken their armour takes a very long time. Perhaps it would be good to see if hacking them twice as fast will help with this?

There also seem to be a few players capable of actually hacking the game. In one round, a player equipped with the melee weapon seemed to be jumping a distance of 20 ft. There was also a player getting constant one-hit kill headshots with a silenced weapon near spawn, but that could very well have been skill. Hacking seems uncommon, thankfully. In this game, good use of abilities can really help to catch opponents off-guard, so there's a viable answer that more or less equalizes the playing field.

The interface and audio were fairly good, and despite using dialogue by characters, it isn't done to the point of being annoying. The jumping and climbing animations feel clunky, but perhaps that's the intention. Melee is fairly hard to do because a player's instinct is to click it within arm's reach of the opponent. Instead, it activates when you are practically hugging them, so it's remarkably difficult to get melee. One of my opponents tried for a minute while I simply walked out of the petit range. I then mercilessly shot him down.

Although it isn't without criticism, First Assault is very fun and integrates many elements of GitS story well. I'm looking forward to playing this one more. Nexon has some bugs to crush and one or two things to balance, but I definitely recommend the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of now (5/2/2016 ) in early access:

Good:
- You play as GITS team members, including a new female: Maven.
- Close quarter, quick battles. If you love CoD like gameplay, you may like this.
- 3 typical I've-seen-it-all modes, though more may come in future.
- Guns sound and feel solid.
- 2-tier level abilities for each class. Batou has more armor, Motoko has cloaking, Maven has a placeable shield, and so on.
- Small but existing reward system that gives bonus xp or items after each map.
- Weapons unlock as you play more. Though you can purchase them directly using in-game virtual currency or of course, the mandetory currency gained from real money. The in-game currency is given after every level up. So far I've seen it giving me 50k/level up.
- Explosion causes damage to the body and you will find severed heads and limbs after an explosive encounter.
- Augmentation system for physical enhancements (i.e. Faster side-stepping). This allows for slight adjustment to your movements, reload speed, etc for combat advantage.

Bad:
- NO support class to provide ammo. Though this may change if the game mode dictates in future.
- All guns can pretty much one shot you from any distance if you manage to land a headshot. Kind ruins the purpose of PDW and long-range weapons.
- Dying behind wall...is back. Though to some extent, far less evident compared to BF4's nightmarish issue.
- No environmental effects. It feels dead and boring.
- Only 7v7 match so far. Does 16 sound ominous, let alone 32?

Food for thought:
- This is year 2029 (if you take the anime timeline) and technologically humans have gone so far ahead, still we are using AK and M4? Where is the creativity with guns and concepts? They already veered off significantly in terms of gameplay mechanics, why not go with guns as well? They do use some real-world guns in the anime, but why stick with that, when you could tweak the design and add more fictional components to the weapons?
- All except Togusa are cyborgs. You should be able to jump high, land from great height, do feats that are otherwise not feasible for humans, yet most of those are not present.
- As a cyborg, you have extra strength, yet you don't carry extra ammo or more than two weapons (excluding melee). GITS is famous for hacking and diving into networks, but you don't get to dive into network or hack modules/turrets.

Overall I think it's a good FPS game, but certainly no where near what GITS stands for. They just took the rights to use the setting/characters to make an FPS where the gist of the game got lost. If you are a serious fan of GITS, you will be disappointed, as I am. Just treat the game as if it's not GITS, but another generic shoot-and-level-up FPS, and perhaps you may enjoy it a bit more. Combat is solid but without fully utilizing the tech from the related universe, this feels bland.

Now let's hope they make an RPG GITS. Finger crossed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hello guys, low-life gamer here.
Going to give an honest review or rather a first look about this game.

Now first of all we do all need to remember this is not the full release and anything can and will be changed if necessary.
Also side-note, I like to write a lot so bear with me.

Starting off with my playing time, not much time I spent on the game so I am giving a first look with the free weekend, as my curse is not being able to be near my computer at weekends I was only able to get a short glance at the game and make suggestions, cheap person as I am, I only purchase games that I really want for like a year or so or if I can afford the game, since this is going free to play (hopefully) I hope I won't need to purchase anything.

So let's begin with the good stuff:

This game is unique, feels a bit like Dirty Bomb, but still a bit of freshness to the gaming genre.
Graphics and animations are also noticeable to be made with quality.
It reminds me of War Rock for some reason, god I loved that game, do a remaster of that game without cheaters and a new engine and count me in, that game was a blast for me, now unfortunately it's decaying.
It has classes each one being unique, also it seems to have a damage model that is pretty realistic, few shots and you're down, melee animations look great, I myself didn't notice any hit detection problems but if they are there, they should be fixed indeed. Actually all animations were great and all, HUD was looking pretty nice as well. In short it could be a pretty solid shooter. Also the game is quite small, well at least at the moment, so it's a pretty much 1-2 minute download and play, of course depending on the internet speed the person has.

Now on to the part I didn't like that much:

Specifications needed to run this game, are you sure you are right on with those? I don't see this game requiring much above an i3 if even that, yet an i5 2500 is in the recommended list, might want to lower that a little, the graphics aren't bad but they don't look THAT demanding, neither is it open world what would require a lot of processing power.
Secondly, framerate - While I myself have a pretty high-tier computer, I would expect the game to run very fast but for some reason it feels like it's under a framerate lock even with vsync off, does not matter if it's on low, medium or high, not saying it's unplayable but the trailers you guys do run a lot faster with 60 frames while I myself don't get that feeling exactly or maybe it's just me.
Also, moving feels a bit clunky somehow, it does not really bother me, but it could be a bit polished.
Other than that I don't have much to complain about on this first look.

Suggestions:

This is a class based game, class based games work well in CO-OP, would love to see CO-OP here, not a generic stale zombie survival (of course it can be there still as an extra), but actual CO-OP missions, if a team executes it well on a hard settings they could be rewarded their own way, also while doing CO-OP they could familiarize with their classes more and use them more effectively in Player versus Player rooms.
Bigger maps would be a lot nicer, also if you do plan on CO-OP you could make tactical insertion points, like how to breach some place to keep the mission interesting. Right now the maps feel a bit Call of Duty like, I got all these fun gadgets to use, yet I get mowed down in a choke point.
Lastly, indeed some classes could use a fix, for example Motoko's cloak or what you call it, could have less visibility when you execute the cloak, when you skill sync the cloak with someone else it could remain at the same visibility level.
Also one big suggestion would be leaning, so many times I see good cover with little use, I don't know how others would react to this but I would like leaning for more tactical viewpoints and firefights.

This is pretty much it at this first look, would be nice to play more and experience more, but free weekends don't last forever. Overall this game has potential and I am interested to see what it becomes into.

If you read all this text until this part, you deserve a reward. Thanks for taking your time to read.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Mind you this is review was based on the early access game as it was available on a F2P weekend.

I loved the movies, series and everything to do with the entire universe of Ghost in the Shell, I decided to give the game a go during its free to play weekend deal. It has a lot of call outs to the anime series, using the same voice actors for the Major, Batou etc. However thats where anything to do with the universe ends. I played it for awhile and genuinely had fun and enjoyed running and gunning, but there were little things that I noticed that I wasn't to fond of.

The quick and dirty:
The game feels a little clunky in the controls, looks and sounds great. Provides a cheap run and gun experience however the damage system is basically aim for the head as you won't do damage elsewhere. Its entertaining but don't expect more than that.

Gameplay:
Its by and far a standard FPS with a couple of other elements. Its fun and engaging, punishing and fast paced. Bullet damage seems to be way underpowered to anywhere that isn't the head. Any shot to the head is a garunteed one hit kill. Moving on from that, the skills used by the individual 'classes' or in this case characters, are recharged over time and gained by getting kills. They're all pretty basic; theres invisibility, increased damage resistance, super sprint, an invisibility sheath. Some of these can be shared with up to three teammates, and some just get powered up when they reach tier 2. This was pretty cool I thought and really encourages team play or at least being near your teammates. The leveling system seems sluggish, you unlock equipment for your gear buy using it but it comes slow, I didn't unlock anything for any of the weapons I was using while playing. I had to buy stuff to get optics or silencers. You also get in game currency which allows you to buy them from the marketplace; this includes new weapons. The currency you win from matches comes slow, so you can't run one match and then buy one of the better guns in the game. Another thing with the guns is oh my god the recoil. Aiming down the sights is a nightmare and really teaches you to burst fire instead of going full auto. Not necessarily a negative point, but it does take some getting used to. Theres a limited number of maps and with the map voting system it just seems like I was playing the same ones over and over. Some maps have fixed spawn points for each team, some maps have moving spawn points. One final thing to mention is that shotguns are horrendously overpowered in this game.
When I was starting up the game I was hoping for a small team based co-op game involving AI and stealth missions rather than this run and gun FPS.

Universe:
Sure its called Ghost in the Shell, sure it has the characters and voice actors, but beyond that it doesn't feel like the universe at all. Theres no futuristic weaponry; all the weapons in game are just modified modern weapons to look futuristic. The maps and settings have no GITS feel to them, you could copy and paste them into any other sci-fi shooter and it wouldn't make a difference. So far theres nothing with the tachikomas other than you see them in one map being worked on. The only thing this game holds onto in the universe is the characters.

It'll be interesting to see where they go with the game. Again this is early access but who knows what the final product would be. I'd recommend it for a cheap FPS shooter game, but don't expect the world of it.

Pros-The guns feel pretty balanced.
-SkillSyncs (Abilities that each character has) don't feel overpowered.
-Graphics aren't that bad, I was able to play on an intergrated graphics card.
-The game is easy to pick up on.


Cons-Some things they need to fix on is the random recoil spread.
-Movement feels sluggish.
-There is a fixed spawnpoint for each team. Spawn killing may become a problem, though I have never witnessed anything like that during my playthrough.
-No health regeneration. That's fine, but there needs to be an ammo drop or a medpack when you kill an enemy.

ConclusionThe gameplay isn't groundbreaking, but it's nice to find a F2P FPS game that feels similar to COD. IMO, don't buy into Early Access, just wait until the free launch.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me preface this: I hate CS:GO. I love this game. Why? Because it brings tears to my eyes to see my favorite anime so correctly translated into an FPS. The voice acting is spot on, the graphics are immediately nostalgic and the gameplay, while a little buggy (It's an alpha, what do you expect?) is fun. The characters all feel well represented and communicate frequently with eachother during a match, making it feel like you're ACTUALLY playing as the character of your choice.

On a side note, the progression system is a little slow. The only Heavy Machine Gun in the entire game (Currently as of this review) was locked behind a HUGE grind wall of 400+ TP (You earn anywhere from 0-18 a match). I finally unlocked it and I'll say this flat out: This game does what Warframe never did. Make guns feel like GUNS. Recoil. Stability. Effective weapon range. All are dealt with fairly well.

The servers aren't perfect and I could swear I've seen a few lopsided matches, but the game is fun and easily worth the small price of admission.

Gun/5
