reviewText:
Early Access Review

A decent team-based FPS. It looks very nice, plays fast and smoothly. Levels are well-planned and do a great job of approximating the pen and gouache look of the background art in the GITS anime. The character models look good and it sounds like they employed the same voice actors from the Bandai English dub of the anime, which is nice.

The character animations, however, are just so-so. Player movements sometimes appear unnnautral, and the tachikomas and tanks move about in a ridicuolusly herky-jerky fashion and clip through the environment a lot.

The team matching system seems fair enough, but the weapons are a little unbalanced and hits vs misses seem to be somewhat randomized, which is frustrating. The mechanism for switching guns leaves something to be desired within the heat of battle.

The SkillSync idea shows promise, but the way they're implemented just comes off as gimmicky. The ability to suddenly acquire an uncharacteristic new skill is kind of fun, but it's ultimately pointless from a tactical perspective. Lacking any mechanism for working out a collective strategy, you just end up with a bunch of teammates randomly employing the same ability for no coherent purpose.  It also tends to result in players of the same team ganging up together, apparently just so they can get in on the next shared skill.

I'd certainly recommend this game if you're a GITS fanboy or fangirl who really loves team FPS games like Counterstrike. For $5, go ahead and knock yourself out. It's a fun way to kill a few hours, but I wouldn't pay more than $20 for it.

But to be honest I was expecting something a lot more intriguing from a GITS game. I would really like to have seen some Deus Ex-type tactical skills? Maybe something that actually requires strategy, like having some players run defense and protection while another player jacks into the network for some kind of hacking minigame that leaves them vulnerable? Instead of the hackneyed old bomb defusing plot with the countdown timer, maybe you have the team taking down a mainframe or commandeering some automated systems? Maybe some form of cyberbrain hacking to infiltrate and sabotage, like the spy in Team Fortress? I'm obviously just spitballing here...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex is an interesting, though somewhat flawed take on the FPS genre. Overall, its mechanics and gunplay feel very solid. There is something of a grind to obtaining new weapons and modifications for weapons, but it generally isn't so significant as to prevent an average player from obtaining them over a stretch of time.

By far the biggest issue has to be the netcode, which seems very unreliable past 70-100 ping. While I was able to maintain a good ping while on the east-coast server, when I switched to the west coast server to join some friends, the hit registration was noticeably worse, and several shots that seemed like they would hit didn't connect. Additionally, when my ping spiked to a bit over 70, I noticed similar issues on the east coast server. While this is anecdotal, it did seem to be an issue for me, but if you can keep your ping to <50 or so, I, at least, didn't notice any issues.

In summary, 7/10, a decent first-person shooter and one that is worth sinking a bit of time into, but not revolutionary, and with some netcode that (seemingly) works well only under good, but not average/slightly below average conditions.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played early access before the days of steam and felt it was a good start. They never reinvited me despite all testers from that wave were reinvited so I didn't care to take it back up.

After playing it the past 24 hours (8.2 on record at the time so I gave it a chance) I must say the changes, if any, were subtle.

Cons:
*Money/exp is grindy but what game isn't? Also gives emphasis on cash shop but that isn't here (yet).
*Only proper way to define it is 'glory kills' from Doom(4). You can mouse2 an enemy and basically execute them, however you are left standing there soaking all bullets or waiting to get chained. Think taunt kill in Team Fortress 2 but the only reason why you use melee.
*Gun spread. Sure you heard of it but once you actually try to play with it you almost wonder what is the point in trying to scope in? If your first shot isn't a headshot (which btw any gun will 1 hit kill with a headshot) then you hold the fire button until one of you dies.
*Abilities are extremly restricted. Each agent of Sec9 has their own perks, you unlock those perks by unlocking that character. You cannot change characters during a match and you have to buy unlock licenses in order to get more. You can pay-to-progress this with NX or grind out 100s of thousands of gp.
*Range of Effectiveness is a lie (for the most part). I have seen the assault rifles have the range of effectiveness applied to them but it almost appears as if Shotguns / Sub-machine guns do not have them. People appear to be more accurate from mid-long range with smg than I am single / burst firing with AK-47 specd for stability/accuracy.

[]Pointless Concepts found in this game (chop this up as basically 'Super Cons'):
*AP (armor points): What is the point if only one Sec9 Agent can regenerate health but not armor? Seems like it doesn't do good since most die in 3-4 shots.
*Grenade Warning Icon: Why have it if it phases into the UI behind you?
*Glory Kill" melee system: just let me humiliate someone by killing them
date:
not make a spectical out of it
*Agent Upgrades via Chip System: hardly any of them make a direct impact short of reload / movement / aiming
*Respawning: classic Call of Duty: Modern Warfare+ respawning where you spawn at random places (save for 2 maps or any game mode that isnt Tdm)
*Dead allies still talking: thats right! your fallen comrads will still talk as if they are still alive
recommended:
despite missing a head.
*Lack of voice-chat: no need for that right? only team-based shooter [no free for all]

There is a ton more
hoursPlayed:
but basically I have better things to do.

TLDR:
Combat Arms with a Ghost in the Shell License. If you arn't good at aiming with scope and just hold left click then you will do well.

To Developers:
Doing the same thing Doom Open Beta did to the public: showcasing only what the bare minimum of 'finished' content you have. Give us something to hope for
voteText: not another cash grab."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Overall a good, addicting online FPS.  Get it if you always wanted a CS:GO and Team Fortress 2 hybrid. There are problems but couple of fixes and optimisation will make this game work like a clock. GITS lisence will atract attention but it's not neceserraly a good thing.

First off I'd like to talk about what I feel about the anime, I liked the original movie because of it's philosopy, not neceserally because of the cyber terrorism stuff. I never had any interest to watch Stand Alone Complex because Ghost in the Shell was over for me when the original movie rolled its credits. The point was made, the story was told and trying to make anything else in the GITS universe would feel redundant for me. Imagine if the movie Her had a sequel, Ex-Machina, Interstellar, Inception, Akira had a sequel, GITS sequels feel the same for me. Just like Terminator 3 and the rest of the movies. The story was told and the point was made in T2. Conclusion; I don't really like the setting of this game that much.

Now to the game; It's a great online action FPS with specialized classes and varied weapons and mods. Shooting experience is really good, music is good, atmospehere is good, maps are a little small but well designed. Game modes we have for now are TDM, Demo and Conquest. Only demo feels like GITS, other modes are just run and gun than respawn style modes, in Conquest camping will give you KDR, rushing will make your team win.

Although variety of operatives are appreciated, some are extremely overpowered and some are reall underpowered. For example; There is a guy with litteraly invurnerablity" skill

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Decent Game had a great time playing it, one of NExons finest to be sure only a few problems i have found:
- There's a toggle for aim (hold or tap to aim) but no toggle for running, Ilike to sprint in my FPS  games without having to hold so i have access to other buttons.
-Spawns could be better, group spawning is very annoying especially when an enemy has an arm launcher.
- Cramped Spawns: A more spreaded spawn so teammates are placed in more of an arc and less of a cluster would be much better since a few of the maps spawns are by far waaaaaay too cramped , you cant escape with some maps if someone sets up a sentry and racks in the kills.
Now onto positives
This is definitely not a Pay to play game I was a low level myself (didnt play for too long) and killed quite a few highly ranked enemies myself customisation is GREAT and weapons are reasonably priced and dont have a time limit on them- (im looking at you Blacklight and Warface) , for now at least its a pretty even game characters are pretty even with no true OP characters as weapons arent chracter locked (besides arm launcher).

Overall great game community isnt toxic and admins are ever so nice if your a bit skeptical give it a try at release if its one think that ill give it credit for its for being different with more a team apporach and makes everyone in the team feel as if they have a purpose.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell is a series that would make a great game, and here we have it! First Assault is a fast paced FPS that features good gunplay and abilities that the player can use and share with their teammates. My review will cover the current iteration of First Assault, as it's currently still in Early Access.

PROS:
-The game is fairly easy to run and didn't cause any problems for my R9 380, it does offer a good amount of settings customization and resolutions.
Though you can pay to advance through the ranks and get faster access to some equipment it doesn't mean that you'll be a better player, the Pay 2 Win thing isn't present here as far as I'm aware.
Gunplay isn't bad and spraying at any range isn't viable, the Mp5 is best suited to close range encounters while the M4 is better at medium to long ranges, as it should be.
Fast paced combat means that you'll be able to rack up huge kill streaks if playing correctly. I never saw any instances of spawn trapping" either

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is very well rounded but it does have a few solid issues that need addressing. Some of those being character related, some weapon-balancing related. I haven't played much of this game, but at first glance, I was not expecting much out of it. I watched a few episodes of the GitS series, and I rather enjoyed them, and I was honestly excited to see this game on Steam.

The Pros:
-Great customization system
-A variety of characters to choose from
-Viable weapons

The Cons:
-Small weapon variety
-Some characters abilities do almost nothing (Motoko's Therm-Optic Camo)
-OP weapons like the 870 ICS

All in all:
I will say that I definately recommend picking this game up, even if you have not watched any of the show. It is a great game to just pick up and play, though some of the weapons need a little bit of a buff (Such as M4A1 or AK47). There also needs to be more weapons added, because at the moment, all anyone is using is either the 870 ICS or the AK47 with an external barrel to make it do an unbelieveable amount of damage (even with body shots). Either way, this is a great game and deserves to be treated as such. Thanks for reading my review and I hope that you found it helpful!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

[13 may 2016 edit]: Still recommended. Still a great game. Still adoring every minute of it. Community is surprisingly good, unlocks are great, skill matters more than weapons, and GP gaining is still quick enough to buy tons of great weapons, though the starting ones are still VERY viable and you can always buy with GP stuff you haven't unlocked. It's just cheaper if you do unlock it seems.

I was skeptical, because Nexon Corp are involved, and I am ALWAYS, ALWAYS cautious about korean MMOs, what with their grinding, pay2win f2p models, and legions and legions of hackers that always seem to turn up just to ruin the entire game. I adored both Gunz and S4 League when they were in beta and weren't saddled with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥zz p2w mechanics and hackers. The moment they actually released? That's when the p2w bs started, and also when the hackers started. It made them abysmal immediately.

So you can imagine how worried I was when I saw one of my most beloved anime franchises turn into an online game published by Nexon. At the behest of a close friend though (who shares my feelings on f2p crapstackery), I gave it a try during the recent free weekend and HOOOLY HELL I was wrong, this game is awesome.

I mean it's balanced, it feels good, you can pay for in game currency (NX i think it's called) but that's purely for weapon skins and character skins by the looks of things (some of which genuinely look really cool actually), and I know this is in Early Access still, but guns and attachments you can purchase with the normal currency earned in game (GP), which you get quite a bit of with each match. Maybe ten matches will be enough to get you the cash necessary to purchase a bunch of attachments. Also levelling up at the start goes really nice and quick so you can unlock more operatives fairly quickly. Again it costs GP to unlock further operatives after that but again you'll earn a fair bit from each match.

There's three game modes: TDM, a TF2 style CP game mode, and what is effectively Counterestrike's default bomb setting game type. All three are fun and have their own unique twists, like the Tachikoma support in the CP mode upon capturing a point, and how you can hack it to lower its defences so you and your team can take it out as fast as possible, balanced by the hacker being always visible on the map so the opposing team can hutn them down to stop this from happening.

Every operative is functionally identical apart from their special skill, half of which can be shared between nearby team-mates (another great unique feature), and all of which have a higher tier mode if you let them charge enough, which buffs their abilities. You can also switch between three loadouts (which you can customise) between respawns, and each one you use earns TP at the end of the match to unlock more attachments and customisation for purchase (again with GP so far, Hope it stays that way!)

Gameplay wise it feels nicely balanced, fast paced, levels are nicely designed without (so far) any annoying chokepoints which favour one side more than the other, and hell it's Ghost in the Shell, what's more to love? It also has a Counterstrike style radar which functions seemingly exactly the same way, and it's a great addition. The HUD is nice, clear and easy to understand, and the contextual actions are clear and easy to understand in a blink.

There's a ton of really great decisions and right now it's free to play, and only £2 to get the basic package to gain you access forever. So why not? Best hurry though, only 10 more hours or so.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TLDR: There are game gameplay balance issues and bugs, but it's overall good for a pre-relase game. Bugs and lack of polish is to be expected. I think it's worth the $5 to try out and see what directions the game makes as development continues.

***

Overall I enjoy playing this game (in it's pre-release status), but there are lots of polish that need to happen before it's released.

Note: I haven't watched Ghost in the Shell yet, although I plan to now. I can't comment on how well it is in that regard.

A few things I've noticed so far:

The gameplay has some unique elements, but still needs more work to stand out from other shooters out there. The hitboxes and damage needs lot of refinement. Basically, you need to pretty much always always shoot for the head. I've emptied a clip from an SMG on an enemy's torso and they managed to survive it, yet pretty much any shots to the head critically wounds them, if not killing them outright, even if you are at full health. The nano-gel ability mitagates this, but only temporarly It's finding these imbalances and learing how to take advantage of them that can make a major difference in surviving.  Until then it can be very frustrating feeling like everyone's killing you so easily and it's difficult for yourself. It took me a few hours to get a feel for the game and then I was able to improve my KDR. Once you find a gun that works well for your playstyle things will be less difficult.

The spawn locations need improvement. I've seen an enemy spawn directly behind our team while assaulting a terminal allowing him to kill several of us. There's also some spawn protection, which is in general good, but made it impossible to take him down for a few seconds. There's been a few times an enemy has spawned a few feet in-game from me or a teammate allowing them to kill us quickly (again, spawn protection).

The melee weapon can be fun to use and it should be even better with the speed and camo/cloaking abilities, but I haven't seen many people actually kill others with the standard attack, but instead always having to use the assasination ability. This ability will show up if you're next to them, even if they see you or you are in front of them. This kills people instantly, but you can't move for the few seconds that it takes to complete. That makes melee mostly useful when using on lone enemies, otherwise while you'll complete the kill all of the other team is shooting at you and you die right away. I think this needs lots of refinement, but will be really fun when it is.

There's also some ocassional bugs and oversights. The cameo power usually works fine, but sometimes you'll see the enemy's name tag near them, making the cloak a bit pointless. There were also a few times I don't think it registered a kill, even if it told me I made it.

The gameplay initally seems to play a lot like Call of Duty, but I've found that you will do best if you keep yourself moving around. Other than a few across the maps, there aren't a whole lot of good places to play as a sniper. A lot of the maps are mostly close quarters to a medium distance. Some of the maps are relatively open while some others are very linear without a lot of choice when it comes to trying to approach a target location.

The player community seems okay so far. Most players get along, but you'll occasionally get the kind of player who racks up lots of kills on a demolition or hacking map and fails to help the team then complains about how horrible the team is. Unless it's team deathmatch it's important everyone's playing ball otherwise you're team fall apart. You can get all the kills and high KDR you want, but it ultimately does nothing if you're not helping your teammates. I suppose every game has these people, but I seem to run into a small select few who keep poping up, and I'd hate to see the player atmosphere devolve into the sort of negative ones that some other FPSs have.

Performance wise it's been pretty consistant at 60fps on my hardware (i7 3770k, GTX 670, 12 GB RAM, SSD, HD). There have had been a few times where the fps will drop near 30 fps for a few seconds and then quickly recover. Fortunitely that has only been two or so times. I've also had some unexpected latency in some matches, where I'd get my usual 30-60 ping then it would jump up to 100-170 for ten minutes. However, I don't know if that's a problem with the servers or just me.

Overall I'd recommend the game. It's far from perfect, but I expect things will improve. If you keep your expectations in check it's certianly worth the $5 (as of this review).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shows a fair amount of Promise. Definitely makes me second guess a number of things, mostly stereotypes. One, that Nexon only imports their garbage titles and they are handled terribly in the east (or buys only cheap, bad titles and publishes them here). Also, that known licenses dont make good games (with a few exceptions). Another would be that EA buy-ins (especially from sketchy publishers known for producing garbage) will not end well. The game is clearly lacking, both in content and in substance. Mostly in content.

Here's hoping by full release they dont do what most companies do and buckle and make some kind of major changes that ruin the game. Not shaping up to be a cash grab either. Another barrier set by stereotypes would be foreign FPS MMO hybrids with lobbies are all the same. GITS:SAC is actually a decent game with the ability to become something truely special if they can dump enough money and time into it and speed up the rather slow development. Since it is EA As it stands:

Graphics: 7

Lasting appeal: 4 (atm) with much promise and intuitive and creative ideas that if kept and implemented correctly will sustain the game alone for years to come. so for that i will say:  6.5

Controls: 7.5

Community: 8.5

Handling/Management of game: 6 atm (but because of it being Nexon and their history i bump to an 8)  8

Updates/patching/ EA development and rollouts: 5.5

Overall: 6.5 as it stands, with easily the promise for an 8 to 8.5 if they do nothing but add more maps and a few promised features. If they really excell it could possibly garner a 9/9.5 even. However, i am still extremely leery with Nexon and have a 75% chance feeling that they are going to ruin the game in one way or another by release or shortly after. Especially if they dont get enough sales...Hopefully they prove me wrong. Definitely worth it if your only going to buy the 5 dollar entry or F2P full release(especially if they come through). So id say worth a play and to do so casually and occasionally and sit on it until a full east version is completed and released with contiual updates, could be a highly populated good go to FPS/MMO hybrid.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Seems like a really fun game. As a GiTS fan, I love the character design of Motoko et al. The music is en pointe. The graphics are great; fast and smooth thus far.

One problem: No one to play with.

If I were involved in the game design process, I would have made an argument for kicking this off with a PvE or singleplayer mode. There are a few reasons, one of which is certainly based on hindsight:

1) It's a game about an Anime show. Give me half a reason to play and I will. Unlike Call of Dudeskis, I'm actually obsessed with the subject matter/ambiance so capitalize on that and create a series of PvE missions which highlight key features like the operative skills, etc.

2) Way, way easier to sort out bugs when you reduce variables. With all of this netcode speculation, who really knows at this point. Now, instead of having the luxury of sorting out specific gameplay features like shooting, moving and skills, the devs also have to worry about multiplayer optimization. Seems to me that PvP would be easier to tackle after learning some lessons about the player base in PvE.

Speaking of this, I feel like the designers made just a few too many assumptions about what the player wants. For an early access/iterative release, the main advantage is making small sets of assumptions and validating them first--again in some simplified PvE that lets people fan boy out in GiTS land.

Again, I think something really solid and workable is here, but without a player base, I can't hold out much hope. On a totally random side note: Maybe I've been playing too much Xcom 2, but the awesome models in First Assault make me really, REALLY want a reskin of Xcom with Motoko and Section 9. I would love to move cyborgs and think tanks around on a map of Dejima...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex - First Assaullt Online is not the most original shooter, hell, it's not even really innovative. But dammit, it's fun. Taking the overly saturated multiplayer FPS genre and running with it, First Assauly Online stands above its contemporaries with great maps, developers who are willing to listen to their playerbase, somewhat realistic bullet damage, sniping that actually requires skill, and overall feels much more true and gritty than say, Call of Duty. That being said, if you only enjoy shooters akin to CoD, it'd be wise to stay far, far away from this.

Of course, it's not perfect. It's still clearly early access and while you'll see a lot of reviews complaining about hit detection, in most cases it's really nothing too severe. It's certainly enjoyable, and as a Ghost in the Shell fan, unless you can dig up a copy of the PS1 game, this is undeniably the best it'll get for you.

If you enjoy a good tactical online shooter, this is a must have, especially for its price (and if $5 is still too much, the game's free if you sign up on the website. The steam version is basically just instant access plus cosmetics and in-game currency (which can be easily unlocked just by playing)). To add, despite microtransactions being in place, they are only for A. cosmetics, and B. points earned by leveling for people who don't want to wait. The game itself is not in any way pay to win. Provided the devs keep it that way, this review should always be positive.

Buy it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After over 20 Hours ingame, my review.

First this game seemed pretty decent.Cheap, pretty stable servers, all your beloved characters from GitS. But now... they got 5 Servers (2 US, 2 EU, 1 Australian). 4 of them are empty 24/7 and the only one with players (EU West), got like 2 rooms á 5 people playing at its primetime.

I serioulsy wonder, this game still gets supported and not called dead finally. Well, support might be too much, as you cant call patches with new Skins and Weapons for real money, support.

Others Pros and Cons.

+ if you get to play it can be pretty fun
+ fast paced shooter with some kind of tactic
+ each character with his own special ability

- the graphic is less than decent for 2015/ 2016, just grey in grey with a low amount of polygons
- the buyable Skins are kinda wasted, since all enemies look the same from your view (some counterstrike-like terrorist-model)
- the spacial skills arent balanced at all, Makotos Invisibility isnt completly invisible, so its pretty useless, Arm-Rockets kill you instantly, no matter how many hp you have, in a pretty big area, seeker drones are op as ♥♥♥♥ (you send them out, they spot an enemy, follow him endless, stick to him, explode and kill you, no matter how many hp) and the hyperspeed in combination with shotgun or knife is simply gg, since you can insta-kill people with knife, if you get somehow close, without any counterchance.
- There are 3 Diffrent Main Weapontypes (snipe, shotgun, spray). From like 30 guns, 3 are shotguns, 3 sniperrifles and 24 are smg, mg and rifle. The First guns are more or less all horrible.
-The Starter Snipe cant hit anything further away than 5 metre, no matter if it would have been a straight hit, while the Sniperrifle for around 250k ingame money (you get like 50-200 per match, depending on the amount of kills, without real money boosts and 10k for a level up which goes quite fast at start but from around lvl 10 on takes ages).
-Shotgun is just halfway aim, shoot, kill and there are 2-3 really op smgs, picked by pretty much all players left in the game.

Ill spare you any more. All in all its quite unbalanced, so all people play the same 3 chars /classes, pick the same 3 guns and play one of 3 modi with only a handful maps. So save your money and invest it in... i dont know... CS:GO i.e. I hate CS:GO but its still a thousand times more fun than this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Where to start, where to start...

Note: This review is coming from someone who has never seen Ghost In The Shell before

The bad:

Servers are pretty much garbage at this point, even when I have nothing else running on my internet I experience stutters from lag that render the game almost un-playable at times. (Frame Rate dropping from 60 to 0)

The guns, kick, a lot... can't decide whether this is a bad thing or not neccessarily... it just seems like even when I'm on target my gun still fails to take them down. Tapping the trigger is definitely the way to play right now.

The graphics are not that great, now don't get me wrong, I don't mean this as a specifically bad thing about the game, I  just wanted to point that out in this review.


The good:

This game, lets you pay in game money for character slots! You heard me! No microtransactions as of yet for new characters, just 249.000 in game money, (You get 50,000 every time you level up) And you get a free character liscense at ranks 3 and 5!

The gameplay, is fantastic. It's a fast paced game with decent gun play and a lot of teamwork.

Each character in the game has a different skill, and these skills can be combined in combat to make some interesting scenarios. ie: If your skill reaches rank 2, (Note: This is only applicable to certain skills) you can activate a skill link, allowing nearby friendly players to share that skill with you. I usually play as a a character that grants a speed boost. When I was playing a match of TDM earlier, our team combined a rank 2 defense boost, with my rank 2 speed boost, and that combination took us well into the lead, making us harder to kill and faster than any of the enemy team.

The progression system is on point. You spend a small amount of credits on guns/attachments to gain the ability to EARN them, not actually buying them. ie: I spent around 30,000 credits on a gun, and it was added to my unlocks, and requires 200 tp to unlock. At the end of every match, depending on how well you did, you earn a certain amount of tp, and it goes towards that unlock. Once you get the required amount of tp, that gun is now available to you in your armory.

The game's maps at the moment are not plentiful, but they do the job.


Overall, I think this game is definitely worth the $5 to play for a bit, and it will most definitely be worth downloading at launch when the game is Free To Play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honest, personal review after about 7hrs
Pros: Good character models
Nice abilities that can be shared with 3 of your teammates
Pretty fast-paced(while not being too fast)
English voices
Teamplay is a must
Good selection of characters with unique skills
Easy to get the hang of with a nice and detailed Tutorial
Motoko
Currently NO P2W(atm, we'll see if Nexon changes that)
GP is no issue as each rank up gives you 50k
Free Operative Unlock Coupons at ranks 3 and 5. Cons: Few maps
Weapons don't have that GitS theme
Spawns are not the best(can spawn surrounded by enemies, even with the few seconds of immunity, still kinda a pain.)
Map textures are a bit lacking compared to the character's
Map sizes; Would be nice to have a few, larger scale maps, especially for TDM
Hit detection seems to be pretty random
No ammo pickups
Guns are very innacurate, even when aiming down the scopes
Overall, a good game if you can put up with a few issues that will hopefully be smoothed out as the game gets more feedback. Is it worth the $5? Yes. Feels like most other F2P Shooters out there, and would be nice if they added some sort of Co-op mission mode that feels like you're reinacting parts of the anime, but a good game considering it just came out today.

If you're afraid of the game just having Nexon's name on it, please just stay away and cry somewhere else. Too many reviews with under 1hr of gameplay and most just saying it's P2W" which it is not atm. We'll see if it goes that route
date: but I'm hoping it doesn't.\n\nIn the end
recommended: I would rate this game a 7.5/10 and will change my review as it gets updated."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Does this game have flaws? Yes.
Would I recommend it? Hell yes!

Let's all keep in mind this is an Early Access stage, and by purchasing it we accept that the game HAS flaws and is incomplete, I don't get why people should downvote it only because of this.
For what I see, it has such a great potential. It's fun, fast, dynamic, and as a Ghost in the Shell lover I appreciate the effort put in keeping the original voice acting and small details that make this game an average FPS with Ghost in the Shell references.

There are several features I'd like to talk about:

- Weapon Customization: You begin with basic weapons that can be upgraded by changing different parts (ex. barrel, scope, magazine...). Unlockable parts take time to be available as you earn point while playing. Those parts modify the weapon stats, enhancing a value while giving a disadvantage (ex. small damage increase - huge movement speed decrease).

- Shooting Range: I personally found it to be an extremely useful area to test your weapon, learn how to use it and to test some techniques to polish your gameplay.

- Teamwork: Teamwork is necessary. Rambo gameplay only ends up in a very long death ratio. Teamwork is also sponsored by the devs thanks to skill sharing: when a player uses a Tier 2 skill, all the nearby teammates can use it as well. Think twice before going solo.

There are a couple of aspects I would like to point out, just minor bugs I found and advices I'd like to give the developers (which are doing such an amazing job so far) hoping they could read this review:

- Matchmaking: I found that sometimes teams are not well balanced, it's easy to find teams made of a majority of operatives/classes of the same type or made of lower levels players.

- Respawn: A very rare bug"
date: it happened that I spawned in the middle of the enemy team. It may be due to the size of the maps that at the moment is still a little bit smaller than expected.\n\n- Linear maps: So far the maps have quite a linear feel. I would like to see some open maps where the player can move with more liberty."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Things first, if you love the anime series and expect something similiar : Don't bother.
You see Maps and Characters that reminds you of the GITS Series, but gameplay wise you don't get much what you'd expect from a Ghost in the Shell Game. Sure it's an Free2Play game made by Neople and published by Nexon. I had some starter problems (cause of the Steam-Nexon Account stuff) but the gameplay itself is fun in my opinion. It doesn't achieve something thats worth calling Ghost in the Shell, but hey - right now it's early access. Not much content so far, and TDM sucks a bit hard because the Spawn System. Overall the Maps are looking good itself but it lacks something, not quite sure what it is. The main problems are : the random spray pattern - it shoots everywhere if you dont burst with your weapon. yet rookies with no aim and only hipfire kinda often give you some headshots which brings me to the second point : the hitboxes - it's not worth aiming for the head because you mostly won't hit it, until like I already said go for hipfire.

TL;DR : If you want an Free to Play - First Person shooter thats seem promising and fun - buy it. It sure has its frustrating moments where you can't do everything with your Skill - but I have high hopes that they're changing it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Glad this game is in Beta still:

I want to give this game a yes and a no. A yes, because it brings a new vibe to First Person Shooter games, and it is quite fun when you can figure out the controls. There is a new era in this game with it different choices of characters and techology you can use with the different characters you wanna play with. I find that this is really fun to dink around with. If you get good at the game, you can become a very good FPS gamer in this game. So brovo to Nexon for creating a new kind of game.

A no, becuase the game is utterly unfair. Pay to win. Want a better gun? Put your cash into it as fast as you can and you'll become a better player within 24 hours. This is unfair: When someone bull rushes you, you shoot them in the head twice. It doesn't kill them and they knife you to death, like in many FPS games... a head shot is suppose to do that, kill someone in one hit with 1 or 2 headshots. I feel like their are aim botters in this game and it ruins it. I hope that Nexon can find those players and ban them from the game. It would make the game so much better! I also want to say that it has a lot of whiners, and try hards in this game.

Just a fair warning before starting this game: There are a lot of rude people that won't wanna play with you if you're just begining. They will bash on you and try to hurt your feelings. The tryhards are the rude ones because they will complain that you suck" and should "quit at life." Just ignore these players and play the game as causal and for fun as you can.

Glad there isn't voice chat for this game. The chat would get so salty.

Overall
recommended:
but needs lots of fixing.

Cons:

1. Aim botters.
2. Pay to win.
3. Players are rude.

Pros:

1. New community.
2. New genre for FPS
3. Cheap game to buy.

They need to add a feature where we can just play around and train against bots. Throwing us against already good players is a bad way to promote the game. Train us better or have better training features.

Overall I give this a B+ and a thumbs upish."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a pretty fun Game
It is a typical fps with many features
Also im an anime fan so seeing an a game like this is like treasure (so yeah a lil bias i admit)

This game focuses on many core features a  multiplayer should have:

Team work is essential - sorry cod fans but you cant be a one man army in this game

Weapon Customization - I do so love customizing weapons, though there are a few now, more will be added later

Abilities - each caharacter has thier unique abilities that can aid either yourself or your teammates in battle (tip: build up to tier 2 always)

Fair Gun Play - SMG and Rifles are pretty much what dominate this game like every shooter

Fair sized maps - I feel that the maps are a bit crowded but there are enough positions for snipers to do their thing

EXP and Dosh - its fairly easy to earn a lot of experience and money as you lvl up so dont worry if you a little behind

Free to play? - Not sure but this game is quite eligable to be free to play however developers take caution if doing so because then this game can be open to anyone including all sorts of hackers so be sure to have a strong effecient anticheat system.

Now there are some cons to this game and some just can straight on ♥♥♥♥ off anyone these really need to be fixed:

Little Spawn protection - you have about 2-3 seconds of spawn protection in game combined that the team respond itself doesnt have any form of protection, essentailly the enemy team can come into your team spawn, camp and kill you all day if they wanted to (Please add some kind of turrent or barrier that kills anyone or at least haults them from entering anywhere near team spawn - im looking a dubbing site specifically)

Connection problems - maybe not everyone experiences this but time and time again i have seen that some players snap out of their cover, supposidly one shot me, and snap back into cover all under a second, its insane when there seems to be no way to counter this other then to get behind an enemy and kill them or somethinglike that.

Under-powered  or over-powered weapons - clearly in the game, some weapons are better then others, there should be some sort of rebalancing, one example is I use the .44 magnum which no one uses because it has 6 shots and does about 40 ish damage which mean 3 shots to kill someone = half of the clip to kill someone, :/ not exactly the most powerful handgun in the world now is it. Also weapons like the one lmg in the game automatically beats every single smg  with its fire rate in close quarters and it has as much range and damage as an assault rifle, clearly this needs a nerf. Shotguns have terrible hit detection, i shot someone not even 3 feet away, runs straight at me with his m4 and i hip fire a shell into his chest -> doesnt kill him but he headshots me... really?

Team Collision - Its super annoying when your teammate blocks you from going back into cover and you get shot up by the enemy or vice versa, also more so you keep getting blocked as you journey accross the map by some of your teammates or them standing in the middle of door ways trapping you in a room

Controls - at some essential points ive realized how stiff the aiming and movement can be while playingin an intense match

Fire Spread - I know that going full auto should increase the spread, but the rate of spread in this game is so severe you can be a few feet away from an enemy spray your bullets and only about 1/4 of them would hit your target unless you went to burst or semi.

Other then those issues, this game is fairly good, worth the $5 early access start, and clearly one of the better games in the overall 2015 game roster.

Developers please address these issues and fix them in the next hotfix or update, the issues are extremely annoying and are quite harmful to the game's status.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS-REVIEW
Pro:

+ It's a Ghost in the Shell Shooter
+ Teamplay is important
+ Abilities are better reconsidered than in Black Ops III
+ Not Pay-2-Win
+ Good weapon balance and customization
+ Weapons have recoil
+ Orginal Englisch Voice Actors
+ Plays like a mix of CoD and Counter-Strike
+ Steam-Traidingcards

Contra:

- Only Multiplayer Shooter, would be fun to play a GitS story mode
- Sometimes has weird lags
- No Japanese Voice Actors
- Currently doesn't have much variety (3 game modes and a handful of maps pretty neat, though)

Bought it on sale so I have a blast playing that game for only ~4$
One of the early access games that isn't horribly bad

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At the moment, as free to play shooters go, it's okay. Average even. The mechanics show a lot of promise through. The cyborg superpowers your characters get work really well for encouraging teamwork, adding a twist to the standard F2P Shooter model, and so far the business model seems enough like Dirty Bomb to be enticing, but not as punitively ridiculous as Blacklight: Retribution.

The game uses the English VAs for Stand Alone Complex, which is ♥♥♥♥ing spectacular, and goes well with the overall attachment to the theme.

For $5 it's definitely worth it for fans of the series. If the game improves over development, I'll be back to give it an more vigorous thumbs up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honest, personal review after about 7hrs
Pros: Good character models
Nice abilities that can be shared with 3 of your teammates
Pretty fast-paced(while not being too fast)
English voices
Teamplay is a must
Good selection of characters with unique skills
Easy to get the hang of with a nice and detailed Tutorial
Motoko
Currently NO P2W(atm, we'll see if Nexon changes that)
GP is no issue as each rank up gives you 50k
Free Operative Unlock Coupons at ranks 3 and 5. Cons: Few maps
Weapons don't have that GitS theme
Spawns are not the best(can spawn surrounded by enemies, even with the few seconds of immunity, still kinda a pain.)
Map textures are a bit lacking compared to the character's
Map sizes; Would be nice to have a few, larger scale maps, especially for TDM
Hit detection seems to be pretty random
No ammo pickups
Guns are very innacurate, even when aiming down the scopes
Overall, a good game if you can put up with a few issues that will hopefully be smoothed out as the game gets more feedback. Is it worth the $5? Yes. Feels like most other F2P Shooters out there, and would be nice if they added some sort of Co-op mission mode that feels like you're reinacting parts of the anime, but a good game considering it just came out today.

If you're afraid of the game just having Nexon's name on it, please just stay away and cry somewhere else. Too many reviews with under 1hr of gameplay and most just saying it's P2W" which it is not atm. We'll see if it goes that route
date: but I'm hoping it doesn't.\n\nIn the end
recommended: I would rate this game a 7.5/10 and will change my review as it gets updated."
hoursPlayed: December 14, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a pretty fun Game
It is a typical fps with many features
Also im an anime fan so seeing an a game like this is like treasure (so yeah a lil bias i admit)

This game focuses on many core features a  multiplayer should have:

Team work is essential - sorry cod fans but you cant be a one man army in this game

Weapon Customization - I do so love customizing weapons, though there are a few now, more will be added later

Abilities - each caharacter has thier unique abilities that can aid either yourself or your teammates in battle (tip: build up to tier 2 always)

Fair Gun Play - SMG and Rifles are pretty much what dominate this game like every shooter

Fair sized maps - I feel that the maps are a bit crowded but there are enough positions for snipers to do their thing

EXP and Dosh - its fairly easy to earn a lot of experience and money as you lvl up so dont worry if you a little behind

Free to play? - Not sure but this game is quite eligable to be free to play however developers take caution if doing so because then this game can be open to anyone including all sorts of hackers so be sure to have a strong effecient anticheat system.

Now there are some cons to this game and some just can straight on ♥♥♥♥ off anyone these really need to be fixed:

Little Spawn protection - you have about 2-3 seconds of spawn protection in game combined that the team respond itself doesnt have any form of protection, essentailly the enemy team can come into your team spawn, camp and kill you all day if they wanted to (Please add some kind of turrent or barrier that kills anyone or at least haults them from entering anywhere near team spawn - im looking a dubbing site specifically)

Connection problems - maybe not everyone experiences this but time and time again i have seen that some players snap out of their cover, supposidly one shot me, and snap back into cover all under a second, its insane when there seems to be no way to counter this other then to get behind an enemy and kill them or somethinglike that.

Under-powered  or over-powered weapons - clearly in the game, some weapons are better then others, there should be some sort of rebalancing, one example is I use the .44 magnum which no one uses because it has 6 shots and does about 40 ish damage which mean 3 shots to kill someone = half of the clip to kill someone, :/ not exactly the most powerful handgun in the world now is it. Also weapons like the one lmg in the game automatically beats every single smg  with its fire rate in close quarters and it has as much range and damage as an assault rifle, clearly this needs a nerf. Shotguns have terrible hit detection, i shot someone not even 3 feet away, runs straight at me with his m4 and i hip fire a shell into his chest -> doesnt kill him but he headshots me... really?

Team Collision - Its super annoying when your teammate blocks you from going back into cover and you get shot up by the enemy or vice versa, also more so you keep getting blocked as you journey accross the map by some of your teammates or them standing in the middle of door ways trapping you in a room

Controls - at some essential points ive realized how stiff the aiming and movement can be while playingin an intense match

Fire Spread - I know that going full auto should increase the spread, but the rate of spread in this game is so severe you can be a few feet away from an enemy spray your bullets and only about 1/4 of them would hit your target unless you went to burst or semi.

Other then those issues, this game is fairly good, worth the $5 early access start, and clearly one of the better games in the overall 2015 game roster.

Developers please address these issues and fix them in the next hotfix or update, the issues are extremely annoying and are quite harmful to the game's status.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My initial impression: This game is fun and has a lot of potential. It feels and plays very much like todays common FPS. If you are looking for something to compare it to, somewhat like Call of Duty I suppose (cannot officially say cause I do not play Call of Duty). As I continue to play it, I hope it does not feel like a skinned version of other FPS classics.

The one huge bummer that disappointed me is lack of controller support. Does not have controller support (at the moment of it's release). I really hope they add it ASAP. I am not a keyboard fan and I would love the option.

I haven't played it long enough to say it is awesome or terrible. But I can say it is worth a shot if you are looking for something new.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game for a true FPS lover!

PROS:
-Great class system with custom skills
-Unique and spot on graphics
-Combat Arms players will feel at home
-Easy to learn controls and navagateable UI
-Will have you coming back for more
-Fans of the show and movies will appreciate
-Guns are very customizable
CONS:
-Only 4 levels at the moment
-Occasional lag spikes and disconection
-Aiming system is hard to get use to (at least for me)
-Still in early access  / Not many lobbies
-Limited customization (as of now we will see what the future holds)

VERDICT: -8.5- An all around, well put together and executed game. Fans of the show will feel right at home, as will newcomers, to the GITS family. A challenging yet rewarding F2P game with a lot of room for expantion!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

-As it says, the game is still Early Access Beta, so you'll find lack of content.
-Also, the armor suit and some maps that they show on the trailer are not added on the game right now,nor the PVE content.
-The hitbox is broken, so you'll get a headshot easly even aiming at the shoulder of an enemy.
-The weapon customization is pretty good and there's a decent amount of weapons for an Early Access,lots of parts,skins,also you can choose all characters from the series with unique abilites.
-There's sniper rifles, but they're pretty much useless since the maps are small/arenaish and most of the modes are aggresive, unless you play DEMOLITION.
-Tachikoma AI needs alot of work.
-Pretty good graphics, 60 fps all the time too.

It's a good game, but i recommend playing if it gets a discount or until release at the moment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not a bad game, but in its current state, I do not feel that I can recommend it, either.  This is an early access review, so I hope that the devs will make improvements because this is a game with potential.  But that potential is not yet realized.

SummaryThe graphics and art are very good.  Controls are mostly responsive, with the only caveat being sometimes sprint doesn't work when I want it to (like trying to get clear of a grenade).  Voice acting is very good.  The sci-fi theme of Ghost in the Shell seems overwhelmed by the generic theme of I am a shooter".  Really
date: this is another military-style FPS with a different coat of paint
recommended: and that is where the potential is unrealized.\n\nShooting MechanicsAs noted in some other reviews -- shooting mechanics are wonky.  I've had several instances where my taget is right in front of me
hoursPlayed: ironsights right on him
voteText: firing -- and I get greased because not one bullet I fired actually hit.  It is a source of confusion that took me a while to understand
helpfulPercent: and even then I find the design to be rather "meh."\n\nIt all revolves around gun upgrades as they focus mostly on improving stability (less recoil) and accuracy (bullets fly straight).  Without these upgrades
votesHelpful: most guns are unreliable and bullets can do unnatural things like fly diagonally
votesTotal: sometimes even excessively so -- and yes
votesFunny: miss a target right in your face.  But once I dumped a ton of GP on a K22 assault rifle and installed a scope
commentsCount: laser sight
column16: different barrel
column18: and grip -- it was a much more reliable weapon.  Not perfect by any means
column19: but noticeably better.  I had a similar experience in upgrading a MP5-V5A smg.\n\nBut fully upgrading a gun has its costs.  First you play a bazillion matches to unlock certain guns and acquire GP.  Keep in mind that unlocked guns and upgrades still cost GP
column20: although not as much as those guns/upgrades in the "market".  But the game is rather generous starting out.  You get a GP bonus at every level and the first few levels go quick.\n\nBut the costs don't end there.  Most upgrades also reduce certain combat stats
column21: like movement speed and attack range.  Sometimes also damage and weapons swap speed.  A few upgrades run counter and actually reduce stability
column22: which you really need more of.\n\nAnd this is why I conclude
column23: "meh."  Upgrading guns isn't about making them interesting
column24: but rather to make them useable -- at a sacrifice to other combat stats.\n\nCommunityMy review comes after a free Steam weekend
column25: which would imply that there are more people playing than normal.  What chatter I saw in game seemd to indicate that impressions were it was a decent game
column26: but perhaps not compelling enough to buy in.  Although at $5 for the recruit's package
column27: you can do a lot worst than this.\n\nBut more important is that even during the free weekend
column28: I am consitently playing matches with/against the same people.  Is that due to matchamaking or is that due to a limited pool of players?  I don't know.  But everytime I tried to join a Terminal Conquest match
column29: there were not enough players around to start the game.  But I had no trouble getting going in Team Deathmatch or Demolitions.\n\nUnrealized PotentialThe Ghost in the Shell anime series and movies are action heavy
column30: but the plot revolves around more than just greasing badguys.  And this is where the game's potential goes unrealized.  This is an FPS that does little more than just grease the badguys (the enemy team).  Sure
column31: each operative (aka "class") has a unique power based on their role in the anime
column32: but these don't add enough to the theme to set it apart from other military-style shooters.\n\nNotes to Devs1) Everytime someone on the enemy team uses one of their operative's powers
column34: everytime I took a rocket to the face and been reduced to scrap
column36: "The enemy is using an arm launcher."  Really?--You don't say.  Kinda figured that one out when it hit me in the face.  This would be more meaningful if announced when a launcher is armed
column37: not when it's fired.\n\n2) Speaking of Batou's arm launcher.  It would be great if I could "put it away".  More than a few times
column38: I primed it to setup a hallway multi-kill only for my team to clear the hallway before I could setup the shot.  And now I'm stuck hobbling around with this thing until I find another target -- any target.\n\n3) Awards for skills are unbalanced.  They strongly favor those operatives that can share their powers
column39: like Motoko's thermo-camo.  Those operatives whose powers are not shareable (like Batou's arm launcher) earn substantially less rewards.  It's something I observed immediately after I started playing Motoko after I had played Batou for several hours.\n\nConclusionBeing early access
column40: there is always hope that the game will get better.  And I have to admit that I had a lot of fun with it
column41: despite its flaws (and getting greased more often than not).  You can do worst than this game for $5.  But at the time of this review
column42: I find the game is still too "raw" to be able to recommend it.  But there is potential for greatness
column43: although that is a long road from here.  Hopefully
column44: the devs are good for the journey.\n\nEdits: Style

column29: there were not enough players around to start the game.  But I had no trouble getting going in Team Deathmatch or Demolitions.\n\nUnrealized PotentialThe Ghost in the Shell anime series and movies are action heavy
column30: but the plot revolves around more than just greasing badguys.  And this is where the game's potential goes unrealized.  This is an FPS that does little more than just grease the badguys (the enemy team).  Sure
column31: each operative (aka "class") has a unique power based on their role in the anime
column32: but these don't add enough to the theme to set it apart from other military-style shooters.\n\nNotes to Devs1) Everytime someone on the enemy team uses one of their operative's powers
column34: everytime I took a rocket to the face and been reduced to scrap
column36: "The enemy is using an arm launcher."  Really?--You don't say.  Kinda figured that one out when it hit me in the face.  This would be more meaningful if announced when a launcher is armed
column37: not when it's fired.\n\n2) Speaking of Batou's arm launcher.  It would be great if I could "put it away".  More than a few times
column38: I primed it to setup a hallway multi-kill only for my team to clear the hallway before I could setup the shot.  And now I'm stuck hobbling around with this thing until I find another target -- any target.\n\n3) Awards for skills are unbalanced.  They strongly favor those operatives that can share their powers
column39: like Motoko's thermo-camo.  Those operatives whose powers are not shareable (like Batou's arm launcher) earn substantially less rewards.  It's something I observed immediately after I started playing Motoko after I had played Batou for several hours.\n\nConclusionBeing early access
column40: there is always hope that the game will get better.  And I have to admit that I had a lot of fun with it
column41: despite its flaws (and getting greased more often than not).  You can do worst than this game for $5.  But at the time of this review
column42: I find the game is still too "raw" to be able to recommend it.  But there is potential for greatness
column43: although that is a long road from here.  Hopefully
column44: the devs are good for the journey.\n\nEdits: Style

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I usually don't write reviews, but I feel compelled to do so for this one. If you have not yet paid for early access, then don't. You are better off waiting until this game is free to play. The controls are clunky and slow. When shooting, you might as well drag the mouse across the table like you are having a seizure. If you want to use a controller, you will quickly find out that the inputs for it are bugged. As some other users have stated, you will fire your weapon continously or be unable to aim down the sights.

As far as gameplay goes, you aren't missing much. It the grindy unlock system that the entire COD franchise uses. The 3 modes are TDM, Demolition, and some sort of control that I have not checked out yet. Of course, the phrase Team Death Match is used loosely. Everyone runs around in opposite directions and gets shot, much like in a certain other franchise that keeps coming out every year. This game also is succeptible to hackers, just like every other FPS on the market. For some reason we can't  just play the game and enjoy it. The hit detection is attrocious. There are times when it works ok and even when you die you know it is because your skills aren't up to others'. Then there's plenty of times when you shoot someone who is facing the other direction, emptying your entire clip into the back of their head or chest and they simply turn around and one shot you. All of this makes for a frustrating experience.

Story? There is none. In fact, I would go as far as to say that this has absolutely nothing to do with Ghost In The Shell. It's just a skin with some of their voices.

TL;DR
-Pros: Shooty, shooty
Cheap

-Cons: Fix the controller support
Improve slow and clunky controls
Find some magical way for the bullets to get to where you are aiming.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't put too much time into this game, but enough to write a review I think. Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex - First Assault Online is a futuristic, FPS game based on it's anime/manga counterpart.

I would rate the game a solid 8/10 for a F2P game, but a 6/10 for a game in general. It's like CoDs futuristic little brother. he's a bit of an ♥♥♥, but he's fun to be around. All you can do is hope that he'll become a better person with some life experience, although somehow you doubt it.

THE STORYIf you came to this game for any sort of plot, you're better off reading or watching the source material this game is based on. Being a F2P (Atleast when it releases anyway), there isn't any campaign, but there is story there, you just have to know about Ghost In The Shell. To sum the main story up, you play as Section 9 members (cybernetically augmented Humans/Cyborgs who are pretty much like futuristic police/armed-forces), and you have to fight Terrorists throughout Japan's streets. I personally never read or watched any of the source material, so I can't really compare how true it is to the source, but I imagine this is what the show was like so...

GAMEPLAY PROSThe Game itself is extremely fun for short periods of time. It looks great, plays great and feels great.
Pros:
- The game is FUN.
- Fast-paced matches.
- 'Kinda(?) balanced guns.
- Small (quick) sized maps for Deathmatch and Medium maps for the other game modes.
- Will be F2P upon release.

THE PAYMENT MODELI had some doubts about this game, since it is made by Nexon, who are notorious for making pay to win games, but they proved me wrong this time. The game seems pretty (Not fully) balanced, so it's not exactly pay to win, but don't get me wrong, this game has micro-transactions. You can purchase currency in this game to purchase characters and weapons/attachments quicker, but they're (kind of) optional. Of course you can unlock everything everything through gameplay, but in 6 hours of game play, I've unlocked maybe 3 attachments and no guns even. The purchases are the problem, The currency isn't over-priced, its just guns and everything else is. For example a rifle is 250K credits and you earn a couple of thousand per-match. And then you have to unlock each individual attachment for that weapon, with each unlock costing around 50K credits. At the beginning of the game, you level up quickly and with each level you are given X amounts of credits (usually around 50K), but each level gets slower and slower, until it's just a painfully slow grind. It would probably take you around 8 hours of gameplay to get enough credit for 1 gun! It's pretty bad, and it encourages you to pay for credits, but hey! This is F2P so what did you expect?
Note- Just because bying credits speeds things up, it's not necessarily P2W. See below and I'll explain.

(I also wanted to note, If you buy into the E.A. you only get one of the skins that is shown in the E.A rewards picture. I got the MP5 but I'm not sure if its random for everyone else.)

THE GUNSI Really enjoy using the guns in this game. They're all fairly easy to use and none are OP. You start off with an SMG, a Rifle and a Sniper. All are fairly decent and with skill, could beat someone with one of the purchasable guns 9/10 times. I personally really like the MP5 as it makes for good stealthy and speedy play. Paired with the Stealth or Speed operatives, this thing is a beast. However, all the guns are decent in their own respects. There are around 15 available weapons, yet more are added occassionaly, though I haven't been able to play with any other weapons. Weapons themselves range between 200K-250K to purchase, so unlocking them is an exruciatingly slow process. Once you unlock a weapon, you get kills to earn towards unlocking individual attachments, each of which cost around 50K. Some people may think this is unbalanced, and it is slightly, but if you have even a little skill, you can go toe to toe with people who have purchased items, even if you have a base gun with no ATTs. Like I said, the game feels very balanced with more of a reliance on skills and a persons insticts/reactions. Sure some people buy guns but its A) Optional B) Available through unlocks C) The gun they brought is most likely the same stats as yours.  TO SUM UP: The guns are balanced enough. They're fun to play with. Even though most are based on real guns, they feel futuristic. However problems are: Slow grind to unlock. Over Priced. Get's repetitive to play with the same 3 weapons for 6 hours, But hey! F2P.
I think a great comparison to this games guns are Call Of Duty weapons. They are all decent, some weapons are shunned and there are some slightly better weapons, but with skill, anyone can succeed.

(Just as a personal note, firing the guns feels more like a POP than a BANG. You just don't get that explosive feel from firing a weapon, unlike in a game like CS:GO or Battlefield. But that's my personal feel)

GAMEPLAYAgain the best thing to compare the game play to, is CoD. It's fast-paced and fun. It's fair enough to the point where you won't be raging constantly and there are several unique elements (such as the Operatives and the ThinkTank in Domination), When you launch the game, you're treated to a pretty stylish cutscene then you are dropped into a server selection screen. Currently, I play on EU West and it's DEAD. It takes 5 mins to find a half empty lobby, then another 5 mins for it to fill up. You can select the tutorial (which isn't so much about FPS controls, but about introducing you to the unique (ish) cahracters you'll be playing as and against. When you finish, you select an operative to unlock and jump into the game as, then you can start queing for a game. you can choose between Deathmatch, Domination or Search and Destroy game-modes (or a random gamemode). Deathmatch is fast-paced first to X amount of kills, Domination is first to X amount of site captures and S&D is first to X amount of Bomb plants/defuses/eliminations.

OTHER FEATURESOperatives: The characters you play. Each has a 'Unique' ability (such as cloaking) which switches up your play style.
-Fun. Makes the game interesting and can provide some gameplay changes.
-None of the characters are unique. The only thing they change is what abilities you have.
-Unlocked quickly initially, then slowly as the game progresses.
-From exprience, there are only 3-4 that are actually played out of the 8 or so that exist. Of course some people play           other ones but it's less common.

Loadouts: The section where you pick which guns you take into combat.
-Fairly easy to operate.
-Has a usefull test range, where you can train with weapons or test attachments.
-Rather annoying that I have to go through like, 8 tabs just to acces my 1 hour 10% xp boost.
-Unique (ish) perk system where you get temporary perks after each match which you can socket like gems into the character. (For example- 10% less fall damage for the next 5 games).
-Went the Payday 2 route of giving you a choice of 3 reward after every match.

Graphics: How the game looks.
-Game looks amazing on high settings!
-Not the best graphics ever, but very nice on High.
-They nailed the futuristic feel with the polished metalic and neon textures.
-Awesome little 'cutscenes' here and there.
-The 'Dive' animation before every match is dope!


So Sorry for the short review, I had 5-6 more paragraphs to write, but the limit on written characters meant I had to condense the review to the things I considered most important.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

Got this game for free during closed beta but never got round to playing it until recently, and I have to say I've been playing it with my friend quite  a lot for the past few days, we really have been enjoying it.


Pros
-Currently you do not have to pay money (other than the buying the game) to play the game as the only things you can buy with cash are gun skins and character skins
-Really like the look of the game
-The skills in this game feel very unique and are literal game-changers
-Incredibly cheap for it's content
-Each level you earn 50,000 gp (Which is a lot of in-game mone btw)
-Motoko's Thermo-optic Camo is only easily visible up close and only when you're paying attention to your surroundings

Cons
-Meele needs to be extended on
-Lacks a variety of weapons (2 snipers, a few pistols, and a lot of machine guns currently in-game)
-Very easy to walk past a sentry
-Weapon attachments that you can't unlock are incredibly expensive
-I can literally get one-shot by a guy with a machine gun
-Once had to empty an entire mag on someone (who wasn't using gel) at point blank just to kill them (I had the best attachemnts too)
-I suck at this game rip
-Once murded someones friend with a knife while he sat and watched, then murded him because he was reloading

Summary: A promising game, lacks content right now but a new map is being released. If the devs follow the anime and their own creative ideas, then im sure this game will turn out pretty good!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review Update  at 75 hours of play

In the space of a couple months, all the cons that I had have gone, the community for this game is great both in-game on and twitch during the weekly streams.
The game is constantly being updated with new guns, maps, characters and skins.

There is always an event going on to give you different objectives to earn extra in-game currency (GP) or maybe even a weapon.
If there are any obvious issues, they are going to be solved.

If you are thinking about getting this game, I must give you the heads up of the learning curve, you need to get used to your guns as there can be a modrate amount of recoil, depending on if your moving, crouching and which gun and attachments.
You will get beaten a lot early on by higher level players, but you soon get the hang of things. A major majority of players have a negative KD, do not worry that you die more than you kill you will only get better.
______________________________________________________________
First 2 hours of play reiew......
(Biased as I'm a massive fan of all Ghost in the Shell)

I love the game, and will be playing it a lot... There is room for improvements
(Able to choose which accesory I want to unlock next, Removal of W+Space" prompts)
The connectivity was insane
date: games started very quickly and even start without you if your changing aspects of your character or laodout
recommended: meaning that if you're ready and someone else isn't
hoursPlayed:
well you get to go on without them until they are ready!

I will later be buying the additional DLC to try out more characters and help support the game.
Will do another review after say 24+ hours of play for a better in-depth review etc."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is quite alright but still need fixing and improvements. We don't think is a good idea to get early access now but try playing it during free weekends or full release free. This review might change in the future.

However, there are few matters to mention in the game. Sadly, anyone with macro (rapid single click per second) mouse have more accuracy and recoil recovery than normal full/burst firing players. This exploit is unfair, they need to change the script for the recoil system or better do something about it. In most F2P FPS games, widescreen users have lesser vertical fov so they have to becareful or everyone better off playing 4:3 resolution stretched and the graphics will be meaningless. Some thin woods wall or object are not penetrable, only a few kind of obstacles. They need to unlock monitor refresh rate rather than 60 Hz maximum, we are playing in 120 Hz in most games hardly seeing stutters and smooth video records. You cannot save your allies when they are a victim in stealth kill during their slow animation, both enemy and victim dies after the animation if you kill the enemy.

Other than the issues in the game, is a good thing they apply enemy models depending on the map. Doesn't matter what 'Agents' the enemy are using, all enemy looks the same. Weapon customization variaties are good enough not too many or too little. Especially the part where you can put a single drum magazine to most weapons like our real-life guns.

Conclusion, early access is not a good idea for now. Let's wait until is playable stage.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros- First thing I want to say is that the game is really good for its price. At the time of this review, its not pay to win. The game has a decent amount of attachments and a diverse community of players in terms of skill. In many of games you will have a mix of some good players with a mix of many novices, so the level of competition is balanced for most matches. The game gets better as you buy more attachments for your guns ( they will not be great at first )  which you get points for it through leveling up and in game performance. As an early access game, it shows alot of promise and has an atmosphere that is true to the original work, in terms of characters, weapons, and a clip of the anime they show before entering a lobby.

Cons- While this game is not pay to win at the time this review is written, it does have some gun balancing issues and other issues that can be fixed with time but should still  be addressed. The most overpowered guns in the game have to be the shotguns because not only do they have an extreme amount of range,  there  are  times when they are a one shot from a distance of 15 to 25 meters( In this game thats the range of an SMG/AR ). I personally refuse to use such weapons becuase it encourages more use of it but I do think those guns need to be nerfed at least, though if they were banned I wouldnt complain. There are also some instances of severe server issues that cause the matches to lag for the entirety of the round  and as a result diminishes the overall experience of the game. Although the server issues arent often its still an issue that ive seen a few times that  negatively impact the matches. This is an early access game so a few issues are bound to happen. But its important to point them out now so it can be fixed in the future.

But to conclude this review i'll finish it by saying that I think this game deserves a try, especially for its price of 5 dollars  (at the time of this review). If your a fan of the orginal work or a fan of fast-paced  fps  games I strongly recommend it. I also want to thank the game developers/publishers for making the game free to play for the duration of a  weekend because thats how I found out about the game and was able to play it before making the purchase.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In the games current state it is a well balanced fps shooter featuring varous diffrent characters from the ghost in the shell series based around the TV series of ghost in the shell, stand alone society with each of the playable characters having special abilities such as radar, or invisibility, an arm launcher, drone, etc which fill up as you get kills or assists much like special abilities in the call of duty series. each of these skills have 2 levels the first being for you to use the ability and the second for others and yourself to use that ability although that being said some abilities are not shareable. the gameplay is a mixture between blacklight and counter strike in the way that it does not take all that much to die or get kills and most of the time a burst of fire is enough. currently there are 3 diffrent gamemodes to play the first is your standard team deathmatch the second is a capture type gamemode where if you capture a zone a spider tank is deployed and the third gamemode is demolition much like the csgo game mode where you have to either plant a bomb or defend two areas  with 1 life per round per player and is my most prefered current gamemode.
overall i would say to give to game a try in its current state because it is quite fun although harsh at time and think in its current state its atleast worth to give it a try when a free weekend come around.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First and foremost, if you intend to buy this game, get it while it's in early access to get it for cheap. I paid only $2.79 and would have gladly paid more.
I really enjoy the game, of course being early access it is not without issues, but the devs are trying to listen to player feedback.
It's an interesting blend of some concepts we've seen before, and a new concept that really makes for an interesting game.

The gameplay:
Feels like Call of Duty. It's a small to medium map twitch shooter. For me, however, I like the way they have made their maps/weapons/character abilities a bit more than any CoD I've played. In every call of duty, I find myself going for the same stuff: whatever loadout offers the best combination of firing speed, hip fire accuracy, and range. Every, god dang CoD I end up doing this. In GitS: First Assault I find myself jumping between assault rifle loadout, submachine gun, and sniper. I have literally never played a twitch shooter in which I found sniping either useful or fun - I basically only snipe in Battlefield, and vary game to game between assault rifles and submachine guns. Here, they all have their place.

The abilities:
Remenescent of games like Crysis, but with it's own twist. Instead of having just cloaking or nano-gel (which, actually, GotS: FA does have those two), you also have the options of speedboost, a cloaking shield (a shield that can be put up and shot through which makes the user/friendlies invisible), an arm launcher (essentially a rocket/noob tube), a sentry, or a heat-seeking bomb thing. You can not spam the abilities. They take time and/or points to build up the energy to use. Where GitS: FA really differs is the ability's Tier 2" capabilities. Tier 1 (the standard use of the ability) will gradually refill over time

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBeing a big fan of the Ghost in the Shell, I was very excited to hear that an FPS was being made around it. Having spent $5 to buy into the game isn't a big deal, for what will be a F2P game later. As of right now, I am happy to say I love the game, for what stage it is in. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is one I was looking forward to. My hopes weren't too high, because Nexon has failed me in the past (*cough* Vindictus *cough*), but I like this game. The combat is a little clunky (That my very well be my low end PC. I'm building a much better one currently) but is still very fun. Each character has different abilities which allows for different gameplay. Currently, pretty much everyone uses Motoko. I think it'll move around over time though. Anyways, Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex - First Assault Online (Screw that long name. I'm calling it GitSSACFAO. Yeah. Works) is a game that is still in progress, but very fun in it's present state.
