reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're an irish man with alot of luck this game is for you. Most of the gun play is random and anyone on their first try could get insta kills. Yes, you heard me right. insta kills. I will list the pros and cons inorder to help improve this game.
Pros:
The Voice acting is good quality.
The graphics fit the anime style.
Cons
1.Gun play is random and C.O.D like.(but worse)
2.The game gives you skins for your weapons that no one can look at. Pointless
3.The sounds are generic and nothing special
4.It takes no skill. You just shoot everywhere and hope for the best. You will probably get a insta-kill.
5.You will most likely take one step and get insta-killed.

How to fix:
1. Add spray patterns, proper health and proper damage to weapons. (Make it balanced)
2. Add a kill-cam" or something in first person so you can see skins or allow away to show them off.
3. Create more unique sound even if you have to stray away from the anime or use more sounds from it.
4.(see number 1) Also change movement to be more fluent and add more unique features that only this game has.
5. Once again do number 1 and overhaul spawning.
If these steps are taken with active devs I believe this game has potential. Otherwise there is NOTHING special in the game. Just wait for f2p or go and play a different game.

Recommended for the Irish:
11/10 would luck again."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW (Will change upon updates)
A pretty faithful first person shooter based on the Ghost in the Shell series. So far it's quite good but has plenty of room for improvement.

PRO
- It's a pretty solid game
- Plenty of characters with each one having a unique skill which changes how you play
- All characters are free (Out of a set of a few you can only choose one to begin with. Once you reach level 3, then 5, you get 'licences' which allow you to unlock another of your choosing. After that you can buy licences with in-game currency.
- You can use other players skills in the middle of battle by using 'SkillSynth'
- No overpowered weapons or items
- The levels are good sizes. Not too big to get lost or not find anyone but not too small for it to be a constant slaughter.
- Upgrades and drops are interesting to use and equip
- Weapons are customisable (Not too many atm but expect more)
- The game modes are pretty classic but nevertheless fun to play
- Original voice actors are used for the voices
- PVE has been announced to be a feature some point in the future

NEUTRAL
- Hacking the Tachikoma's are quite challenging
- Spawns are a little messy and can be infront of or behind a single enemy sometimes

CON
- Hitboxes seem a little wrong atm but hopefully should get sorted out
- There is no autobalancing

So far the game is well made and have promising things coming ahead. For only £4 access with a starter pack it's worth checking out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In the game's current state, DO NOT BUY IT.

My time on steam isn't much but I put in a good 10 hours in the closed beta that took place last yearish.


The hit detection is awful. So much so that you can put a whole mag into a guy and you won't get a hitmarker while standing beside him (has happened to me multiple times). The sniper rifle(s) won't hit even if the guy is standing still and you're reticle is on his head.


Something is wrong with the ADS sensitivity as well. All the guns seem to behave differently when you ADS. The one that acted the least spastically was the starting SMG. The AR and SR both seem to have issues where they either lower or raise input sens when ADS. AR lowers it by a TON. SR raises it just enough to be annoying.


Either way, as a CB tester, and someone who REALLY wants this game to be good, I can't tell anyone they should spend money on it. Hell I don't even wanna play it on the free weekend.

It also stutters on these specs on high settings @ 1080p

GTX 780 @ 1.2 GHz
4770k @ 4 GHz
16GB of 1866 MHz RAM
Running on an SSD

Come one guys, you gotta do better.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGlad to say that the game is overall a lot of fun. I was a bit worried before i bought it that it was just another p2w nexon/net marble generic fps in the style of A.V.A and Genesis A.D but after a few maps and getting the hang of it the game play is pretty nice. I'd pick this game up if you like the Show or want a fast skill based shooter.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ghost in the Shell Standalone Complex First Assault Online (GITSO from now on) is a Sci-Fi First Person Shooter, based on the infamous Ghost in the Shell Saga from Masamune Shirow.

Another thing I have to note: I will not elaborate how this game destroyed or somehow killed the GITS Saga, since I don’t know anything about it. I never watched any of the movies until now (I know, everybody please hate me now) but I PROMISE, I will do so after I played this game. I will solely focus on the game and the game alone.

Summarized Thoughts (tl;dr Section)The game feels somewhat bland. The mapdesign is crude and simple, it feels like the game forces you to face the enemy head-on. I wished for a bit more tactical advancement with flanking maneuvers. Unfortunately, the maps won’t let me do this.

Player movement is bearable but feels just wrong. Even after playing a long time, it still feels weird.

Operatives are nicely designed and feature different abilities, yet in the end, it is just easier to point a weapon at the enemy and just kill him. Unfortunatly, some of the Skills feel more powerful than others.

Most of the players said, that the game feels like a generic FPS with GITS as a theme. I approve that, it is completely right. However, I bought this game out of simple interest (since I love FPS and Sci-Fi) and grew to enjoy it to a certain degree. It is a shooter of very old times, just you, a weapon and the enemy featuring new special shareable abilities and no autoheal, a welcome change for me next to overloaded shooters like Crysis 3 and the neverending tales of Call of Doody and Rattlefield.

Even in light of all these downsides, I do enjoy the game. Eventually I might grow tired of it, just to pick it up at a later date again. But if you are here for some FPS-action and don’t really care about all the ruckus of why and how this is not GITS, then I cautiously advise you to take a look. Enjoy it, while it lasts.

Design & ArtGraphics don’t shine that much. Compare these to Warframe and you’ll see what I mean. Textures seem washed out, even on maxed settings. Overall, the graphics seem to be behind the standards, yet passable enough. Characters and weapons seem more well designed than the environment.

Only three maps are available for Team Deathmatch (I will talk about gamemodes in section “Gameplay”). The design of the maps really fell short in my opinion. Very few to absolute NONE possibilities to flank or outmaneuver the enemy are possible. Fighting hotzones mostly stay the same hotzones, even over different sessions. This enforces simple “Fight-or-Flight” situations, no way to outsmart other players, you either have the better aiming skills or you die.

ControlsThe controls are pretty straightforward; if you played any shooter in the last century, you’ll have no problems whatsoever. You play from First-Person-perspective. A nifty tutorial at the beginning of the game teaches you all the basics you need to know.
Unfortunately, at the current time, there is no controller support for those, who wish to play that way.

Sound & MusicSounddesign is okay in my opinion. Weapons sound powerful and the sounds adapt to environment. All of the sound effects feel fitting. Unfortunately sometimes, light cracking or other bugs are noticeable: Sometimes, gunfire makes my headset crack very loudly and the sprinting sound effect seems to be buggy, since it sometimes breaks up completely whilst sprinting. The music feels techy and enjoyable for my tastes.

Gameplay The game currently features three gamemodes: Team Deathmatch, Demolition (which I couldn’t play until now because no one wants to play it) and Terminal Conquest (Capture the objective and hold it). I will focus on TDM from now on, since I played this mode the most.

After the tutorial you get to choose one from currently seven operatives with special abilities. Some are shareable throughout the team (meaning you can give them to a small group of three teammates if you wish to decide so). This is pretty nifty but to gain maximum effect of your skills you need to stay close to teammates and help each other to dominate the enemy.

The gameplay is only as enjoyable as the design of the maps can make me enjoy it. It is either “Going-in” or “Going-home”. No flanking possible, no outsmarting, only you, your skill and your ability (which might not even available at that time, because it has cooldown timers).

No Autoheal! Awesome! If you barely survived the last confrontation, a light bloody screen will shroud your vision, but that will fade. You will then be left with the shred of health you desperately try to still get some kills out of to increase that tasty Kill-Death-Ratio.

Weapons or equipment are not tied to a certain level but do cost ingame currency. How refreshing!
The amount you gain from one match is really small, compared to how much a new gun actually costs (500-1.000 GP vs. 249.000 GP). Fortunately, levelups grant you 50.000 GP.

You have three different loadouts which can be changed on-the-fly before or whilst in the game! No need to hit “esc” or anything like that! Just hit F1, F2 or F3 for your respective loadout and the game will spawn you with your chosen loadout on your next spawn if you’re still alive and kicking. Very nice!

WeakpointsThe design of the Menu is terrible. It really does look nice and I like the techy style to it, yet it feels really overcrowded and confusing. Simply changing a sight on a rifle needs too much unnecessary clicking and confirmation, in my opinion.

Also, until you play a game, you have to wait. ‘What’s wrong with that?’ you ask. No, no, you got me wrong, I mean you need to wait UNECESSARILY OFTEN. Once you join a session, which is currently not in play, a timer counts down until when the game starts. If that timer reaches zero, YOU HAVE TO WAIT ANOTHER FIVE SECOND COUNTDOWN. Why? After that, you will spawned , BUT YOU HAVE TO WAIT AGAIN. Annoying. I just want to play. It is called “quickmatch” for a reason!

Movement of your operative seems really crippled. The sprinting doesn’t really feel like sprinting, it only feels like sprinting, when one operative activates his ability for other players to let them sprint faster. ‘Why isn’t this standard movement speed then?’ you ask. Simple, that would render said operative useless. But with sprinting that slow, he has somewhat of a purpose.

Speaking of movement, the player movement overall seems really clunky. That’s not just my opinion, many players complained about it whilst ingame and I do agree. I mostly feel like a wandering block. My jumping height is really limited, yet I can grab ledges which are nearly twice as high as me through contextual movement. A normal jump in comparison doesn’t even let me jump HALF that height. That doesn’t even make any sense.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When you load it up and play for the first time, it is most obviously a great experience for fans of Ghost in the Shell. There aren't many maps yet and quite a few of the key elements are missing, but that's what you get with a beta. For the first ten hours or so it plays like a standard shooter with a few novel features, and then it grows on you; First Assault Online does show the potential to develop into something extraordinary.

The skill-sync teamwork feature can turn a fairly standard capture-the-flag mode into a tactical avalanche. The demolition mode is highly dependant on individual skill and a critical choice of operative to match your playstyle. It is very good to see that the performance for reward system is fair without being punishing.

Elements of the game that require more work are :
1. The system of money for guns is disappointing to say the least. Players can unlock a good array of standard weapons just by playing, though all of the premium (ie fun) gear costs more than the game lets you earn in a reasonable time - it is not hard to see this turning into a real-money funding model.
2. Some kind of story mode is almost mandatory for a game set in a well-loved anime franchise, yet there is no hint of one. Without a story mode all we have is a fan-based shooter.
3. The augmentation feature lets you alter some of your operatives base stats, such as cyber-brain skills or physical endurance, without being seriously advantageous to the experienced player who has unlocked it all. This is all well and good, however there are not nearly enough drops, which is disappointing and again looks like turning into a real-money funding model.
For the time being i am having a lot of fun with GiTS:SAC-First Assault Online, and for that reason alone i have to recommend it.
4. Team auto-balance isn't there yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(This review has been copied from a forum post I made earlier today on an anime-based forum that I frequent, I left it unedited becuase it flows better but some information may be extraneous here on the Steam Store page.)

Ghost in the Shell Stand Alone Complex First Assault Online (*gasps for breath*) is an online first person shooter set in the world of the Ghost in the Shell franchise. The game is planned to be free-to-play sometime in the future but at the moment players can buy into the current early access test for as little as $5 and as much as $30 with 4 total tiers available to buy. None of the available tiers provide any gameplay advantages beyond some non-premium, in-game currency and some extra character slots (which can be earned with in-game currency), the rest of the items are strictly cosmetic, consisting of assorted weapon skins and a character skin. The game does not currently have a premium currency, but it may once the game goes free-to-play, I am not sure of the dev's plans.

When you first boot up the game you are taken immediately into the game's tutorial which can be skipped or replayed at any time, after this you select an operative, each of which has a unique skill with skills ranging from cloaking devices to arm-based rocket launchers. Players may only select one operative to start but as stated above, more can be purchased with in-game currency.

The actual gunplay of the title feels very solid, though I've only played a couple of matches so I have yet to see how the weapons perform over time. There is a currently broken weapon, the SA50 Sniper Rifle which is almost always a 1-shot kill and can be equipped with a short range scope allowing it to be used at most ranges quite effectively. Beyond this one weapon though, the other weapons feel very well balanced and are fun to use and shoot. Design wise the weapons seem to be inspired by modern firearms but with a visual overhaul to make them look and feel more futuristic, personally I like this design. Weapons can apparently be earned or bought, and I haven't seen any of the buyable weapons being particularly overpowered or underpowered, just situational in a couple of cases. Weapons may also be customized with some attachments being earned and others bought in a similar fashion to how guns work. Attachments can modify many aspects of a weapon and can increase or decrease stats in addition to being purely visual.

Aesthetically the game is hard for me to personally judge, I have never seen any of Ghost in the Shell (though I plan to remedy this) but apparently the devs have used the English VAs from Ghost in the Shell to reprise their roles, there are also little snippets of footage from the films/show when selecting match types which I thought was a neat little choice. I have enjoyed the game's visuals and I like the designs I've seen so far.

In summary, I'm cautiously optimistic about the game, as long as the weapon lists stay open to regular players without being locked behind pay-walls or premium currency I'll be happy, and once some balancing bugs are worked out I think the gameplay will be very solid. My biggest complaint so far is that the games seems like it is going to be an ungodly grind for purchased weapons and attachments, in my first couple matches I earned roughly 900 credits per match for a passable performance, cheap attachments go for 40,000 to 50,000 credits or more, guns are as little as 187,000 credits but mostly are in the 250,000 credit range. Rounding up to 1000 credits per match, it will take 40-50 matches to purchase a single attachment and hundreds of matches played to buy a single gun. The game will no-doubt have premium accounts that earn more money, but this is a tad crazy to me. But beyond this I have no major complaints and I may very well start earning more credits per game as I get better and level up, we shall see.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I, am a huge fan of GitS in all of it's Anime/Manga and video gaming glory. I'm also an avid fan of FPS games like CS:GO, CSS, Dirty Bomb and the like. This game however, annoyed me more than it allowed me to have any fun. Why? The spread for the bullets is absolutely horrid, the hitboxes are horrendous and you have Nexon pretty much not really doing a damn thing about the Aimbot/ESP Hacking issues. I give them credit for trying to build a game off of an amazing genre, but seriously; you have far more bugs to exterminate before I could really get into this game.

Pros:
1.) It's GitS.
2.) In game sensitivity options to change for while scoping and not scoping. <-- REALLY liked that.
3.) Original GitS characters and unique abilities for each made me feel like I was actually a Section 9 Member.
4.) Great weapon customization and ability changes depending on mods you install to weapons.
5.) Menus and videos in menus with backgrounds of characters and weapon model viewer.

Cons:
1.) Aimbot/ESP Hackers abound!
2.) Recoil is ridiculous, as is the spread for bullets.
3.) Hitboxes are broke, can aim just to the left or right of someone and get a headshot.
4.) Capslock = Sneakmode? Why?

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

Personally I really enjoy the game, it's action packed and with the skillsync feature teamplay is more likely to be seen.  Started playing the game during the closed beta and received the game for free, but as the community grew and got to know them more I found myself playing the game for 10+ hours straight at days and buying the game here on steam as well. It's not a P2W game and a new player can fight on equal grounds with a player that has been playing for months. Only difference would be the selection of mods/weapons to use, but I myself often use the weapons you start out with.

As any Early Access Game you will encounter some issues with the gameplay, but the development team are open for suggestions and listen to the community, for example: the community requested the Mateba (Togusa's handgun from the series) and now we have a Mateba. Incase you are doubting if you should purchase early access. There is an official twitch channel where you can watch one of the GM and/or the CM play the game so you can preview the gameplay itself and get a couple of laughs, or visit the official Discord server to where the community can talk or discuss the game development with the developpers.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The future never looked so expensive.

I used to like Nexon once upon a time. I played the beloved Combat Arms, and enjoyed it. So much so that I spend $125 on permanent guns. I regret it to this day. The great thing about Combat Arms was that I didn't have to pay to access it: All the Pay-to-Win aspects were free. This game, on the other hand, is charging every step of the way (At the time of writing). If you want a game that looks pre-2010 with extensive microtransactions, this is the game for you. Otherwise: AVOID AT ALL COSTS. It doesn't deserve the Ghost in the Shell" title."

I wouldn't recommend this game right now. It seems to have potential, but a lot of games we know that turned into ♥♥♥♥ had potential as well.

There's some issues I've had with the game so far:

Maybe more problems later edited in.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to like this game, but can't because the gunplay and movement feels really bad. Weapons can't hit the broad side of a barn when moving, and movement feels too sluggish to support a CS style strafe and tap playstyle, not to mention that ironsights do little to actually make the guns more controllable as it still has loads of horizontal recoil. The skill system is an interesting concept, but feels very gimmicky in comparison to other ability based shooters like Dirty Bomb. I'd also mention that the game feels a lot like the second coming of Combat Arms, but I won't go there as I'd rather not speculate about a title that's still in closed beta.

tl;dr guns handle like ♥♥♥♥ and movement is sluggish and codlike

It's an FPS game that you've seen so many times before, but the setting is great and the gunplay is enjoyable

Demolition is by far the best gamemode in the game at this moment imo, Gun customization is neat lots of stuff you can do to all weapons to really make it your own, plus skins if you're into that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't give much credit to FPS MMO's, simply because they're generally the same but with a different skin and engine. Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone Complex however is one of those FPS MMO's that is actually worth a play. If you've ever played Ghost Recon Online than you'll probably like this.

Weapons that actually play quite well and recoil that is actually a thing. Different characters, each with a unique skill that you can use and share with your team. With the auto rifle for example, you can't aim down the sights and spray and expect a kill, you actually have to control your fire.

The maps are small enough that you will run into enemies but big enough to feel not too crowded. All in all, it's quite a nice game and fairly well done. It's worth a play and this is Early Access, so there's room for improvement and extra content. And for as little as $5 for Early Access that's quite a bargain, a number of MMO's usually ask for around $15+ for Early Access packs.

Gameplay wise its fairly straight forward and easy to understand, of course you can feel free to change keybindings if you like. I know I did with Walk, but other than that one key they're pretty nice and simple.

This definetly has potential and with some updates and tweaks it can be quite funner (yes funner) to play.

My overall score? 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yes rating only stands if the game is significantly improved.

Pros:

+VA is on point, while annoying with its constant jabbering it sounds nice.
+Models look good
+Unlocking System is fair and seems to be permanent unlocking
+Abilities help with battle flow and allow for tactical advantages

Cons:

-You Can Melee finish people from the front. Just no. Make that a from behind option only.
-Guns litterally spew bullets in all directions. No again. Guns have firing patterns.
-Some abilities are unbalanced such as the rocket arm being OP as heck.
-No way to regain your abilities fairly at the current time in the same life
-No Medpacks or Medics currently in the game. Impossible to clutch something for your team.
-No Autobalance for teams, good luck 5 v 10ing those terrorists.

All in all, I WOULD recommend this game IF the devs fix this before it comes to open beta. Right now the utter stupidity that is the firearms and the lack of balance in certain aspects of the gameplay make the game unfair and unbalanced in game modes such as Demolition where the player is granted a single life. The ability for players to run up and instant kill you with their melee weapon even when you are face to face with them is absurd for who and what we're playing as.

This feels more like a close to end alpha then a beta. It has substance and it will do well with a loving touch up from Nexon but so help me god if it becomes P2W this review will change faster then italy changed sides in ww1.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a great early access game that feels half way done. Sure the maps may not be that many and you get a handful selection on weapons, but all that will change with updates.
-
You earn XP which allows you to purchase stuff. I haven't seen any micro-transaction feature here, which I like. It's not a F2P either. You have options that you later unlock to upgrade your weapon and other neat things. However, do note that this is early access so don't expect much, yet. I only have small amount of gameplay and I have found myself enjoying it already.
-
There's no season pass, so for me it's a good thing. I bought the ELITE version of the game, which gives you huge spending points and other cool perks.
-
I had to youtube gameplay first, but once you play it, I'm pretty sure you'll end up going back to it.
-
Leave your COD and Battlefield my gaming friend, this is for you ...
-
:)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've seen a lot of people comparing this game to CoD, which to an extent is kinda accurate rate, but that's not necessarily a bad thing, and this game far surpasses it in every way.(I especially like the fact that there's not any killstreak BS in this game, because evey one knows that the only way to make a game fair is to give the guy in the lead a handicap?) I personally haven't played much Call of Duty or Destiny (because I don't like either of them, not one bit) but as far as gameplay goes, it's pretty similar to that style so if you enjoy either of the aforementioned titles then I don't think you will be disapointed what-so-ever. If, however, you are like me and you prefer more of a Wolfenstein the New Order kind of experience when playing a modern shooter then this is probably going to be hit or miss for you. (most of this having to do with how much of a GitS fan you are) So if you like GitS and are looking for a shooter with a cyber punk atmosphere and some minor tactical abilities that show off your futuristic gear then this is most definitely for you. If you absolutely loathe both CoD and Destiny with a red hot firey passion as do I and you don't really care for novelty of the GitS look" then just wait until the game is actually "free" to play and then give it a try. I can not stress enough though that even if you don't like CoD one bit that this is still a very good game and I would highly recommend it to any fan of FPSes.

All that said I can only give this game a 9.5/10 though because I did not get to drive a Tachikoma :'("

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a huge GITS fan this game is a fantastic and welcome piece of eye and ear candy.

Original voice actors, excellent design and smooth graphics

(and the tatchkoma are freakin' adorable as usual).

But gameplay wise?

It's fairly janky with controls and framerate (and I'm running an 8 core 64 bit processor with a GTX980TI), hit detection is often spotty and the maps suffer from being almost suffocating.

It's definetly still within it's beta stages and needs a bit more polish in the gameplay department, but I wouldn't be quick to write the game off as another F2P P2W with a fancy coat of paint.

The company has treated the source material with great respect and I'm hoping that with time it will become smoother and more playable.

And PVE better roll in.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs someone who is familiar with Ghost In the Shell, my inner fanboy took over the moment I learned of this game's impending release date. Five dollars and ten minutes later I was playing my first match and as is the case with every online competative game I have ever played, I did reasonably well that one time. For every match thereafter I found that I had no say in how well I did, despite my best efforts, and that everyone I encountered with intention to cause my character bodily harm seems to play with a noticably higher degree of finesse than I do. Subsequently, where I am firing in controlled bursts with my basic M4 at the center of mass, I never seem to do enough damage fast enough to prevent my own demise, which always seems to happen the moment someone lines up my character with their crosshairs. My skill at the game (or lack thereof) nonwithstanding, the game itself runs very smoothly. It is difficult to say whether teams and weapons are balanced evenly, as I normally end up on the losing team. However, if played for its intended purpose, that is, for fun, the game is enjoyable. The only improvement I would recommend is controller support.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun game, but needs a few things..
Worth the few bucks for an early access pack if you're looking for a new shooter.
It is reminiscent of Blacklight Retribution if you played that.
Customize weps as you level, add light buffs to character you choose.
Each available character has a unique ablity some of which can buff the team as well.
TDM, CS:GO style bomb defuse, and control point modes.

Needs mouse bindings and more customization of controls.
Hit registry is still a  bit goofy sometimes, but I'll hope it's ironed out for open beta.
If you like AI and fps games it's a decent play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not an anime fan? Neither am I. That said, I've been having a good time with this game.

PROS:
•Gunplay requires managed firing, spraying only works at close range.
•SOLID alpha, I haven't ran into any bugs.
•Not overly anime, you could easily play this if you're not a fan of the genre.
•Pretty well balanced
•FAIR f2p model with a lot of options
•M4A1 starting weapon and AK47 unlocked, what's not to like?

•CONS:
•Hipfire is worthless in most situations
•Mouse accelerations/vsync/odd sensitivity at start, tweaking fixes this
-Scoped sensitivity at 100 is your exact in game sensitivity, only lower it if you prefer
•Muddy textures, players have blank faces- don't know if that's an artistic choice, laziness, or unpolished game
•Objective maps are Cluster%&$*'s due to all the player abilities
•SPAWN camping is a real issue.
•Think Tanks" are a pain in the A$$


Solid game that could easily count as your "arcadey shooter" fix if you're not a fan of COD. I'd highly recommend it for someone looking for some quick pick up shooting."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First Assault is, overall, a very enjoyable FPS with some high potentials.

Yes, it's a FPS. Not a sim, but more of an arcade. It has a feeling similar to that of Warface, CS, or Combatarms, with upgradable and customizable weapons, levels, and skills.

The interfaces are clean and the information they display is legible and helpful. Profile statistics with graphs and averages are very nice to see. The matchmaking as of now is quick and quite fair, and the graphics are sharp and entertainingly futuristic.

I'm still getting a feel for the game, but I have enjoyed every single match thus far.

I dig it, worth the $3.49 for the recruit pack I got.
